revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox noble|type | name = Alexander Seton | title = Lord Seton | image = | caption = | alt = | CoA = | more = no | succession = | reign = | reign-type = | predecessor = | successor = | suc-type = | spouse = Christian Cheyne | spouse-type = | issue = | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = | native_name = | styles = | titles = | noble family = | house-type = | father = | mother = | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | birth_place = | christening_date = | christening_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | death_place = | burial_date = | burial_place = | religion = | occupation = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{{URL|example.com}} --> | module = }} Sir '''Alexander Seton''', also known as '''Alexander de Seton''' ([[fl.]] 1311–c1348) was the Governor (sometimes referred to as the Keeper or the Captain) of [[Berwick-upon-Tweed|Berwick]].
==Life== Alexander Seton took part in [[Edward Bruce]]'s 1315 campaign in Ireland.<ref name=Bruce>[https://archive.org/details/houseofsetonstv100seto Seton, Bruce Gordon. ''The House of Seton'', Vol. I, Lindsay and MacLeod, Edinburgh, 1939]</ref> He signed the [[Declaration of Arbroath]] of 1320 asserting the independence of Scotland.
==Berwick-upon-Tweed== {{Campaignbox Second War of Scottish Independence}} In 1327 he was said to be appointed keeper of [[Berwick-upon-Tweed]]. For how long is unclear as on March 21 King Robert applied for a Safe-Conduct for him to go to England for negotiations.<ref>Anderson, William, ''The Scottish Nation'', Edinburgh, 1861, vol.8, p.436.</ref> In 1331 Sir Robert de Lawedre of The Bass was Keeper of the Scottish Marches and Custodian of the Castle of Berwick-upon-Tweed, receiving a fee attributed to those positions, at Pentecost, of £33.6s.8p. He is also described as Sheriff of Berwick, for which he received a further payment. <ref>''Exchequer Rolls of Scotland'', vol.1, 1264-1359, Edinburgh, 1878, pps: 279,313,339 & 399.</ref> He was still holding those positions the following year as mentioned by the historian of the town.<ref>''Berwick-upon-Tweed, the History of the Town and Guild'', by John Scott, London, 1888, pps.248-9.</ref>
In March 1333 [[Edward Balliol]], son and heir of King John Balliol, and Henry Beaumont, 4th Earl of Buchan, along with their supporters and those of the late [[John III Comyn, Lord of Badenoch|John Comyn]] invaded Scotland with the tacit support of [[Edward III of England]]. The army advanced quickly towards Berwick, which [[Capture of Berwick (1333)|was placed under siege]].
In 1333 Alexander Seton was again governor of the town of Berwick<ref>Anderson, 1861, p.436.</ref>, while [[Patrick V, Earl of March|Patrick de Dunbar, Earl of March]] was entrusted with the defence of the castle. After a long siege, an agreement to surrender Berwick within a certain time unless it has been relieved was obtained. Alexander's son, Thomas Seton, was given as a hostage.<ref>Anderson, 1861, p.436.</ref>
A small party of Scots led by Sir William Keith managed with some difficulty to make their way across the charred ruins of the old bridge to the northern bank of the Tweed and were able to force their way through to the walled town, which sat below the castle. Guardian of the Realm [[Archibald Douglas (died 1333)|Archibald Douglas]], who had crossed the Border into England in order to draw Edward, viewed this as a technical relief and sent messages to Edward calling on him to depart.
King [[Edward III of England]] viewed it differently, and as the town had not surrendered by the agreed date, saw this as a breach of the agreement and hanged Thomas Seton within sight of the besieged and his parents. Another treaty was agreed to so as to protect the other hostages. Berwick was eventually surrendered after the defeat of the Scots at the [[Battle of Halidon Hill]] on 19 July 1333. In this month, in a double tragedy, Seton's son William drowned in an attack upon the English fleet at Berwick, again in sight of his father.<ref>Anderson, 1861, p.436.</ref>
Alexander was present in [[Edward Balliol]]'s parliament on 10 February 1334 and witnessed the (temporary) cession of Berwick to the English. He had a Safe-conduct to go to England, 15 October 1337, and in August 1340 he was one of the hostages for John, Earl of Moray.<ref>Anderson, 1861, p.436.</ref>
He entered the [[Knights Hospitaller|Order of Knights of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem]], after 1341 and was styled [[Torphichen Preceptory|Master of Torphichen]] in 1345 after being appointed to the charge of the Order of Knights of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem House of Torphichen by the [[Hélion de Villeneuve]], Grand Master at Rhodes. Alexander obtained an temporary dispensation granted on 6 February 1346-47 by [[Pope Clement VI]], permitting Alexander to choose a confessor. As a Knight of the Order he was granted safe-conduct dated 12 August 1348 to enable him to visit King [[David II of Scotland]], who was imprisoned within the [[Tower of London]]. Alexander seems to have died shortly afterwards.
==Marriage and issue== He married Christian, daughter of [[Francis le Chen|Francis le Cheyne of Straloch]]; they had issue: * Thomas, executed outside Berwick in 1333 during the siege. * William, drowned July 1333 in an attack upon the English fleet at Berwick, during the siege. * Margaret, the heiress, married [[Alan de Wyntoun]], and had issue. Their children took the surname of Seton. * [[Alexander Seton (d. 1332)|Alexander]], killed opposing the landing of [[Edward Balliol]] at Kinghorn, 6 August 1332.<ref name=Bruce/> * [[John Seton, 1st Baron Parbroath|John of Parbroath]], died c. 1327.
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{DNB|wstitle=Seton, Alexander (fl.1311-1340)}}

{{Infobox criminal | honorific_prefix = | name = | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|5|25}} | birth_place = [[Barranquilla, Colombia]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Colombia]]n | other_names = "Narco Queen"
"Queen of Cocaine" | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Model, beauty queen | known_for = | religion = | criminal_charge = Drug trafficking and racketeering | conviction_penalty = 6 years imprisonment | conviction_status = Released on 27 September 2013 | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | conviction = }} '''Angie Sanselmente Valencia''' also known as '''Angie Sanclemente Valencia''' (born 25 May 1979)[http://www.interpol.int/public/Data/Wanted/Notices/Data/2010/38/2010_10938.asp Interpol Wanted Notice for Angie Sanclemente Valencia]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} is a former [[Colombia]]n beauty queen and lingerie model believed to be the ringleader of one of the world's largest drug syndicates. ==Background== Valencia is originally from Colombia. where she won the Reinado Nacional del Café, a national qualifying competition for the prestigious [[Reinado Internacional del Café]] (International Queen of Coffee) beauty pageant, in 2000 but was dethroned two days later when it was found she was married. The title was awarded to Ximena Andrea García Buitrago.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/03/24/colombia.drug.queen/index.html?hpt=C1|title=Model, allegedly drug queen, on the lam|publisher=CNN|author= Karl Penhaul|date=2010-03-26}}{{cite web | last =Zamora | first =Héctor Fabio | title =Destronada la Reina Nacional del Café | work =Archives | publisher =El Tiempo | date =2000-07-06 | url =http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1220246 | accessdate =2011-10-19 }} ==Syndicate== Valencia's operation is believed to be a "rival empire" to that of her former boyfriend, a Mexican drug baron known as "The Monster".[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/argentina/7304510/Lingerie-model-runs-one-of-worlds-largest-drug-gangs-according-to-police.html Telegraph.co.uk: Lingerie model runs one of world's largest drug gangs, according to police] She formed her own cartel after splitting with him.[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/world/1016790/police-hunt-ex-model-turned-cocaine-kingpin NineMSN: Police hunt ex-model turned 'cocaine kingpin'] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227091035/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/world/1016790/police-hunt-ex-model-turned-cocaine-kingpin |date=February 27, 2010 }} She is alleged to have recruited other models, whom she is quoted referring to as her "unsuspicious, beautiful angels" as drug traffickers, paying them up to around $5,000 (£3,200) per trip to transport [[cocaine]] from Argentina to England by way of [[Cancún]].[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2010/02/lingerie-model-sought-for-allegedly-hiring-beautiful-models-to-smuggle-cocaine/1 USAToday: Lingerie model allegedly hired beautiful models to smuggle cocaine] ==Investigation== Valencia's alleged syndicate was believed to have been exposed on 13 December 2009, when a 21-year-old woman, "Ariel L", was arrested with a suitcase containing 55 kg (121 pounds) of cocaine at [[Ezeiza International Airport]], Buenos Aires, Argentina. "L" made no attempt to hide the drugs inside her bags, leading authorities to suspect the ring had help from employees.[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/2010/02/24/2010-02-24_lingerie_model_angie_valencia_running_global_cocaine_ring__using_fellow_catwalke.html NY Daily News: Lingerie model Angie Valencia running global cocaine ring -- using fellow catwalkers as mules: cops] She is reported to have been told that no one at the airport would try to stop her, and an investigation was launched to find employees of the airport with possible links to the syndicate. After questioning "L", three additional arrests were made and a warrant was issued for Valencia's arrest. Authorities believed she was still in Argentina after she fled a hotel where she had been staying with her [[Pomeranian (dog)|pomeranian]]. Investigators attempted to trace her location through the address under which the animal was registered, but it only led them to an abandoned warehouse.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1253347/Runaway-lingerie-model-Angie-Sanselmente-Valencia-named-head-drug-gang.html DailyMail.co.uk: On the run, the lingerie model who heads an all-women cocaine-smuggling cartel] In March 2010 [[Interpol]] issued an international warrant for her arrest. Valencia was finally arrested in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on May 26, 2010, while staying in a local [[hostel]]. Police reported that she had registered under a false name and had tried to alter her appearance by dyeing her hair blonde.[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/05/26/argentina.model.arrested/?hpt=T2 CNN: Former model arrested in Argentina on drug charges] She was initially jailed on 27 May 2010 in the "Centro Federal de Detención de Mujeres Unidad número 31" in the city of Ezeiza, Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina. In October of the same year she was moved to the "Instituto Correccional de Mujeres Unidad número 3" also in Ezeiza after she suffered some violent attacks.http://www.ambito.com/noticia.asp?id=543682{{cite web | last =Hurley | first =Bevan | title ='Cocaine queen' moved after assaults in prison | work =New Zealand Herald | publisher =APN Holdings NZ | date =1 May 2011 | url =http://www.nzherald.co.nz/bevan-hurley/news/article.cfm?a_id=645&objectid=10722644 | accessdate =19 October 2011 }} She was released from prison and deported back to Colombia on 27 September 2013[http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/argentina-frees-deports-colombia-narco-model InsightCrime.org: Argentina Frees, Deports Colombia 'Narco Model'] after serving only half of her original 6 year and 8-month prison sentence.[http://www.clarin.com/narcotrafico/Confirman-anos-prision-Angie-Sanclemente_0_827317508.html Clarin.com: Confirman la pena de casi 7 años de prisión para Angie Sanclemente] She is banned from returning to Argentina. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Valencia, Angie Sanselmente}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Colombian businesspeople]] [[Category:Colombian criminals]] [[Category:Colombian drug traffickers]] [[Category:Colombian female models]] [[Category:Illegal drug trade in Mexico]] [[Category:Organized crime in Mexico]] [[Category:Female organized crime figures]] [[Category:Organized crime people]] [[Category:Outlaws]] [[Category:People from Barranquilla]] [[Category:Racketeering]] [[Category:Colombian women in business]]

'''Anselme Selosse''' is a [[Champagne (wine)|Champagne]] producer and [[Grower Champagne|grower]] based in the [[Avize]] region of [[Champagne (wine region)|Champagne]], [[France]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vinography.com/archives/2015/05/drinking_time_itself_the_champ.html|title=Drinking Time Itself: The Champagnes of Anselme Selosse|website=Vinography.Com: A Wine Blog|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref> He is the son of [[Jacques Selosse]] and is part of the fourth generation of his family to grow wine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldoffinewine.com/news/champagne-selosse-the-house-that-jacques-built-4205321|title=Champagne Selosse: The House that Jacques Built - World Of Fine Wine|website=www.worldoffinewine.com|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304475004579276402276259002|title=The Indie Innovator of Champagne Country|last=McInerney|first=Jay|date=2013-12-27|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref>
== Production == Anselme produces [[Jacques Selosse]] champagne, named after his father. He took over the family vineyard in 1980<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/champagnes-pop-stars|title=Champagne's Pop Stars|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref> after attending enology school in [[Burgundy]] and working alongside the legendary vignerons at [[Domaine Coche-Dury]], [[Domaine Leflaive]], and Domaine des Comtes Lafon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rarewineco.com/producer/selosse-champagne/|title=Selosse Champagne - Rare Wine Co.|website=www.rarewineco.com|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=But First, Champagne|last=White|first=David|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|year=2016|isbn=978-1-5107-1144-0|location=New York, NY, USA|pages=251|language=English|via=}}</ref> As of 2006, the Selosse fields numbered 37 acres, in 42 different parcels, almost all [[chardonnay]] with some [[pinot noir]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com//2006/06/15/tiny-bubble-makers/|title=Tiny Bubble-Makers|last=Asimov|first=Eric|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref>
His particular type of wine is known as [[Grower Champagne]], where grapes used to produce the wines are grown in vineyards owned by the Selosse family, rather than being purchased from other growers. He was one of the first winemakers to show that small producers can make their own wine.<ref name=":2"/> Anselme is considered a pioneer of biodynamics in Champagne and grows his grapes in an organic way.<ref name=":0" /> Selosse wines are fermented in [[Oak (wine)|oak barrels]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/dec/26/food/fo-wine26|title=The Questing Knight of New Age Champagne|last=SMITH|first=ROD|date=2001-12-26|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref> in contrast to the majority of Champagne producers who often use stainless steel tanks.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB1039119215825133713|title=Something New Is Bubbling In the Champagne Region|last=Journal|first=William Echikson Special to The Wall Street|date=2002-12-06|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref> Consequently, the wines are often described as [[Artisan|artisnal]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/wine/article/Champagne-s-solo-act-Single-vineyard-bottlings-3210472.php|title=Champagne's solo act: Single-vineyard bottlings allow France's revered houses to buck tradition|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref>
In 1994, the [[Gault Millau|Gault-Millau]] guide named him France’s best winemaker in every category.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.departures.com/shopping/worldly-goods/frances-distinctive-affordable-champagne|title=France's Distinctive, Affordable Champagne|website=Departures|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref>
== Hotel == Anselme and his wife Corinne, own and operate Hôtel Les Avisés,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g1572192-d2202458-Reviews-Hotel_Restaurant_les_Avises-Avize_Marne_Champagne_Ardenne.html|title=Hotel Restaurant les Avises (Avize, France) - UPDATED 2016 Hotel Reviews - TripAdvisor|website=www.tripadvisor.com|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref> a 10-room inn adjacent to the family winery.<ref name=":2"/> While his champagne house does not take many tasting appointments, staying at the hotel is one of the ways to meet this winemaker.<ref name=":2" />
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Selosse, Anselme}} [[Category:Champagne producers]] [[Category:Winemakers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Antonio Galloni | occupation = Wine critic | nationality = American | subject = Wine | influences = | influenced = }}
'''Antonio Galloni''' is an [[United States of America|American]] [[wine]] [[critic]] and founder and CEO of Vinous, one of the world's most influential wine publications, for which he is also the lead critic covering the wines of Bordeaux, California, Italy, and Champagne. From 2006 to 2013 Galloni was a [[wine tasting|tasting]] staff member of [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]]'s publication ''[[The Wine Advocate]]''. In May 2013, Galloni founded [[Vinous Media|Vinous]] (http://vinousmedia.com).<ref name=sf/><ref>Official Vinous website (May 20, 2013). [http://vinousmedia.com/statics/about About]</ref>
== Biography == Galloni was born in Caracas, Venezuela to an Italian father and American mother. When he was 11 the family moved to Sarasota, Florida where his parents retailed Italian wines. This early exposure to wine began a lifelong fascination with wine. Galloni’s maternal grandmother introduced him to the wines of Burgundy, while his father instilled in him that “there are two great wines in the world: Barolo and Champage”.
Galloni received a degree from Boston’s Berklee College of Music in jazz composition and guitar. After a stint as a musician and waiter, which led him to get to know many of the new California wineries of the time, he took a job with Putnam Investments and was soon after sent to Putnam’s Milan office. This opportunity was a total immersion in Italian wine and culture. Galloni returned to the U.S. to acquire a formal business education.
==Career== In 2004, while studying for an MBA at MIT's Sloan School of Management, Galloni began publication of the ''Piedmont Report'' newsletter profiling the wine of [[Piemonte wine|Piedmont]]. At the time the only critic who had been writing about the wines of Italy in English was James Suckling. Within weeks ''Piedmont Report'' had subscribers in more than 25 countries and quickly established itself as the premier guide in the world for Piedmont wines. Galloni turned down an offer to write for Robert Parker’s ''The Wine Advocate'' to work for a brief stint at Deutsche Bank in New York City. In 2006, he accepted Parker’s offer to join ''The Wine Advocate'' as a reviewer of [[Italian wine]],<ref>{{cite web|last= Goldberg |first= Howard G., ''Decanter.com'' |title= Parker announces new staff |url= http://www.decanter.com/news/wine-news/487005/parker-announces-new-staff |date=September 1, 2006 }}</ref> and became a contributor to Parker's ''Wine Buyer’s Guide''.<ref>{{cite web|last= Comiskey |first= Patrick, ''Los Angeles Times'' |title=Robert Parker shares his soapbox World of wine scores |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2008/oct/15/food/fo-parker15 |date= October 15, 2008 }}</ref> In January 2011, as Parker restructured the coverage of his staff of reviewers and announced he would no longer review [[California wine]], Galloni's area of coverage was expanded to include California, [[Champagne (wine)|Champagne]], [[Chablis wine|Chablis]] and the [[Côte d'Or (escarpment)|Côte d'Or]].<ref name=sf>Bonné, Jon, ''San Francisco Chronicle'' (February 7, 2011). [http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/jonbonne/2011/02/07/robert-parker-passes-the-california-torch/ Robert Parker passes the California torch]</ref><ref>Yarrow, Alder, vinography.com (February 5, 2011). [http://www.vinography.com/archives/2011/02/the_end_of_an_era_robert_parke.html The End of an Era: Robert Parker Stops Reviewing California Wine]</ref>
Galloni has stated in ''The Wine Advocate'' issue 186 that he will only review Champagne that provides a [[Disgorging|disgorgement]] date so he may accurately rate a Champagne by its release.<ref name=sf/><ref>Colman, Tyler, drvino.com (December 29, 2009). [http://www.drvino.com/2009/12/29/champange-champagne-values-bargains-bordeaux/ SIPPED: upgrading label info?]</ref>
In 2013 Antonio left the ''TWA ''to start ''Vinous''. At the time of his departure, Galloni was the lead critic at ''The Wine Advocate'', and had authored 1/3rd of the reviews published by ''TWA'' in 2012. Galloni also ran the world’s most followed bulletin board on Italian wines and spearheaded ''TWA''’s production of video content. He developed tailored public events & seminars such as the highly anticipated “La Festa del Barolo,” vertical tastings focused on the benchmark wines of Italy, and numerous charity dinners.
==Vinous launch== In February 2013, following the announcement by Parker that he was stepping down as editor-in-chief of ''The Wine Advocate'' and had sold a controlling stake to a Singapore investor, Galloni announced himself that he would leave the publication and establish his own internet publication,<ref name="nyt13">Asimov, Eric, ''The New York Times'' (February 12, 2013).[http://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/12/a-new-web-venture-for-antonio-galloni/ A New Web Venture for Antonio Galloni]</ref><ref>Barmann, Jay, ''GrubStreet.com'' (February 12, 2013). [http://sanfrancisco.grubstreet.com/2013/02/robert-parker-antonio-galloni-wine-advocate-web-venture.html Robert Parker Protégé Antonio Galloni Leaves The Wine Advocate to Launch New Web Venture]</ref><ref name="deca-ag">Woodard, Richard, ''Decanter,com'' (February 14, 2013). [http://www.decanter.com/news/wine-news/530861/galloni-leaves-wine-advocate Galloni leaves Wine Advocate]</ref> launched under the brand [[Vinous Media|Vinous]] (http://vinousmedia.com). Aimed towards a broader demographic of wine consumers, Galloni has stated he would continue to report on the wines of Italy, Champagne, California and Burgundy and will cover wines from [[Bordeaux]] from the 2013 vintage, as well as craft spirits.<ref name="deca-ag" />
Vinous has since acquired Stephen Tanzer’s ''International Wine Cellar'' and the apps Delectable and Banquet.
==Lawsuit==
In March 2013, it was reported that ''The Wine Advocate'' had filed a [[United States federal courts|federal]] [[lawsuit]] against Galloni five weeks after his departure for breach of contract, fraud and defamation.<ref name="sf-sue">Bonné, Jon, ''San Francisco Chronicle'' (March 20, 2013). [http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2013/03/20/the-wine-advocate-sues-antonio-galloni/ The Wine Advocate sues Antonio Galloni]</ref><ref name="dec-sue">Lechmere, Adam, ''Decanter.com'' (March 21, 2013). [http://www.decanter.com/news/wine-news/583732/robert-parker-s-wine-advocate-sues-antonio-galloni-for-fraud-and-defamation Robert Parker's Wine Advocate sues Antonio Galloni for fraud and defamation]</ref><ref name="nyt-sue">Asimov, Eric, ''The New York Times'' (March 21, 2013). [http://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/21/robert-parker-vs-antonio-galloni/ Robert Parker vs. Antonio Galloni]</ref> The lawsuit, filed in [[United States district court|U.S. District Court]] in Maryland, advancing the complaint, was never served.<ref name="shk-sue">''Shanken News Daily'' (March 21, 2013). [http://www.shankennewsdaily.com/index.php/2013/03/21/5406/parkers-advocate-suing-former-contributor-galloni-in-federal-court/ Parker’s Advocate Suing Former Contributor Galloni In Federal Court]</ref> All the articles cited in the case have subsequently appeared on Galloni's [[Vinous Media]] website.<ref>Official Vinous website. [http://vinousmedia.com/articles Articles]</ref>
According to Robert Parker, ''The Wine Advocate’s'' efforts were “simply a matter of retrieving a service we paid for,” rather than “an attempt to stop Antonio from moving on; we continue to wish him our very best.”
==See also== *[[List of wine personalities]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.vinousmedia.com/ VinousMedia.com] official site
{{DEFAULTSORT:Galloni, Antonio}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Wine critics]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} '''Arthur Jay Finkelstein''' (May 18, 1945 – August 18, 2017) was a [[New York (state)|New York State]]-based [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] (GOP) consultant who had worked for [[American conservatism|conservative]] and right-wing candidates in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Israel]], [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]] over the past four decades.
With his brother, Ronald, he ran a political consulting and survey-research firm based in [[Irvington, New York]]. Finkelstein's specialties were polling, strategy, message, media, ad placement, and advising on general campaign management. In 2013, he was honored by the [[American Association of Political Consultants]], and named to its Hall of Fame, "the highest honor that the working members of the profession can bestow upon a colleague."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theaapc.org/awards/hall-of-fame|title=Hall of Fame|website=theaapc.org|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
==Youth and education== Finkelstein grew up in a lower-middle-class [[American Jews|Jewish]] family, living in [[Brooklyn]]'s East New York section until age 11, then in [[Levittown, New York]], and later [[Queens]]. He and his two brothers attended local public schools; Finkelstein graduated from Forest Hills High School. Their parents were immigrants from Eastern Europe,<ref name="samroberts">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/19/us/politics/arthur-finkelstein-innovative-influential-conservative-strategist-dies-at-72.html|title=Arthur Finkelstein, Innovative, Influential Conservative Strategist, Dies at 72|first=Sam|last=Roberts|date=August 19, 2017|accessdate=August 26, 2017|website=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.google.com&gwh=089C9969ED118EFCCA3706372C68E4B0&gwt=pay] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909232900/http://www.google.com/ |date=September 9, 2017 }}</ref> and the father worked as a cabdriver<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/05/nyregion/1992-elections-new-york-state-behind-victory-d-amato-strategist-shuns-spotlight.html?scp=1&sq=%22Arthur+J.+Finkelstein%22+d%27amato&st=nyt|title=BEHIND THE VICTORY; D'Amato Strategist Shuns the Spotlight|last=Janofsky|first=Michael|date=November 5, 1992|work=The |accessdate=October 9, 2009}}</ref> and did various jobs in the garment trade. While a student at [[Columbia University]], Finkelstein interviewed and helped produce radio programs for author/philosopher [[Ayn Rand]],<ref name="princeton.edu">{{cite web |url=http://www.princeton.edu/~maw/Link%20Paper.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015155426/http://www.princeton.edu/~maw/Link%20Paper.pdf |archivedate=October 15, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and was a volunteer at the New York headquarters of the [[Draft Goldwater Committee]] in 1963–64 (the famous "Suite 3505").<ref name="samroberts"/> He eventually earned a bachelor's degree from [[Queens College]] in 1967 in economics and political science.<ref name="samroberts"/><ref name="washingtonpost.com">Schudel, Matt, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/arthur-finkelstein-shadowy-campaign-mastermind-and-gop-operative-dies-at-72/2017/08/19/0bd638c6-84e8-11e7-902a-2a9f2d808496_story.html "Arthur Finkelstein, quietly influential GOP campaign mastermind, dies at 72"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', August 19, 2017.</ref>
==Early career (Buckley, Nixon, Helms, Reagan), 1968–76== In 1968, Finkelstein did behind-the-scenes election analysis for [[NBC News]], part of the network's team working under former Census director [[Richard M. Scammon]] and exit-polling pioneer Irwin A. "Bud" Lewis.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
In 1969–70, he worked as a computer programmer in the Data Processing department of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] at its offices on 11 Wall Street in lower Manhattan. He was a familiar face in Greenwich Village, where he often argued politics from a street-corner soapbox.<ref name="samroberts"/> In his spare time, he aided State Senator [[John Marchi]] in his unsuccessful Republican-Conservative campaign for Mayor of New York City in 1969.<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979">Lynn, Frank, "A Political Pollster for Conservatives", ''The New York Times'', December 16, 1979.</ref>
[[F. Clifton White]], mastermind of the [[Draft Goldwater Committee]], was Finkelstein's political patron and consulting partner in the early 1970s in the firm, DirAction Services. The young pollster's first electoral success came at age 25 in 1970, with the independent Conservative campaign of [[James L. Buckley]] for senator from New York. This was one of several New York statewide contests where he was able to maneuver his clients to victory in three-way scenarios. Buckley won a plurality upset victory over GOP incumbent [[Charles Goodell]] and favored Democrat [[Richard Ottinger]]. Of that election night, Buckley later wrote, "By 10 pm, ... Finkelstein (my volunteer analyst who called the final results within one-tenth of one percent based on a Sunday-night telephone survey) assured me that I had won."<ref>Buckley, James L., ''If Men Were Angels: A View From the Senate'' (New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1976), p. 25</ref> Finkelstein encapsulated Buckley's message in the catchphrase, "Isn't it about time we had a Senator?"<ref name="samroberts"/>
Finkelstein's work in New York led to his serving in 1971-72 as one of several pollsters for President [[Richard M. Nixon]]'s [[United States presidential election, 1972|re-election campaign]] developing sophisticated [[demographics|demographic]] analysis.<ref>Evidence of Finkelstein's polling work for Nixon is cited in ''Catholic Historical Review'', Jan 2012 issue, Vol 98, No. 1, "CATHOLIC CACOPHONY: Richard Nixon, The Church and Welfare Reform", specifically "Letter from Arthur Finkelstein to Robert Marik, December 16, 1971, attached to Memorandum from Roy Morey to John Ehrlichman, September 24, 1971, White House Central Files, Subject File - Religious Matters, Box 18, Folder: RM 3-1 Catholic 1/1/71-12/72, RMNPP"</ref>
The 1972 election also saw the first of his three victorious campaigns to elect [[Jesse Helms]] as U.S. senator from North Carolina.<ref name="newsweek.com">[https://archive.is/20130208131845/http://www.newsweek.com/id/102818/page/2]</ref> After the election, Finkelstein worked with Helms political aides [[Thomas F. Ellis|Tom Ellis]] and [[Carter Wrenn]] to establish a permanent conservative organization, the [[National Congressional Club]],<ref>Taylor, Paul, ''The Washington Post'', October 15, 1982, "Helms Modernizes GOP Political Machine for the Electronic Age"</ref> which lasted until 1995.<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017">Christensen, Rob, ''Raleigh News & Observer'', September 8, 2017, "He was the man behind the curtain in NC politics"</ref>
Finkelstein and White went their separate ways in the mid-1970s,<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/> and he founded his own firm, Arthur J. Finkelstein & Associates (often later shortened to AJF & Associates).<ref name="samroberts"/> In the 1976 presidential primaries, White supported [[Gerald Ford]],<ref>''Los Angeles Times'', January 11, 1993, "OBIT: F. Clifton White; Architect of '64 Goldwater Campaign"</ref> while Finkelstein worked for [[Ronald Reagan]]'s insurgent campaign.
He helped Helms's Congressional Club turn around the faltering Reagan effort with a victory in the April North Carolina primary.<ref name="princeton.edu"/> His work continued in the subsequent Texas primary. "Finkelstein had been a key figure in 1976, when he helped orchestrate Reagan's campaign-saving comeback in North Carolina" which was crucial in Reagan's further political advancement.<ref name="North Carolina 1976">{{cite book|title=Reagan's Revolution: The Untold Story of the Campaign That Started It All|last=Shirley|first= Craig|authorlink= Craig Shirley|year=2005|publisher=Nelson Current|location= Nashville, Tennessee|isbn= 0-7852-6049-8|page=417}}</ref>
At Finkelstein's urging, Reagan made a major issue of the impending [[Panama Canal Treaties]], which [[Gerald Ford]] was negotiating and which infuriated conservative voters. (This proved to be Reagan's signature issue throughout the late 1970s.) As [[Jules Witcover]] later reported, "Tens of thousands of [[George Wallace|Wallace]] voters were gradually cut adrift during his slide [in the primaries] ... and Reagan media man Arthur Finkelstein recruited a Wallaceite from Fort Worth to radio and television spots for Reagan ... It was dynamite."<ref>Witcover, Jules, ''Marathon'' (New York: Viking Press, 1977), p. 419<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref> The [[Associated Press]]'s Mike Robinson wrote Finkelstein was "viewed by many as instrumental in Gov. Reagan's 1976 primary successes in North Carolina and Texas."<ref>Robinson, Mike, Washington Dateline, [[Associated Press]], May 5, 1979</ref>
==NCPAC, a GOP Senate majority, and Reagan's victory, 1975–80== Passage of the post-Watergate [[Federal Election Campaign Act]] (FECA) amendments, and the subsequent 1976 Supreme Court decision in [[Buckley v. Valeo]], drastically altered the rules by which Presidential and Congressional contests were waged. Finkelstein was among the first to sense an opportunity, and pioneered the concept and execution of [[independent expenditure]] campaigns, which would operate as a third force in an election beyond the control of candidate or party officials.<ref name="samroberts"/>
Beginning in 1975, Finkelstein was the chief strategist behind the most successful IE operation of this period, the [[National Conservative Political Action Committee]] (NCPAC).<ref>Sinclair, Ward, ''The Washington Post'', October 8, 1982, "Is Politics Threatening to Become Poll-itics?; The Electorate and the Art of Pulse-Taking"</ref> Its Executive Director was Finkelstein protégé [[Terry Dolan (activist)|Terry Dolan]]. In 1981 New Right activist [[Richard Viguerie]] wrote, "NCPAC relies heavily on research and polling, a reflection of one of its founders, conservative pollster Arthur Finkelstein."<ref>Viguerie, Richard, ''The New Right: We're Ready to Lead'' (Falls Church, Va.: Viguerie Co., rev. ed. 1981), p. 57; and Edwards, Lee, ''The Conservative Revolution'', (New York: Free Press, 1999), p. 186<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref>
In 1978, NCPAC was instrumental in the defeat of Democrats [[Dick Clark (senator)|Dick Clark]] in Iowa and [[Thomas J. McIntyre]] in New Hampshire. Both liberal senators were replaced by committed conservatives.<ref>''The Washington Post'', December 13, 1982, "Latest Mixers Of Politics, Religion Scrutinized"</ref> NCPAC ran hard-hitting ads for television, radio and newspapers, crafted by Finkelstein. A central idea behind the strategy was to expose the liberal words and actions in Washington of elected officials, usually senators, whose moderate or conservative public image at home was at odds with their actual voting record.<ref>Martin, Lawrence, ''Toronto Globe and Mail'', December 28, 1978, "U.S. veers toward New Right on anti-Government wave"</ref>
NCPAC hit its peak in 1980, operating IEs in six states, its ads and organizing efforts helping to topple liberal Democrats in Iowa ([[John Culver]]), Indiana ([[Birch Bayh]]), Idaho ([[Frank Church]]) and South Dakota ([[George McGovern]]).<ref>Andersen, Tena, Associated Press, October 3, 1980, "National Conservative Group Drops out of Anti-McGovern Campaign"</ref> Less well-known were NCPAC's TV ads in the presidential contest, both negative (one featuring [[Jimmy Carter]] in a 1976 debate, another with [[Ted Kennedy|Edward Kennedy]] shouting "And no more Jimmy Carter!") and positive (footage of [[Ronald Reagan]] speaking on values); Finkelstein concentrated these ad buys in closely contested Southern states (e.g., Mississippi, Louisiana, Alabama), all of which switched from Carter to Reagan in 1980.<ref>Alexander, Herbert, ''Financing the 1980 Election'' (Rowman & Littlefield, 1983)</ref>
Finkelstein believed in the usefulness of third forces to help conservatives win elections, but not a conservative third party (a much-discussed option in the mid-1970s). At a February 1977 conference, he told activists, "The development of a third party may very well hurt conservative options in the future by diluting them," warning that traditional and emotional ties to party labels would keep many conservatives in their present parties.<ref>Don McLeod, Associated Press, February 4, 1977</ref> He said the Watergate scandal had cost the GOP the one clear advantage it had over the Democrats - the perception by voters that it was the more honest of the two parties. Nevertheless, he counseled against third-party option, saying this would succeed only in drawing conservatives out of both parties, creating a weak satellite party and leaving the major parties more liberal.<ref>Cannon, Lou, "Conservatives Are Cool To Forming Third Party", ''The Washington Post'', February 5, 1977.</ref>
Besides NCPAC, Finkelstein found particular success during this period in guiding individual Senate and House campaigns. Reagan backer and political unknown [[Orrin Hatch]] won a resounding 56% victory in Utah in 1976 against a three-term Democratic incumbent. In 1978, he was consultant to the successful re-election campaigns of [[Jesse Helms]] in North Carolina and [[Strom Thurmond]] in South Carolina<ref>''The Washington Post'', May 29, 1978</ref> — the latter being Thurmond's last seriously contested race (he served until 2002, age 100). That same year, Finkelstein shepherded [[Carroll Campbell]] to his first win in South Carolina's Greenville-area 4th Congressional District.<ref name="newsweek.com"/><ref>Gailey, Phil, ''The New York Times'', September 24, 1986, "Bigotry Issue in Carolina Campaign"</ref>
After a brief interlude early in 1979 as adviser to conservative Congressman [[Phil Crane]],<ref>Robinson, Mike, Associated Press March 6, 1979</ref> Finkelstein returned as one of the pollsters advising [[Ronald Reagan]]'s primary campaign.<ref>Lynn, Frank, ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 16, 1979, Sec. 22, p. 1</ref> His services were also reportedly sought by the [[George H.W. Bush]] campaign.<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/>
In 1980, he engineered<ref>Herman, Robin, ''The New York Times'', August 23, 1980, "A Persistent D'Amato Focuses on Javits's Record and Health"</ref> the improbable Senate victory of Long Island supervisor [[Alfonse D'Amato]] over incumbent [[Jacob Javits]], another three-way contest where the Democrat (Congresswoman [[Liz Holtzman]]) was favored.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> He advised the successful campaign of 31-year-old State Senator [[Don Nickles]] for U.S. Senate from Oklahoma.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1997/08/28/1997-08-28_sen__fires_gay_pollster.html|location=New York|work=Daily News|title=Sen. Fires Gay Pollster|date=August 28, 1997}}</ref> Most unlikely was the victory (aided by [[National Congressional Club]] allies) of [[John Porter East|John East]] in the North Carolina Senate contest;<ref name="Allen, Kenneth S. 1988">Allen, Kenneth S., ''St. Petersburg Times'', April 11, 1988, "''Attack politics' specialist to lead Mack campaign"</ref> East was a little-known professor who used a wheelchair, recruited for the race by [[Jesse Helms]] and elected through the efforts of Ellis, Wrenn, Finkelstein and the Helms organization.<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017"/>
Besides Campbell, House winners included [[Duncan Hunter]] in California and [[Denny Smith]] in Oregon (both 1980), the latter toppling House [[Ways and Means Committee]] chair [[Al Ullman]]. Finkelstein also had his share of Senate losses, including two by previous client [[James L. Buckley|James Buckley]] (1976, New York,<ref>''The New York Times'', October 18, 1976</ref> and 1980, Connecticut),<ref>Madden, Richard L., ''The New York Times'', December 21, 1980, "It Costs More to Win Votes"</ref> and with Avi Nelson (1978, Massachusetts). Finkelstein was also pollster-strategist for Maryland Congressman [[Robert Bauman]], who narrowly lost his seat after he was charged in DC with homosexual solicitation, one month before the November election.<ref>Feinstein, John, "Bauman: 'I'll Carry This to My Grave'", ''The Washington Post'', August 15, 1982.</ref>
==The 1980s== During the 1980 campaign Finkelstein was a Reagan pollster and had been "aboard the Reagan campaign" since mid-1979.<ref name="Reagan on Carter in Baltimore 478">{{cite book|title=Rendezvous with Destiny: Ronald Reagan and the Campaign That Changed America|last=Shirley|first=Craig|authorlink= Craig Shirley|year=2009|publisher=ISI Books|location=Wilmington, Delaware|isbn=978-1-933859-55-2|page=478}}</ref> from the early primary days all the way through November. Having ridden (and driven) the Republican wave of 1977–80, he found the 1980s a period of consolidation, helping clients grow their base and win re-election.
In 1981, Finkelstein was one of four pollsters designated to do work on behalf of the Reagan White House, paid by the [[Republican National Committee]]. (The others were [[Richard Wirthlin]], [[Robert Teeter]] and Tully Plesser).<ref>Cattani, Richard, Reagan will keep close tabs on public image, ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'', January 13, 1981, p. 1</ref> [[Newsweek]] reported in 1982 that "each of the President's top three advisers has his own numbers man: "Wirthlin became [[Edwin Meese]]'s pollster, Teeter became [[James Baker]]'s and now Finkelstein has become [[Michael Deaver]]'s."<ref>Gelman, Eric, A Third Pollster for the White House, ''[[Newsweek]]'', July 5, 1982.</ref>
Throughout Reagan's first term and into the 1984 re-election campaign, Finkelstein advised Deaver, conducting polls and planning events and visuals (e.g. Reagan's trip to France for the 40th anniversary of [[D-Day]]). As ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported: "For the White House, Finkelstein is more of an idea man than a pollster, specializing in media events such as the president's "spontaneous" drop-ins on disadvantaged individuals and institutions."<ref>Cannon, Lou, "Public's Personality Seems Split in Its Perception of Reagan", ''[[The Washington Post]]'', July 12, 1982.</ref>
He also began dabbling in gubernatorial contests—in New Jersey (1981), for [[Jim Wallwork]] (defeated by [[Thomas Kean|Tom Kean]] in the GOP primary);<ref>Carroll, Maurice, "Wallwork Seeks to Ride Conservative Tide in New Jersey", ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 5, 1981, p. B2</ref> and in New York (1982), for [[Paul J. Curran|Paul Curran]] (defeated by [[Lewis Lehrman]] for the nomination).<ref>Lynn, Frank, "Curran Trails Lehrman at Start of GOP Race", ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 19, 1982, pp. 2–28</ref>
In 1982, Finkelstein client [[Orrin Hatch]] sailed to re-election in Utah, while in Florida, banker [[Connie Mack III]] won his first campaign for the House.<ref name="Allen, Kenneth S. 1988"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.healthaffairs.org/cgi/reprint/19/4/134.pdf|format=PDF|title=A Senator's Quest To Beat Cancer|website=Content.healthaffairs.org|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref> But his efforts on behalf of Democrat-turned-Republican Congressman [[Eugene Atkinson]] of Pennsylvania ended in defeat,<ref>Robbins, William, ''The New York Times'', October 17, 1981, "PENNSYLVANIANS HOPING TO BENEFIT IN LEGISLATOR'S SHIFT TO G.O.P."</ref> as did the Congressional campaign in Westchester County of John Fossel, chairman of Oppenheimer Funds.<ref name="Purdum"/>
That year, NCPAC (with Finkelstein as pollster-strategist) was successful in only one targeted race (helping to oust Democrat [[Howard Cannon]] in Nevada), failed in several others (e.g. Maryland),<ref>Baker, Donald P., Washington Post, June 3, 1981, "Rep. Holt Working Toward A Challenge of Sen. Sarbanes; GOP Rep. Marjorie S. Holt Working Toward Challenging Democratic Sen. Paul S. Sarbanes"</ref> and thereafter declined in influence. The pitfalls of running IEs and campaigns at the same time were illustrated when NCPAC was sued for running ads in early 1982 against New York Sen. [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]]—around the same time as Finkelstein was working for GOP Senate candidate [[Bruce Caputo]].<ref>Albin Krebs and Robert McG. Thomas, ''The New York Times'', September 16, 1981, "NOTES ON PEOPLE; Senator Moynihan Gets a Challenger for 1982 "</ref>
In 1986, a federal court ruled against NCPAC, and ''[[The Washington Post]]'' editorialized, "Both NCPAC and the Caputo campaign used the same pollster, Arthur Finkelstein. They could hardly be said to be independent unless the Caputo side of Mr. Finkelstein's brain refrained from communicating with the NCPAC side."<ref>"The FEC's Good News", ''[[The Washington Post]]'', May 22, 1986, p. A18</ref> (Finkelstein himself was not sued or charged; ironically, Caputo's campaign had imploded after revelations he'd lied about serving in the military, and Moynihan was never seriously challenged.)<ref>Edsall, Thomas B., "Election Law Violations Admitted in '82 Race", ''The Washington Post'', January 20, 1984.</ref> As late as 1987, Finkelstein was doing surveys for NCPAC (e.g. in New Mexico).<ref>NCPAC Release on New Mexico and [[Jeff Bingaman]], April 30, 1987; accessed through PR Newswire.</ref>
During the early 1980s, Finkelstein became involved in international polling, for groups such as Canada's [[National Citizens Coalition]]<ref>United Press International, January 13, 1983, "Clark's popularity in decline, poll says"</ref> and (in 1986) the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario]] after losing their majority in the [[Ontario Legislature]] following the 1985 elections.<ref>Speirs, Rosemary, "The Tories' desperate bid to hang on", ''Toronto Star'', October 15, 1986.</ref>
The 1984 election cycle saw him involved in three pitched battles for the Senate, the most heralded being the challenge of Democratic Governor [[Jim Hunt]] to Helms in North Carolina. The Ellis-Wrenn-Finkelstein team used the permanent assets of the [[National Congressional Club]] to wage a three-year campaign to undermine Hunt,<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017"/> including a groundbreaking opposition-research and advertising effort that redefined the popular governor as a tax-raising national Democrat.<ref name="Allen, Kenneth S. 1988"/> Helms won with 52%, in what was then the most expensive Senate race in history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dyn.politico.com/printstory.cfm?uuid=FF8B80E5-3048-5C12-004D234BCA6E32A4|title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 16, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716055026/http://dyn.politico.com/printstory.cfm?uuid=FF8B80E5-3048-5C12-004D234BCA6E32A4|archivedate=July 16, 2011}}</ref> However, this was the last Helms campaign on which Finkelstein would serve as pollster. Before Helms' 1990 re-election campaign, Finkelstein told the North Carolina team he couldn't work for the Senator any more. According to Carter Wrenn the New Yorker was polite about it, didn't offer a reason and recommended one of his proteges, John McLaughlin, handle the survey and strategy work. At the time, Helms was becoming one of the leading critics of the gay rights movement. "I took it that Arthur wasn't comfortable with Jesse's stand on the social issues," Wrenn said, and chalked it up to Finkelstein's libertarian views.<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017"/>
in November 1984, Finkelstein also found success in New Hampshire, as he aided freshman conservative Sen. [[Gordon Humphrey]]<ref>[[Mary McGrory|McGrory, Mary]], "Sen. Humphrey's Unexpected Stand With the MX Mavericks", ''The Washington Post'', June 2, 1983.</ref> in overcoming a tough challenge from long-time Democratic Congressman [[Norman D'Amours]]. But in Massachusetts, after winning a contested primary against [[Elliot Richardson]],<ref>Black, Chris, ''Boston Globe'', September 9, 1984, "GOP SENATE RACE A STUDY IN CONTRASTS"</ref> businessman [[Ray Shamie]] lost a close uphill battle to Lt. Gov. [[John Kerry]] for the Senate seat vacated by [[Paul Tsongas]].<ref>Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 16 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 1984'' (CQ Press, 1985)</ref> Another client, Congressman [[Tom Corcoran (politician)|Tom Corcoran]], failed to dislodge incumbent [[Charles H. Percy|Charles Percy]] from the Senate nomination in Illinois, despite tough ads (attributed to Finkelstein) suggesting Percy was personally close to [[PLO]] leader [[Yasser Arafat]].<ref name="Neal, Steve 1986">Neal, Steve, "Dirty Political Ads Can Muddy the Perpetrator", ''Chicago Tribune'', April 13, 1986.</ref>
His Congressional clients in 1984 included three New Yorkers -- [[Joseph DioGuardi]] (who won election in Westchester County),<ref>Feron, James, ''The New York Times'', October 5, 1986, "Abzug and DioGuardi On Road to November"</ref> Robert Quinn (who lost in Nassau County)<ref>Lynn, Frank. "A WEALTHY NOVICE TAKES ON INCUMBENT FOR SEAT IN CONGRESS", ''The New York Times'', October 28, 1984.</ref> and [[Serphin Maltese]] (who lost a close race for [[Geraldine Ferraro]]'s seat in Queens).<ref>Maltese campaign press release, October 19, 1984, accessed through PR Newswire</ref> He helped guide [[Bill Cobey]] to an upset victory for Congress in North Carolina against incumbent [[Ike Andrews]].<ref>Gallagher, Andrew & Timothy Bannon, "GOP House gains tied to money, religious groups", United Press International, November 11, 1984.</ref>
In 1985, Finkelstein polled for the gubernatorial campaign of Virginia Attorney General [[Marshall Coleman]], losing the nomination to Wyatt Durrette (who was then defeated by Democrat [[Gerald Baliles]]).<ref>Sherwood, Tom, "Coleman Poll Shows Voters Favor Him for Va. Governor; Durrette, Parris Dismiss Effect of Survey", ''The Washington Post'', November 15, 1984.</ref>
Republicans lost their Senate majority in the November 1986 midterm elections. Nevertheless, Finkelstein's leading clients won re-election — [[Alfonse D'Amato]] in New York,<ref>Lynn, Frank, ''The New York Times'', October 20, 1986, "Aggressive Tactics Raise $7.7 million for D'Amato"</ref> and [[Don Nickles]] in Oklahoma.<ref>Gerstel, Steve, United Press International, April 20, 1986, "Political Notebook"</ref> However, his candidate to succeed John East in North Carolina, [[David Funderburk]], lost his primary,<ref>''[[National Journal]]'', May 3, 1986</ref> and he fared no better in Ohio, where Congressman [[Tom Kindness]] made little headway against incumbent Sen. [[John Glenn]] as well as in Illinois, where state legislator [[Judy Koehler]] failed to dislodge Senator [[Alan Dixon]].<ref name="Neal, Steve 1986"/> Finkelstein also steered Californian [[Elton Gallegly]] to his initial victory for Congress,<ref>Miller, Alan C., "Gallegly Bets on Force of Incumbency", ''Los Angeles Times'', June 6, 1988.</ref> but failed to push State Sen. [[Edward M. Davis|Ed Davis]] to victory in the California U.S. Senate primary.<ref>Love, Keith & Balzar, John, ''Los Angeles Times'', September 8, 1985, "Fear of Cranston, Unrest Clouding GOP Convention"</ref>
In 1985–87, Finkelstein was part of the team advising former U.N. Ambassador [[Jeane Kirkpatrick]] for a possible campaign for the Presidency.<ref>Sneed, Michael et al, Inc Hears That (column), ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', May 1, 1985, p. 12</ref><ref>Edsall, Thomas B., "Kirkpatrick Indicates Interest in White House; Kemp May Suffer if Ex-Envoy Runs", ''The Washington Post'', October 17, 1987.</ref> Kirkpatrick ultimately declined to run.
The Florida Senate contest of 1988 — closest in the country that year — was among Finkelstein's signature efforts.<ref>''St. Petersburg Times'', November 8, 1987, "Mack brings in some big guns"</ref> Congressman [[Connie Mack III]] won a tougher-than-expected primary, but his campaign did not wait for the results of the early-October Democratic runoff.<ref>Blanton, Donna, ''Orlando Sentinel'', November 9, 1988, "MacKay, Mack Cliffhanger Down to Absentees"</ref> Finkelstein determined (correctly) that Congressman [[Buddy MacKay]] would emerge from the bitter face-off, and began running TV and radio ads re-defining MacKay through his liberal voting record, with the tagline, "Hey Buddy, You're a Liberal."<ref>Allen, Kenneth S., ''St. Petersburg Times'', October 30, 1988, "Candidates turn up 'contrast' in TV ads"</ref> MacKay's primary and runoff campaign had focused on ethics<ref>Zaldivar, R.A., Paul Anderson & Mark Silva, "Democrats Turn TV Into Senate Title Bout", ''Miami Herald'', September 21, 1988.</ref> — appropriate for defeating Democrat [[Bill Gunter]], but useless against Mack — and he failed to blunt the ideological attack. Still, the "Hey Buddy" ads were unpopular with the press, and 22 of 23 Florida daily newspapers endorsed MacKay.<ref>Barnes, Robert, "Democrat Battles Tide in Florida", ''The Washington Post'', November 5, 1988.</ref>
Mack continued to press the liberal vs. conservative contrast in debates and ads,<ref>Dahl, David, ''St. Petersburg Times'', October 31, 1988, "MacKay labors as Mack glides"</ref> closing with endorsements by the highly popular [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[George H.W. Bush]], plus footage of MacKay endorsing various tax increases. A slight majority of voters casting ballots on Election Day backed MacKay,<ref>Kleindienst, Linda, "Local Absentee Votes May Decide Governor's Race", ''South Florida Sun-Sentinel'', November 2, 1990.</ref> but an aggressive GOP absentee-voter program<ref>"Mack May Owe Victory to Party's Absentee-Voter Drive", ''Orlando Sentinel'', November 12, 1988.</ref> had already banked a margin of tens of thousands of votes,<ref>Babcock, Charles R., "Being There Unnecessary for Republican Victories - GOP Credited in Rounding Up Absentee Voters", ''The Washington Post'', November 25, 1988.</ref> and Mack was elected senator by a total of 34,512 votes out of 4 million cast.<ref>Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 18 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 1988'' (CQ Press, 1989)</ref>
Finkelstein also advised [[Joe Malone (politician)|Joe Malone]] in his campaign against Massachusetts Sen. [[Edward Kennedy]];<ref>United Press International, September 1, 1988, "Dukakis shown hurting in home state"</ref> Malone lost with 34%, but gained enough positive recognition that, in 1990, he was elected Treasurer in the overwhelmingly Democratic state. Another client, [[Joseph DioGuardi]], lost his congressional re-election contest in New York, 47.5% to 50.3%, to [[Nita Lowey]].<ref>Feron, James, ''The New York Times'', October 23, 1988, "A Quickening Congressional Race"</ref> But, in another tight contest decided by absentee voters, [[Denny Smith]] won re-election to Congress in Oregon.<ref>''The Washington Post'', November 12, 1988, "Rep. Denny Smith Wins a Squeaker"</ref>
==Focus on New York, 1989–94== Brooklyn native Finkelstein had long advised local and state party organizations in New York (e.g., the powerful GOP committees of [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]],<ref>Lynn, Frank, "Suburbs' Power Mirrored in Tally of G.O.P. Victories", ''The New York Times'', November 9, 1980.</ref> [[Nassau County, New York|Nassau]]<ref>Lynn, Frank, "D'Amato Victory Increases Stature of Island in G.O.P.", ''The New York Times'', September 14, 1980.</ref> and [[Suffolk]] Counties,<ref>Lynn, Frank, "Shoreham Issue Splits Party Ranks in Suffolk", ''The New York Times'', October 16, 1983.</ref> then dominant in all three suburban areas).
In 1989, he dove into the contentious world of New York City politics. [[Rudolph Giuliani]]'s initial candidacy for Mayor was met with a primary challenge by cosmetics billionaire [[Ronald Lauder]], backed by Sen. D'Amato and guided by Finkelstein.<ref>Duggan, Dennis, ''Newsday'', January 31, 1989, "'Resources' to Be Competitive"</ref> The Giuliani-D'Amato feud had begun in 1988 over the selection of Rudy's successor as [[U.S. Attorney]] for the [[Southern District of New York]];<ref>Lynn, Frank, "G.O.P. Battling Over Giuliani's Future", ''The New York Times'', January 13, 1988.</ref> it colored Republican politics in the Empire State for the next several years. In this first skirmish, Lauder's millions of dollars' worth of hard-hitting advertising failed to prevent Giuliani's winning the GOP nomination. (Giuliani later blamed Lauder's primary ads for his narrow loss to [[David Dinkins]] that November.)<ref>Borsellino, Robert, "Giuliani Won't Run for Governor, Hints At Challenging D'Amato", ''Albany Times Union'', March 16, 1990.</ref>
A year later, in the disastrous 1990 gubernatorial election, GOP nominee [[Pierre Rinfret]] nearly finished in third place (behind [[Conservative Party of New York State]] upstart [[Herbert London]]). D'Amato, and by extension Finkelstein, assumed dominance over the moribund state party apparatus. Long-time [[Rensselaer County]] activist [[William Powers (politician)|William Powers]], a staunch D'Amato ally, was named chairman, and began the rebuilding process.<ref>Borsellino, Robert, "Powers Elected to Lead Battered GOP", ''Albany Times Union'', January 15, 1991.</ref> (D'Amato allies had started their own state PAC in 1989, the Committee for New York, in order to aid Republicans independent of the decaying party team.<ref>"GOP PAC Supported D'Amato's Cause; State Contributions Skirt Federal Limits", ''Newsday'', May 24, 1990.</ref>)
At this time, the Reaganite Finkelstein was not a fan of the current Administration of [[George H.W. Bush]]. In a rare public appearance in February 1991, after the GOP's poor national showing in the November 1990 elections, he reminded a conservative audience that Reagan prospered through unabashed ideological appeals that drew crossover votes from sympathetic Democrats. But Bush and other GOP candidates "kicked that away" in 1990 by raising taxes, sidestepping abortion and other social issues, and soft-pedaling their anti-communism while rooting for [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] to succeed. "We are going to have to go back to the things that got us here," Finkelstein said.<ref>Harwood, John, "National Conservatives Concerned About Movement's Future", ''St. Petersburg Times'', February 8, 1991.</ref>
Meanwhile, D'Amato faced mounting ethical problems, and these occupied much of Finkelstein's time in 1990 and 1991. Though the New York senator was ultimately cleared by the [[Senate Ethics Committee]] in 1991,<ref>Turner, Douglas, "Ethics Panel Absolves D'Amato; Ruling Chides Senator for Allowing Misuse of Office", ''Buffalo News'', August 3, 1991.</ref> he was the subject of ceaseless negative news stories and editorials.
When CBS's ''[[60 Minutes]]'' ran a highly damaging story on D'Amato, Finkelstein produced a response program that refuted many of its charges and misstatements.<ref>Schanberg, Sydney, "Chutzpah Stars on the Senator Al Show", ''Newsday'', May 31, 1991.</ref> All the while, D'Amato's aggressive casework program and advocacy for New York interests was emphasized in paid and earned media.<ref name="Purdum">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/04/nyregion/1994-campaign-strategists-2-wizards-smoke-mirror-trade-guiding-cuomo-pataki.html|work=The New York Times|title=THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE STRATEGISTS; The 2 Wizards of the Smoke-and-Mirror Trade Guiding Cuomo and Pataki|first=Todd S.|last=Purdum|date=November 4, 1994|accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref> Nevertheless, going into his 1992 re-election campaign, D'Amato was shown in surveys to be a near-certain loser to most prospective challengers. The indictment of his brother, [[Armand D'Amato]], on two dozen counts of [[mail fraud]] in March 1992 darkened the clouds further.<ref>Goldberg, Nicholas and Alan Eysen, "Consensus: A Bad Blow To Senator's Campaign", ''Newsday'', March 12, 1992.</ref>
When the Democrats nominated Attorney General [[Robert Abrams]] in September, Finkelstein's polls showed D'Amato down 25 points, just seven weeks before the election.<ref>D'Amato, Alfonse M., ''Power, Pasta and Politics: The World According to Senator Al D'Amato'' (New York: Hyperion, 1995), p. 225<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref> With the huge lead enjoyed by Democratic presidential nominee [[Bill Clinton]] in New York, the Bush-Quayle ticket was a positive drag on D'Amato. As with the Mack-MacKay race in 1988, Finkelstein moved to define Abrams by his liberal positions on issues. Support for a single-payer national health scheme was translated into "a 6% tax on every job in America"—a contention never challenged.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iyJl4DDA1KQ|title=Al D'Amato Campaign Ad - 1992 - New York Senate Race|first=|last=Random Stuff I Find on VHS|date=January 16, 2011|accessdate=August 26, 2017|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> His backing for other tax increases was documented and publicized in TV and radio ads, with the tagline, "Bob Abrams: Hopelessly liberal".<ref name="samroberts"/>
The D'Amato campaign was no less bold on the ethics issue, repeating [[pay-for-play]] charges made by ex-Rep. [[Geraldine Ferraro]] during the Democratic primary, with ads featuring excerpts from the Abrams-Ferraro debate. When news stories late in the campaign revealed the nominee's disallowed business-tax deductions, Finkelstein's closing ad ran: "Bob Abrams never met a tax he didn't like ... except his own."<ref>D'Amato, Alfonse M., ''Power, Pasta and Politics: The World According to Senator Al D'Amato'' (New York: Hyperion, 1995), p. 229<!-- ISSN/ISBN neede --></ref> On Election Day 1992, as [[Bill Clinton]] was winning New York State by 16 points, D'Amato won re-election by 1.2 points, a margin of 80,794 votes — with a wave of Clinton-D'Amato split-ticket voting<ref>Halverson, Guy & Mouat, Lucia, "Campaign '92 Most Mid-Atlantic Incumbents Win", ''Christian Science Monitor'', November 6, 1992.</ref> in Brooklyn, Queens and Buffalo the deciding factor.
Finkelstein had several other results that day. In North Carolina, he helped the Ellis-Wrenn-Congressional Club team guide businessman and former Democrat [[Lauch Faircloth]] to victory over incumbent Sen. [[Terry Sanford]].<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017"/> [[Don Nickles]] easily won a third term as senator from Oklahoma. But in Illinois, the candidacy of [[Richard S. Williamson|Rich Williamson]] failed to defeat Democrat [[Carol Moseley Braun]] to replace Sen. [[Alan Dixon]].<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
D'Amato's comeback win had demonstrated the Republicans' window of opportunity in New York City's [[outer boroughs]], among working-class Catholics<ref>Keeler, Bob, ''Newsday'', November 5, 1992, "His Winning Ways on Ropes, D'Amato Found Fighting Legs"</ref> and (especially) Jewish voters angered by Democratic leaders' handling of the [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]] violence and subsequent incidents.<ref>Wasserman, Elizabeth, "U.S. Senate Second-Guessing Abrams' Effort", ''Newsday'', November 5, 1992.</ref>
The senator's ticket-splitting performance had the effect of shielding downticket candidates from the Bush debacle, and Republicans actually made Congressional gains in strong D'Amato areas — e.g., working-class Buffalo ([[John Quinn (New York politician)|Jack Quinn]]),<ref>McCarthy, Robert J., "Local Election Results Defy Definition, Experts Say Voters Reject Traditional Party Loyalty, Exercise Independent Thinking", ''Buffalo News'', November 8, 1992.</ref> and suburban Long Island ([[Rick Lazio]])<ref>Levy, Lawrence C., "L.I.'s Strong Message to the Republicans", ''Newsday'', November 5, 1992.</ref> — while holding the majority in the powerful State Senate, which strengthened the hand of D'Amato, Finkelstein and Powers going into 1993 and 1994.<ref>Carroll, Maurice, Newsday, December 31, 1993, "POLS & POLITICS Republicans Are Gunning For Guv Race"</ref>
Giuliani's second Mayoral campaign in 1993 benefited from the resurgent New York GOP. He had made a point of endorsing the Senator for re-election,<ref>Carroll, Maurice, "City Pols: What's In It For Me? Ponder Vote's Local Impact", ''Newsday'', November 5, 1992.</ref> and D'Amato and Finkelstein did not again back a primary challenger. This time, Giuliani ran a more effective race, riding to victory on a wave of discontent with incumbent [[David Dinkins]], with even stronger turnout among ethnic Catholics and Jewish voters than in 1989, and in the same areas where D'Amato had done well a year earlier.<ref>William Bunch, Michael H. Cottman and Mitch Gelman, "A Rudy Makeover Polish paved way to win", ''Newsday'', November 4, 1993.</ref>
In New York City in November 1993, Finkelstein and [[Ronald Lauder]] also guided to victory a measure limiting the terms of elected city officials.<ref name="stevenleemyers">Myers, Steven Lee, [https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/03/nyregion/new-yorkers-approve-limit-of-2-terms-for-city-officials.html "New Yorkers Approve Limit of 2 Terms for City Officials"], ''The New York Times'', November 3, 1993.</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' called this vote "a terrific defeat for the city's mostly Democratic political establishment, which had fought in court throughout the summer to kill the referendum, only to have the state's highest court order it on the ballot just two weeks [before the election]."<ref name="stevenleemyers"/>
Finkelstein had specialized in federal elections to this point, and it was uncertain how he would adapt to the localized issues and personal style of a gubernatorial contest. Reluctantly at first, and only after considering several alternative candidates, he and D'Amato settled on supporting little-known State Senator [[George Pataki]] of [[Peekskill]] for Governor in 1994.<ref name="Pataki, George 1998 pp. 69–72">Pataki, George, with Daniel Paisner, ''Pataki: An Autobiography'' (New York: Viking, 1998), pp. 69–72<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref> They guided him through the State Convention in May, and to a smashing 3-to-1 primary victory in September over [[Nelson Rockefeller]]'s longtime political wheelhorse Richard Rosenbaum.<ref>Humbert, Marc, "Cuomo, Pataki Win Primaries, Face Showdown", Associated Press, September 14, 1994.</ref>
The main challenge was defining the race against Cuomo. Finkelstein's first ad radiated disappointment and sowed seeds of disbelief: "Desperate candidates do desperate things ... [[Mario Cuomo]] could have been senator or President ..."<ref>AP story by Marc Humbert in ''Albany Times Union'', September 16, 1994, "Cuomo's Campaign Takes Both High Road and Low Road"</ref> Subsequent spots, often as brief as 10 seconds, highlighted Cuomo-era failures (e.g. snarled traffic and record-high utility rates in Long Island),<ref>Sack, Kevin, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/01/nyregion/1994-campaign-overview-cuomo-pataki-go-long-island-hunt-for-votes.html?pagewanted=all "THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE OVERVIEW; CUOMO AND PATAKI GO TO LONG ISLAND IN HUNT FOR VOTES"], ''The New York Times'', November 1, 1994.</ref><ref>Fisher, Ian, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/09/nyregion/the-1994-campaign-issues-clamor-over-death-penalty-dominates-debate-on-crime.html?pagewanted=all "THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: ISSUES; Clamor Over Death Penalty Dominates Debate on Crime"], ''The New York Times'', October 9, 1994.</ref> and especially the litany of tax increases over his 12 years. The persistent tagline: "Mario Cuomo: Too liberal for too long."<ref>Goldberg, Nicholas & John Riley, "Pataki: Cuomo 'Too Too' Challenger unveils ads attacking governor", ''Newsday'', September 15, 1994.</ref>
Pataki introduced himself in ads first as a gentle reformer, then angry in responding to Cuomo attacks, and finally enthusiastic (in excerpts from rally speeches at campaign's close). Cuomo defended his record and played up D'Amato's sponsorship of Pataki's campaign (to the tune of [[Paul Simon]]'s "[[You Can Call Me Al]]"), but had trouble overcoming the anti-incumbent tide.<ref name="Purdum"/> Pataki had a slight lead in public surveys when, on October 24, Giuliani endorsed Cuomo, with attacks on his fellow Republican quickly becoming a staple on evening news programs.<ref>Purdum, Todd, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/25/nyregion/1994-campaign-analysis-who-can-most-mayor-s-endorsement-cuomo-reflects-political.html "THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: NEWS ANALYSIS - Who Can Do the Most?; Mayor's Endorsement of Cuomo Reflects Political Interests and Financial Realities"], ''The New York Times'', October 25, 1994.</ref> Poll numbers fluctuated wildly, with Finkelstein's own tracking survey showing a Cuomo lead ballooning to 13 points within days.<ref>A ''The New York Times''/WCBS survey, completed 5 days after Giuliani's endorsement, showed Cuomo at 44%, Pataki at 34%.<br>See Moody, Nekesa Mumbi, Associated Press, October 30, 1994, "National Republicans Go After Mayor for Endorsing Democrat Governor".</ref> It required a swift response. He elected to attack Giuliani's endorsement as a corrupt deal with Cuomo,<ref>Purdum, Todd, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/02/nyregion/1994-campaign-ad-campaign-race-for-governor-pataki-says-cuomo-buying-election.html "THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN; Race for Governor: Pataki Says Cuomo Is Buying Election"], ''The New York Times'', November 2, 1994.</ref> the ad using headlines citing suspiciously timed New York State grants to the City to suggest the Governor had used taxpayer money to buy the Mayor's backing.<ref name="Pataki, George 1998 pp. 69–72"/> Pataki relentlessly pushed this argument in public appearances.<ref>Riley, John, ''Newsday'', October 29, 1994, "Pataki on New Offensive"</ref>
The pendulum swung back, with negative reaction to Giuliani especially strong Upstate and in the Metro North and Long Island suburbs.<ref>Jones, Charisse, [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/28/us/1994-campaign-campaign-upstate-pataki-s-new-message-giuliani-endorsement-has.html "THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE CAMPAIGN; Upstate, Pataki's New Message: Giuliani Endorsement Has Price"], ''The New York Times'', October 28, 1994.</ref> (GOP protestors even chased the Mayor's plane on an airport tarmac during a statewide flyaround for Cuomo.) Pataki closed the sale with an energetic tour of the state, appearing alone on a WCBS-TV Election Eve program when Cuomo refused a one-on-one debate.<ref>Pleven, Liam & John Riley, "Upstate key for Pataki", ''Newsday'', November 8, 1994.</ref> The final result: Pataki defeated Cuomo by 4 points. In an historic Republican landslide year, Mario Cuomo was the most prominent Democrat to fall. As [[Todd Purdum]] of ''The New York Times'' wrote that November, "For good or ill, Mr. Pataki's campaign [wa]s almost entirely a creation of Mr. Finkelstein."<ref name="Purdum"/>
Delaware provided another win for Finkelstein in November 1994, as longtime Senator [[Bill Roth (politician)|Bill Roth]] coasted to victory for his fifth term, 56% to 44%.<ref>Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 21 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 1994'' (CQ Press, 1995)</ref>
==NRSC, Netanyahu, and Being 'Outed,' 1995–96== Following Election Day 1994, D'Amato and Finkelstein were handed new challenges and opportunities, as the 14-year incumbent was named by his Senate peers as chairman of the [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] (NRSC), one of the four permanent GOP campaign operations in Washington. They had a tough act to follow — [[Phil Gramm]] of Texas had just piloted Republicans to a 7-seat gain and recaptured control of the Senate. For Finkelstein, it was his first bow as an inside player on a Washington campaign committee, his dealings previously being as representative of an individual candidate. Now he and D'Amato were responsible for helping to direct Senate campaigns in 33 states simultaneously.<ref>Shepard, Steven, [http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/19/gop-campaign-guru-arthur-finkelstein-dies-at-72-241826 "GOP campaign guru Arthur Finkelstein dies at 72"], Politico, August 19, 2017.</ref>
One of their first moves was to break the cycle of hiring parochial-minded Senate aides to manage the sprawling committee; their choice for Executive Director was [[John Heubusch]] (later a top executive with [[Gateway Computers]] and head of the [[Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation]]). Other key hires were [[Jo Anne B. Barnhart]] as Political Director, and [[Gordon Hensley]] as Communications Director.<ref>"Politics' Fabulous Fifty", ''Roll Call'', September 23, 1996, p. A24.</ref> (Barnhart was a long-time aide and campaigner for Sen. [[William V. Roth, Jr.|William Roth]], and later served as Commissioner of the [[Social Security Administration]].) All three were singled out by ''Roll Call'' newspaper in 1996 as among national "Politics' Fabulous Fifty."<ref>Cook, Charles E., "Political Surveyor" column, p. 5, ''Roll Call'', December 12, 1996.</ref>
The NRSC faced several challenges beyond their control, many emanating from the two dominant Republicans of 1995–96, House Speaker [[Newt Gingrich]] and Senate Majority Leader [[Bob Dole]]. The [[Oklahoma City bombing]] had given President [[Bill Clinton]] an opportunity to marginalize his opponents, and slowed the momentum of the reform-minded Republican Congress.<ref>Many sources, e.g. http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2010/04/remembering_oklahoma_city_and.html and https://archives.sfexaminer.com/sanfrancisco/flashback-how-clinton-exploited-oklahoma-city-for-political-gain/Content?oid=2167590</ref>
By late 1995, unrelenting Democratic/press attacks, and his own missteps, had turned Gingrich into a pariah through much of the country (2-to-1 unfav-fav ratio in surveys); meanwhile, Dole was running for President, and allowing ambition to overshadow his Senate work. In mid-1996, Dole resigned from the Senate to campaign full-time, but by then he was behind Clinton to stay, and eventually polled less than 41% nationwide.<ref name="Scammon, Richard 1997">Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 22 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 1996'' (CQ Press, 1997)</ref>
D'Amato remained personally devoted to Dole, but Finkelstein and the NRSC team urged Republican Senate candidates to cut loose from unpopular national leaders and carve their own individual profiles on issues.<ref>Rosenbaum, David, [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/27/us/gop-hopes-for-senate-ride-on-pollster-s-tactics.html "G.O.P. Hopes for Senate Ride on Pollster's Tactics"], ''The New York Times'', October 27, 1996.</ref> D'Amato remained a champion fundraiser and the committee found new legal ways to deliver assistance to Senate campaigns and local parties. The NRSC paid particular attention to blunting the wave of millionaire political unknowns (e.g., [[Tom Bruggere]] in Oregon, Elliott Close in South Carolina) recruited that year by the Democrats.<ref>Schantz, Harvey, [https://books.google.com/books?id=su-S6liKHx4C&pg=PT261&lpg=PT261&dq=bruggere+d%27amato+1996&source=bl&ots=3ipTXO02cf&sig=k6YYspmL0DRRCgBhxMtEx5IMOw8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjX1-mb1-TVAhUn94MKHS4nCXQQ6AEIVDAM#v=onepage&q=bruggere%20d'amato%201996&f=false ''Politics in an Era of Divided Government: The Election of 1996 and its Aftermath'', pp. 93-99]; accessed August 26, 2017.</ref> It shored up many endangered incumbents, including [[Robert C. Smith|Bob Smith]] (New Hampshire), [[John Warner]] (Virginia), 75-year-old Jesse Helms (North Carolina) and 94-year-old Strom Thurmond (South Carolina).<ref>Kurtz, Howard, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1996/10/22/gop-consultants-strategy-label-opponents-liberally/8ef6af9b-6fae-4ac0-878e-961befb62d2c/ "GOP CONSULTANT'S STRATEGY: LABEL OPPONENTS LIBERALLY"], ''The Washington Post'', October 22, 1996.</ref>
On Election Night, as Clinton defeated Dole by nearly 9 points and Gingrich's House Republicans lost a net 8 seats, Senate Republicans won open seats in Alabama, Arkansas and Nebraska, while losing South Dakota. In a poor GOP year, the D'Amato-Finkelstein NRSC had gained a net 2 seats (and narrowly missed another gain in the [[Max Cleland]] - [[Guy Millner]] race in Georgia).<ref>Shepard, Steven, [http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/19/gop-campaign-guru-arthur-finkelstein-dies-at-72-241826 "GOP campaign guru Arthur Finkelstein dies at 72"], Politico, August 19, 2017.</ref>
Finkelstein was not a consultant to the Dole Presidential campaign, despite his closeness to several of its top staffers. But, in the election's waning days, ''Time'' magazine reporter Erik Pooley detected the New Yorker's influence on strategy, writing:
<blockquote>For Arthur Finkelstein, this week might have been a vindication: Bob Dole finally started labeling Bill Clinton a "spend-and-tax liberal," using a crude but often effective strategy known as "Finkel-think" by some Dole advisers, because the secretive Republican strategist has been deploying it on behalf of his clients for 20 years ... These days, Finkelstein is exercising a kind of remote control. The Senator's latest brain trust is dominated by "Arthur's Boys" ... And Dole is rushing around the country chanting the Finkelstein mantra. "Liberal! Liberal! Liberal!" he cried in St. Louis, Missouri.<ref name="edition.cnn.com">Pooley, Erik, ''Time'', October 7, 1996, "The Mystery Man Who Inspired Dole's Latest Strategy," accessed thru http://edition.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/time/9610/07/pooley.shtml</ref></blockquote>
His own statewide clients in 1996 showed a mixed record, with Senator [[Larry Pressler]] (South Dakota) and ex-Senator [[Rudy Boschwitz]] (Minnesota) both losing, albeit in close races. [[Robert C. Smith|Bob Smith]] survived with a 49% plurality win. New Jersey Congressman [[Dick Zimmer (New Jersey politician)|Dick Zimmer]] was defeated in his Senate bid against [[Robert Torricelli]].''<ref>Orr, J. Scott, "Hired guns add fire to Senate race", ''Star-Ledger'', October 27, 1996.</ref>''
Earlier in 1996, he also helped [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] oust [[Shimon Peres]] as Prime Minister of Israel in a close upset.<ref name="cnn.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/news/9610/10/karl.finkelstein/index.shtml|work=CNN|title=Arthur Finkelstein: Out Of Sight But In Control|accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref> According to ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', "Finkelstein was largely responsible for the strategy that brought Netanyahu victory in the 1996 general elections."<ref>Shimon, Kamoun, It's Sad To Be the Mayor of Jerusalem, ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', November 10, 2008.</ref>
