According to the ''[[Times of Israel]]'', "Finkelstein was behind the "Peres will divide Jerusalem" slogan that helped Netanyahu overcome Shimon Peres who had been forecast to sweep to power in the wake of the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin the previous November. That election was credited with changing the tone of Israeli campaigns, bringing more American-style, aggressive and negative campaigning to Israel."<ref>[http://www.timesofisrael.com/arthur-finklestein-master-campaign-strategist-dies-at-72 "Arthur Finklestein, strategist who helped Netanyahu to power, dies at 72"], ''Times of Israel'', August 19, 2017.</ref> But his expertise helped in subtler ways as well; biographer Neill Lochery wrote in 2016 that Finkelstein was behind such ideas as dyeing Netanyahu's salt-and-pepper hair gray to give him a more statesmanlike appearance.<ref>Lochery, quoted by Fisher, Ben, in ''Jerusalem Post Online'', November 24, 2016, "Books: Unstoppable Bibi"</ref>
Jeff Barak of the ''Jerusalem Post'', a harsh critic of Finkelstein and Netanyahu, called the strategist "the brains behind Netanyahu's first election victory in 1996. Netanyahu's campaign back then, from which he has never wavered, was that you're either for him or an enemy of the people. His campaign slogan at the time, 'Netanyahu is good for the Jews,' encapsulated this. By implication, if you're not for Netanyahu then you're not good for the Jews, and therefore an enemy. And if Netanyahu is good for the Jews, then this also not-so-subtly hints that Netanyahu's bad for the Arabs, regardless of the fact that they are supposedly citizens of equal standing who comprise around 20% of the country's population."<ref>Barak, Jeff, ''Jerusalem Post'', May 8, 2017, "Reality Check: Which US Jew has really influenced today's Israel?"</ref>
But Finkelstein's greatest personal challenge that year came with the August issue of ''[[Boston magazine]]'', which revealed his private life as a homosexual;<ref>Finnegan, Michael, [http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/gop-guru-gay-sez-mag-article-1.743078 "GOP GURU GAY, SEZ MAG"], ''New York Daily News'', September 13, 1996.</ref> the ostensible excuse for the outing was that several Finkelstein clients had voted against gay-rights measures in Congress, and his work to elect them was therefore inconsistent and/or hypocritical. In September, D'Amato said, "I don't think a person's sexual orientation, his private life — a person's private life should be brought up and I think the question is offensive, it's wrong. He's a wonderful, decent person and whatever his sexual orientation is, that's his business."<ref name="cnn.com"/>
==Back to the Empire State, 1997–98== Finkelstein's next two years anchored him again in New York, for the simultaneous re-election campaigns of Senator D'Amato and Governor Pataki in 1998. The contests were as different as the candidates themselves, with the calm, earnest Pataki winning high approval ratings and discouraging stronger Democrats from challenging him. New Yorkers' approval of Republican executives was signaled with the landslide re-election of Giuliani as Mayor in November 1997.<ref>Firestone, David, [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/06/nyregion/the-1997-elections-the-voters-big-victory-but-gains-for-mayor-are-modest.html "THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS; Big Victory, but Gains For Mayor Are Modest"], ''The New York Times'', November 6, 1997.</ref>
Finkelstein crafted a highly positive campaign for Pataki, focusing on fulfillment of promises from 1994 (e.g., tax cuts) and policy innovations (the STAR tax program for seniors<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/.../your-home-homeowner-tax-cuts-in-new-york.html "Homeowner Tax Cuts in New York"], ''The New York Times'', December 14, 1997.</ref>) Raising $21 million, Pataki defeated New York City Council President [[Peter Vallone Sr.|Peter Vallone]] by 21 percentage points, polling 54.3%, the largest share by a Republican for Governor since [[Nelson Rockefeller]] in 1958.<ref>Perez-Pena, Richard, [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/04/nyregion/1998-elections-new-york-state-governor-pataki-wins-election-second-term-hefty.html "THE 1998 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- THE GOVERNOR; Pataki Wins Election to a Second Term by a Hefty Margin"], ''The New York Times'', November 4, 1998.</ref>
D'Amato was another matter; since his narrow victory in 1992, his profile had grown more partisan Republican in this still-heavily Democratic state. Summoning First Lady [[Hillary Clinton]] to testify before his Senate committee in 1995,<ref>Weiss, Philip, [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/news/the-senator-cannot-help-being-himself.html "The Senator Cannot Help Being Himself"], ''The New York Times'', March 3, 1996.</ref> and aggressive campaigning for Dole in 1996,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/07/nyregion/d-amato-to-support-dole-in-96.html "D'Amato to Support Dole in '96"], ''The New York Times'', March 7, 1996.</ref> damaged D'Amato in a state where [[Bill Clinton]] crushed the Kansan by nearly 2-to-1 (59.5% to 30.6%), doubling his 1992 margin over Bush.<ref name="Scammon, Richard 1997"/>
D'Amato's decision to divorce his wife after a long separation<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/08/nyregion/d-amato-and-wife-granted-a-divorce.html "D'Amato and Wife Granted a Divorce"], ''The New York Times'', April 8, 1995.</ref> and announce his engagement to a young socialite<ref>Barron, James, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/22/nyregion/d-amato-says-he-s-in-love-he-must-be-she-s-a-democrat.html "D'Amato Says He's in Love. He Must Be: She's a Democrat"], ''The New York Times'', February 22, 1995.</ref> did not help his favorable ratings, while others recalled his mock-Japanese impression of [[O.J. Simpson]] case Judge [[Lance Ito]] in 1995 (for which he was forced to apologize on the Senate floor).<ref>Henneberger, Melinda, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/07/nyregion/d-amato-gives-a-new-apology-on-ito-remarks.html "D'Amato Gives A New Apology On Ito Remarks"], ''The New York Times'', April 7, 1995.</ref>
D'Amato raised a record $26 million for the 1998 campaign, and Finkelstein went to work early shoring up his client's "Senator Pothole" image of close attention to local needs and the problems of individual New Yorkers (as he had done successfully in 1992).<ref>Stanley, Alessandra, [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/19/nyregion/senator-pothole-s-ultimate-race-al-d-amato-runs-big-guy-for-all-those-little.html?pagewanted=all "Senator Pothole's Ultimate Race; Al D'Amato Runs as the Big Guy for All Those Little Guys"], ''The New York Times'', October 19, 1992.</ref> State polls showed a swing back to such issues as health care and social concerns, which needed to be addressed. The tagline of these ads: "Al D'Amato Cares, Al D'Amato Makes a Difference, Al D'Amato Gets Things Done."<ref>Berkowitz, Harry, "Riding the Airwaves, D'Amato Hones Image", ''Newsday'', August 28, 1998.</ref>
The Democratic primary was ultimately between Queens politician [[Geraldine Ferraro]] and U.S. Representative [[Charles Schumer]] of Brooklyn. Finkelstein prepared for both eventualities. When Schumer won by a surprisingly large margin, he immediately began ads that raised questions about the candidate's work ethic. (As Congressman, Schumer had missed an inordinate number of committee meetings.)<ref>Siegel, Joel. "Attending to Issues: Al Scolds Chuck For Votes He Missed in House", ''New York Daily News'', October 22, 1998.</ref> The unexpected line of attack stymied the Democrat in late September and early October, and despite his weaknesses D'Amato gamely held onto a lead.<ref name="Albany Times-Union' 1998">''Albany Times-Union'' poll, cited in ''New York Post'', October 24, 1998, "PUTZ' CHUCK ; SAYS AL LIED ABOUT IT ; D'AMATO GIVES BRUSHOFF: "IT FITS' by ROBERT HARDT Jr. & GREGG BIRNBAUM</ref>
All this collapsed in late October, after a remarkable show of hubris and bad judgment at a closed-door meeting with Jewish supporters in Brooklyn.<ref name="Albany Times-Union' 1998"/> First, D'Amato did a waddling impression of then-obese Democratic U.S. Rep. [[Jerrold Nadler]].<ref>Halbfinger, David, [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/23/nyregion/the-1998-campaign-the-senate-d-amato-says-he-s-sorry-but-not-to-schumer.html "THE 1998 CAMPAIGN -- THE SENATE; D'Amato Says He's Sorry, but Not to Schumer"], ''The New York Times'', October 23, 1998.</ref> Later in the meeting, he referred to Schumer as a "putzhead" (a mangling of the [[Yiddish]] vulgarism "[[wikt:putz|putz]]"). He later denied using this characterization, during questions from reporters (but was swiftly contradicted by his own supporters, present at the meeting, including [[Ed Koch]]).<ref>[[Adam Nagourney|Nagourney, Adam]], [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/nyregion/1998-campaign-senate-schumer-fires-counterattack-d-amato-holocaust.html "THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE SENATE; Schumer Fires Counterattack at D'Amato on the Holocaust"], ''The New York Times'', October 22, 1998.</ref> Film of the denial was turned into a Schumer TV ad within days.<ref>Harden, Blaine, "The Gaffe Heard 'Round N.Y.; D'Amato Campaign Slowed By His Insult of Schumer", ''The Washington Post'', October 28, 1998.</ref>
Finkelstein's tracking survey the night of D'Amato's "putzhead" comment showed the senator leading Schumer by 10 points with two weeks to go. But the meltdown was quick and decisive, especially among Jewish voters,<ref>Birnbaum, Gregg & Robert Hardt, Jr., ''New York Post'', November 4, 1998, "Too Many Flubs Doomed D'Amato"</ref> with Schumer's ads relentlessly driving the message of D'Amato's dishonesty and dislikeability. The Democrat's closing tagline was itself a homage to Finkelstein: "D'Amato: Too many lies for too long." Schumer won, 54.6% to 44.1%—a 20-point turnaround.<ref>Brand, Rick, Newsday, November 4, 1998, "ELECTION '98 / Schumer Topples Senator D'Amato / 'The battle is over,' incumbent concedes"</ref>
In other races that year, Sen. [[Lauch Faircloth]]—who had earlier replaced Finkelstein for his 1998 reelection campaign in North Carolina — brought him back into the fold in the closing weeks of the race. (Faircloth ultimately lost a close contest to Democrat [[John Edwards]].)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/19/gop-campaign-guru-arthur-finkelstein-dies-at-72-241826|title=GOP campaign guru Arthur Finkelstein dies at 72|website=Politico.com|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
==Later clients and campaigns, 1999–2017== ===International=== In the 2000s, Finkelstein spent more time working overseas than in previous decades, with clients in [[Albania]], [[Austria]], [[Bulgaria]], the [[Czech Republic]], [[Hungary]], [[Kosovo]], [[Ukraine]] and [[Azerbijan]] (the last, in coordination with [[George Birnbaum]].<ref>''Azerbaijan News Gazette'', October 4, 2016, "EU Reporter: Polls show occupied region is main concern in Azerbaijan"</ref>) He continued to consult in Israeli elections, working again for [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] in 1999, [[Ariel Sharon]] (whom he helped become Prime Minister in 2001<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/arthur-finkelstein-shadowy-campaign-mastermind-and-gop-operative-dies-at-72/2017/08/19/0bd638c6-84e8-11e7-902a-2a9f2d808496_story.html|title=Arthur Finkelstein, quietly influential GOP campaign mastermind, dies at 72|website=Washington Post|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>), and finally [[Avigdor Lieberman]] and his [[Yisrael Beytenu]] party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/arthur-finklestein-master-campaign-strategist-dies-at-72/|title=Arthur Finkelstein, strategist who helped Netanyahu to power, dies at 72|website=Timesofisrael.com|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
===Florida=== Having twice steered [[Connie Mack III]] to Senate victories in 1988 and 1994, Finkelstein was in demand for the 2000 Florida contest upon Mack's retirement. His candidate was 10-term Congressman [[Bill McCollum]], and he helped clear the Republican field early in anticipation of a tough general election against Insurance Commissioner [[Bill Nelson (politician)|Bill Nelson]].<ref>Bousquet, Steve, ''Miami Herald'', November 1, 2000, "MCCOLLUM USES `L-WORD,' CALLS NELSON A LIBERAL"</ref> It was a nail-biter with many echoes of the 1988 Senate campaign, but with a different outcome. As enthusiasm among Republican voters faltered in the final days (after revelations of [[George W. Bush]]'s 1976 DUI conviction), GOP coattails and McCollum's slim lead disappeared, and Nelson was elected, 51% to 46%.<ref name="Scammon, Richard 2001">Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 24 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 2000'' (CQ Press, 2001)</ref>
McCollum ran for the other Florida Senate seat on Democrat [[Bob Graham]]'s retirement in 2004, but succumbed to eventual Senator [[Mel Martinez]] after low fundraising allowed the challenger to overcome his early lead.<ref>Caputo, Marc, ''Miami Herald'', July 25, 2004,"IN U.S. SENATE RACE, ADS GO LONG WAY, BUT TIME IS SHORT"</ref> But McCollum was more successful in 2006, when he was the consensus GOP choice for Attorney General, and defeated Democrat [[Skip Campbell]], 52.7% to 47.3%, polling well in a poor year for Republicans.<ref>''St. Petersburg Times'', January 28, 2009, "THE BUZZ: FLORIDA POLITICS"</ref>
In 2009 and 2010, Finkelstein helmed McCollum's campaign for Florida Governor, where he was the favorite of the state's GOP Establishment.<ref>''St. Petersburg Times'', May 12, 2010, "THE BUZZ: FLORIDA POLITICS"</ref> These plans were upended by the surprise candidacy of wealthy businessman [[Rick Scott]], whose bottomless spending that year ($75 million from his personal coffers) led to a furious contest for the nomination. McCollum fought gamely, but lost the bid to Scott, 43.5% to 46.3%, who went on to win election to the Statehouse that November against Democrat [[Alex Sink]].<ref>Cook, Rhodes, ''America Votes 29 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 2010'' (CQ Press, 2011)</ref>
A 2004 open seat in Florida's 14th Congressional District allowed Finkelstein to help create a political dynasty, as he steered State Rep. [[Connie Mack IV]] to a narrow victory in a four-way primary, then general-election wins in 2004, 2006, 2008 and 2010.<ref>''News-Press, The'' (Fort Myers, FL), July 17, 2008, "Mack prevails in fundraising"</ref>
Finkelstein served as strategist for Mack's Senate campaign in 2012;<ref>Leary, Alex, ''Tampa Bay Times'', July 12, 2012, "NATIONAL SUPER PACS AIM BLITZ AT NELSON "</ref> a late entrant in the primary, the Congressman won the GOP nomination with 58%, but was defeated by incumbent [[Bill Nelson]] by a million votes in the Obama re-election year.<ref>Cook, Rhodes, ''America Votes 30 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 2012'' (Sage Press, 2013)</ref> (Mack IV later became a lobbyist, whose clients included the government of Hungary, whose leader [[Viktor Orbán]] was a leading Finkelstein client in the 2010s.)<ref>Novak, Benjamin, ''Budapest Beacon'', December 13, 2016, "Connie Mack IV says blue skies and sunshine in store for US-Hungary relations," Accessed thru https://budapestbeacon.com/connie-mack-iv-says-blue-skies-sunshine-store-us-hungary-relations/</ref>
===New York=== Pataki's third gubernatorial campaign, in 2002, provided some fresh challenges to Finkelstein, including a contest for the [[Conservative Party of New York State]] nomination, a still-shrinking Republican base, and a strong third-party challenge from millionaire [[B. Thomas Golisano]], running again on the [[Independence Party of New York|Independence Party]] line.<ref name="Dicker, Frederic U. 2002">Dicker, Frederic U., ''New York Post'', November 6, 2002, "WINNERS AND LOSERS"</ref> Finkelstein positioned Pataki as an economic conservative but far more moderate on social and spending issues than in previous campaigns. This shift won the endorsement of influential union leaders such as [[Dennis Rivera]] and [[Randi Weingarten]].<ref>Rau, Jordan, ''Newsday'', October 11, 2002, "Hardball-Playing Pataki Hits All Bases"</ref> Pataki enjoyed a 15-point victory, polling 48.3% to 32.7% for state Comptroller [[H. Carl McCall]], and 14% for Golisano.<ref>Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 25 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 2002'' (CQ Press, 2003)</ref>
Finkelstein tried to make use of Pataki's likely coattails by helming the campaign of David Cornstein for the state Comptroller slot being vacated by McCall. Cornstein, a successful businessman and Giuliani's appointed chief of [[Off-Track Betting]], brought personal resources and a strong finance team to the table.<ref>Jones, Thai, ''Newsday'', June 6, 2001, "State Comptroller Race Grows"</ref> He was a longtime ally of both the Mayor and Governor, with a City/Long Island base and unusual appeal as a Jewish Republican running as a moderate-conservative.<ref>Humbert, Marc, AP story in ''Albany Times Union'', August 5, 2001, "SPENDING IS ALREADY REVVING UP FOR 2002"</ref> But party regulars instead fell in decisively behind former Upstate Assemblyman [[John Faso]], a onetime legislative leader for the GOP minority, and Cornstein abandoned his run in 2001. (Faso further failed to expand his appeal beyond the limited Republican base, losing with 46.5% in November 2002; in his subsequent 2006 bid for Governor of New York, [[Eliot Spitzer]] crushed him, Faso polling just 29.2%.)<ref>Scammon, Richard ''et al'', ''America Votes 27 : a handbook of contemporary American election statistics, 2006'' (CQ Press, 2007)</ref>
Back in New York, Finkelstein in April 2005, Finkelstein announced the organization of [[Stop Her Now]], a [[527 committee]] dedicated to defeating then-Senator [[Hillary Clinton]] in the [[New York United States Senate election, 2006|2006 New York U.S. Senate race]]. Clinton sailed to an easy re-election, and the PAC was not a factor in the contest.<ref>Weigel, David, "It takes an agenda: conservatives cannot live by Hillary-hate alone", ''[[The American Conservative]]'', October 22, 2007.</ref>
In the titanic struggle over new stadium construction on Manhattan's [[West Side (Manhattan)|West Side]], Finkelstein was hired to defeat the proposal by [[Cablevision]], [[Madison Square Garden Company|MSG]] and its allies;<ref>Janison, Dan, Newsday, May 23, 2005, "CITY HALL: Stadium a bonanza for insiders"</ref> they ultimately prevailed, and the [[new Yankee Stadium]] was instead built in the Bronx, next to the old ballfield site, opening in 2009. It was the only time that the Finkelstein firm filed disclosure forms as a lobbyist (the filer was Ronald Finkelstein, not Arthur).<ref>New York City lobbying filings, Calendar Year 2005.</ref>
Finkelstein advised former Congressman [[Rick Lazio]] during his campaign for the 2010 Republican nomination for New York Governor.:<ref>''Press & Sun-Bulletin'' (Binghamton, NY), July 25, 2010, "Money crucial in governor's race"</ref> Lazio lost the GOP nomination contest to businessman [[Carl Paladino]].
===North Carolina=== Finkelstein continued to partner with Carter Wrenn on Tar Heel State races after the demise of the National Congressional Club.<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017"/> In 2000, former Charlotte mayor (and UNC basketball star) [[Richard Vinroot]] sought the Governorship, to succeed the term-limited Democrat [[Jim Hunt]]. Vinroot won a contested fight for the GOP nomination,<ref>Squitieri, Tom & Welch, William M., ''USA Today'', May 1, 2000, "Primary voters to set up key state races this week"</ref> but the drop in Republican-voter enthusiasm in the closing days (noted above in Florida) hurt here as well, and Vinroot was defeated by [[Mike Easley]], 44.2% to 52.4%.<ref name="Scammon, Richard 2001"/>
In one of Finkelstein's last major races before his death, he worked with Wrenn in 2016 to win a spirited primary fight between two sitting Congressmen -- [[George Holding]] and [[Renee Ellmers]]. Wrenn had helped Ellmers pull one of the shocking House upsets of the 2010 election, but she abandoned the veteran consultant after her swearing-in and allied herself closely with House GOP leaders. In this primary, Wrenn backed Holding (a former US Attorney he'd guided to victory in 2012 and 2014), after a court-ordered redistricting combined the constituencies of the two suburban-Raleigh members. Aided by Wrenn's management and Finkelstein's polling and advice,<ref name="Christensen, Rob 2017"/> Holding crushed Ellmers, 53.4% to 23.6%, and went on to a 56% re-election in November against Democrat John P. McNeil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/election/article112593858.html|title='Odd duck' Democrat seeks to unseat congressman in GOP-leaning 2nd District|website=newsonserver.com|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/John_McNeil_(North_Carolina)|title=John McNeil (North Carolina) |website=Ballotpedia.org|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
===Other States and Presidential=== In Delaware, Finkelstein continued as pollster in 2000 to Senator [[Bill Roth (politician)|Bill Roth]], but the 30-year lawmaker fell to a 56%-44% defeat that November to [[Thomas Carper]].<ref>''Campaigns & Elections'', May 2000 (Vol 21; Issue 4), "2000 Senatorial Races: Campaign Consultant Roundup"</ref>
Texas businessman [[David Dewhurst]] first approached Finkelstein in 1993 about running for Governor; he advised Dewhurst against challenging [[George W. Bush]], who stormed to victory a year later. In 1998, he shepherded the millionaire to victory for the post of state Land Commissioner,<ref>Kuempel, George, ''Dallas Morning News'', November 4, 1998, "GOP's Dewhurst wins land commissioner race: Businessman defeats state Rep. Raymond"</ref> then to two successive wins in 2002 and 2006 for the job of Lieutenant Governor.<ref>Hoppe, Christy, ''Dallas Morning News'', May 16, 2002, "GOP practicing the 'liberal' arts: Republicans paste tag on Democrats who prefer middle of road"</ref> In 2012, Finkelstein worked against Dewhurst in the U.S. Senate primary, polling for the campaign of former ESPN broadcaster [[Craig James (American football)|Craig James]].<ref>Gromer Jeffers Jr., ''Dallas Morning News'', March 15, 2012, "Texas GOP candidates for U.S. Senate prepare for Thursday debate"</ref>
Finkelstein also served as pollster for the 2004 primary challenge by conservative Pennsylvania Congressman [[Pat Toomey]] against moderate incumbent Sen. [[Arlen Specter]],<ref name="Roll Call 2010">''Roll Call'', April 29, 2010, "Wealthy Businessman Hires Media Recluse"</ref> pairing with strategist Jon Lerner.<ref name="Hagstrom, Jerry 2010">Hagstrom, Jerry, ''National Journal'', November 4, 2010, "The GOP's Smiling Consultants"</ref> Specter averted defeat narrowly only after massive assistance from the NRSC and Bush White House (and then switched parties after the 2008 election); Toomey was elected to Specter's seat in 2010 and 2016.
In 2005, Finkelstein polled for the gubernatorial campaign of [[Doug Forrester]] in New Jersey; he was defeated by [[Jon Corzine]].<ref>Murphy, Dan, ''Star-Ledger'', September 6, 2005, "NEW JERSEY -- GAME ON, GLOVES OFF"</ref>
[[Connie Mack IV]]'s 2007 marriage to Congresswoman [[Mary Bono]] led to Finkelstein's aiding her sharply contested (but successful) California campaign in November 2008, defeating Democrat Julie Bornstein in Obama's triumphant year.<ref name="Roll Call 2010"/> Bono finally lost in 2012, after her [[Riverside County]] seat was redistricted, falling to [[Raul Ruiz (politician)|Raul Ruiz]].<ref>''Desert Sun'', September 23, 2012, "Political Insider: Poll: Ruiz closing in on Bono Mack"</ref>
Finkelstein returned to New Hampshire in 2009-10, taking on the insurgent campaign of [[Bill Binnie]] for the GOP Senate nomination.<ref name="Roll Call 2010"/> Binnie was defeated by former Attorney General [[Kelly Ayotte]], who went on to election that November.
In May 2011, Finkelstein told an audience in Prague that three presidential candidates had asked him to serve as pollster on their campaign for the 2012 Republican nomination, and he had turned all three down. (He further noted that [[Ron Paul]] was not one of those three.)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IfCBpCBOECU|title=CEVRO Institut Forum / Arthur Finkelstein / English|first=|last=CEVROInstitut|date=April 8, 2012|accessdate=August 26, 2017|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>
== Campaign style and reviews == Finkelstein was known for his hard-edged political campaigns, which often focused on a single message with great repetition. He is credited with helping to make "[[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]]" a dirty word in the United States during the late 1980s and 1990s through the use of commercial messages such as this, intended to damage the image of [[Jack Reed (politician)|Jack Reed]]:
{{quote|That's liberal. That's Jack Reed. That's wrong. Call liberal Jack Reed and tell him his record on welfare is just too liberal for you.<ref name="karl">{{cite news | first=Jonathan | last=Karl | url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/news/9610/10/karl.finkelstein/index.shtml | title=Arthur Finkelstein: Out Of Sight But In Control | work=Inside Politics | publisher=CNN | date=October 10, 1996 | accessdate=July 2, 2005}}</ref>}}
While often successful (as with NCPAC's attacks on seemingly moderate Democrats, or the D'Amato and Pataki campaigns in New York), Finkelstein's tactics sometimes backfired – in 1996, his repeated attacks against [[Minnesota]] U.S. Senator [[Paul Wellstone]] (calling him "Embarrassingly liberal. Decades out of touch."<ref name="dionne">{{cite news | first=E.J., Jr. | last=Dionne | url=http://www.wpyellowpages.com/wp-srv/politics/talk/zforum/wellstone/wellstone011997.htm | title=Radical Realist | work=The Washington Post | page=W08 | date=January 19, 1997 | accessdate=May 1, 2009}}</ref>) may have helped galvanize Wellstone's liberal grass-roots base. Republican Sen. [[Rod Grams]] eventually condemned Finkelstein's negative ads against Wellstone as excessive; however, his client (former Sen. [[Rudy Boschwitz]]) came closer that year than any GOP challenger to defeating a Democratic incumbent.<ref>[[United States Senate elections, 1996]]</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=May 2017}}
Finkelstein refused the notion he engaged in negative campaigning, a phrase he said connotes false accusations: "It just means that you speak about the failings of your opponent as opposed to the virtues of your candidate"—a strategy he called "rejectionist voting"—a formula based on slogans that disparaged adversaries.<ref name="samroberts"/>
[[Time magazine]] in October 1996 reported the Liberal-branding strategy was dubbed "Finkel-think" by leading [[Bob Dole]] advisers, and the presidential nominee was (belatedly) employing it against President [[Bill Clinton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/time/9610/07/pooley.shtml|title=AllPolitics - TIME This Week: Oct. 07, 1996|website=Cnn.com|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
Political scientist Darrell M. West, in 1996 said ". . .He uses a sledgehammer in every race ... I've detected five phrases he uses — ultraliberal, superliberal, embarrassingly liberal, foolishly liberal and unbelievably liberal."<ref name="auto"/>
Philip Friedman, a Manhattan consultant who got his start working for Finkelstein's frequent Democratic rival [[David Garth]], described the pollster as "the ultimate sort of [[Dr. Strangelove]], who believes you can largely disregard what the politicians are going to say and do, what the newspapers are going to do, and create a simple and clear and often negative message, which, repeated often enough, can bring you to victory".<ref name="Purdum"/>
Republican strategist [[Roger Ailes]], who worked with Finkelstein on numerous races in the 1980s, described "Art" as "a polling guy with creative talents",<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
John Fossel, chairman of Oppenheimer Funds, characterized him as "basically sort of a mad scientist". Finkelstein polled in Fossel's unsuccessful Republican Congressional campaign in Westchester County in 1982. "We had a knock-down, drag-out over whether busing was an issue in Westchester. His polls told him it was. I said, 'I don't think it is, but if it is, it isn't to me,' and we didn't use it."<ref name="Purdum"/>
[[Carter Wrenn]], who worked on Republican campaigns for 44 years with Finkelstein in North Carolina, called him "one of the most creative people I have ever worked with ... He is brilliant in terms of analyzing polls and numbers. He has a unique combination of an analytical and creative mind ... This guy's a workaholic. He must work 18 hours a day ... If you need him, he comes."<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
[[Thomas F. Ellis|Tom Ellis]], cofounder of the [[National Congressional Club]] said "Just knock on his head, and he'll give you an idea."<ref name="princeton.edu"/>
In 1990, [[Randall Rothenberg]] of ''The New York Times'' documented the rise of political and other ads intended to create controversy (in and of themselves), as well as to persuade. While [[Roger Ailes]] was credited by some as pioneering the tactic, "other Washington political hands give credit to Finkelstein, another Republican consultant, who deployed numerous news-generating commercials in his 1982 work for the [[National Conservative Political Action Committee]]."<ref>Rothenberg, Randall, New Yoirk Times News Service, published in the Toronto Globe and Mail, January 9, 1990, "Controversial ads aimed at attracting news coverage"</ref>
Finkelstein's early style is described in an scholarly account of a Congressional primary race in Arizona, published in 1979 in the "[[Quarterly Journal of Speech]]".<ref name="benson">{{cite journal|doi=10.1080/00335638109383581|last=Benson|first=Thomas W.|year=1981|title=Another Shooting in Cowtown|journal=Quarterly Journal of Speech|volume=67|issue=4|pages=347–406}}</ref>
Finkelstein gave advice to political candidates or elected officials to perform the "dance of the honest man", a metaphor for responding to "questions about transparency, honesty, or integrity" by imagining oneself as a typical, honest voter.<ref name="politickernj">{{cite web|url=http://www.politickernj.com/jeffmichaels/28936/dance-honest-man|title=The Dance of the Honest Man|last=Michaels|first=Jeff|date=April 11, 2009|work=PolitickerNJ.com|accessdate=May 13, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517081608/http://www.politickernj.com/jeffmichaels/28936/dance-honest-man|archivedate=May 17, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Britain's ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' credited Finkelstein with using polling data to pinpoint the division of [[Jerusalem]] as an issue over which Israelis would reject a deal with the Palestinians, during the 1996 election in Israel. The newspaper attributed Benjamin Netanyahu's victory in part to Finkelstein's "scare-mongering".<ref>Colvile, Robert, The world is spinning on the hustlers' axis, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', August 16, 2008, p. 24</ref>
== Other businesses == Finkelstein's office shared a small building with Diversified Research, a separate but related firm that executes telephone surveys and packages their results for political and business consultants (including some media pollsters).<ref name="Associated Press 1988">Associated Press, October 27, 1988, "Presidential Dead Heat in New York"</ref> The firm, long based in [[Irvington, New York]], had formerly been located in nearby [[Mount Kisco]].<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/>
Finkelstein also had interests in Murphy-Powers Media Inc. (whimsically named for two young campaign-manager proteges),<ref>https://www.politicalresources.com/2013-02-19-22-18-56/directory/campaign-media-services/media-consultants/murphy-powers-media-inc</ref> and Multi-Media Services (a media-buying firm helmed for years by [[Tony Fabrizio]]).<ref>Gold, Matea, ''Los Angeles Times'', January 20, 2011, "Alexandria, Va., hosts a quiet hub of Republican power," accessed thru http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/20/nation/la-na-king-street-20110121/2</ref>
== "Arthur's Kids" == Over four decades, Finkelstein was responsible for the early hiring and training of many successful Republican consultants, operatives and managers—collectively called "Arthur's Kids"<ref>http://www.nationalreview.com/article/444254/arthur-finkelstein-republican-consultant-extraordinaire</ref> or "Arthur's Boys"<ref name="edition.cnn.com"/>—including [[Tony Fabrizio]], [[Alex Castellanos]], [[Craig Shirley]], [[George Birnbaum]], [[Beth Myers]], [[Mitch Bainwol]], [[Ari Fleischer]],<ref name="samroberts"/> Carter Wrenn, Kieran Mahoney,<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/05/nyregion/1992-elections-new-york-state-behind-victory-d-amato-strategist-shuns-spotlight.html?scp=1&sq="Arthur+J.+Finkelstein"+d%27amato&st=nyt</ref> Zenia Mucha,<ref>https://thewaltdisneycompany.com/leaders/zenia-mucha/</ref> Jon Lerner,<ref name="Hagstrom, Jerry 2010"/> Rick Reed, Jim Murphy, the pollster brothers John and Jim McLaughlin,<ref>''Roll Call'', July 31, 2003, "Finkelstein's Proteges Are His Best Revenge"</ref> Rob Cole,<ref>https://www.newsday.com/long-island/politics/spin-cycle/1st-cd-cox-making-a-move-demos-naming-a-team-1.1727664</ref> and Adam Stoll.<ref name="Dicker, Frederic U. 2002"/> Others who worked with Finkelstein and have gone on to have successful independent careers include [[Frank Luntz]], [[Larry Weitzner]], [[Charles R. Black, Jr.]], [[Roger Stone]],<ref>Perlez, Jane, "POLITICS; REAGAN'S MAN ON BLUE COLLAR VOTERS", ''The New York Times'', January 20, 1984.</ref> Chris Mottola,<ref name="edition.cnn.com"/>[[John Heubusch]], [[Barney Keller]], [[Gordon Hensley]],<ref>Cook, Charles E., ''Roll Call'', December 12, 1996, "Political Surveyor" column, p. 5</ref> and [[Gary Maloney]].<ref>Schudel, Matt, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/arthur-finkelstein-shadowy-campaign-mastermind-and-gop-operative-dies-at-72/2017/08/19/0bd638c6-84e8-11e7-902a-2a9f2d808496_story.html "Arthur Finkelstein, quietly influential GOP campaign mastermind, dies at 72"], washingtonpost.com; accessed August 26, 2017.</ref>
==One World Trade Center inscription== Finkelstein is also reportedly the author of the words inscribed on the cornerstone of [[One World Trade Center]] (otherwise called the Freedom Tower), completed in 2014. At the 2004 dedication, Gov. Pataki read aloud the inscription: "To honor and remember those who lost their lives on September 11th, 2001 and as a tribute to the enduring spirit of freedom—July Fourth, 2004."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panynj.gov/press-room/press-item.cfm?headLine_id=489|title=Press Release Article - Port Authority of NY & NJ|website=Panynj.gov|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
==Clients, 1970-2017 (partial list)== * Former U.S. President [[Richard Nixon]] (1971–72) * Former U.S. President [[Ronald Reagan]] (1976–84) * Current Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] (1996, 1999) * Israeli Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon]] (2001) * Israeli politician [[Avigdor Lieberman]] (2009–17) * Jerusalem Mayor [[Nir Barkat]] (2008) * Hungarian Prime Minister [[Viktor Orbán]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://index.hu/belfold/2012/04/27/amerikai_specialistak_otleteibol_tankol_a_fidesz|title=Amerikai specialisták ötleteiből tankol a Fidesz|language=Hungarian|trans-title=American specialists fill up the ideas of the Fidesz|last=Spirk|first=József|date=April 27, 2012}}</ref> * Kosovo Prime Minister [[Hashim Thaçi]] * Bulgarian Prime Minister [[Sergey Stanishev]] * Czech Prime Minister [[Mirek Topolanek]] * Former Romanian Prime Minister [[Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu]]<ref name="berkowitz">{{cite news|first=Bill|last=Berkowitz|url=http://www.mediatransparency.com/story.php?storyID=58|title=Arthur Finkelstein is Hunting Hillary Clinton|publisher=Media Transparency|date=January 9, 2005|accessdate=May 6, 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051214200235/http://www.mediatransparency.com/story.php?storyID=58|archivedate=December 14, 2005|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * Azerbijan President [[Ilham Aliyev]] (2012–17) * U.S. Senator [[Orrin Hatch]] (1976–82) * Former U.S. Senator [[James L. Buckley]] (1970–80) * Former U.S. Senator [[Jesse Helms]] (1972–84) * Former U.S. Senator [[Strom Thurmond]] (1978) * Former U.S. Senator [[Gordon Humphrey]] (1978–84) * Former U.S. Senator [[Connie Mack III]] (1982–94) * Former U.S. Senator [[Larry Pressler]] (1996) * Former U.S. Senator [[John East]] (1980) * Former U.S. Senator [[Roger Jepsen]] (1978–84) * Former U.S. Senator [[Alfonse D'Amato]] (1980–98) * Former U.S. Senator [[Rudy Boschwitz]] (1996) * Former U.S. Senator [[Lauch Faircloth]] (1992–98) * Former U.S. Senator [[Bob Dole]] * Former U.S. Senator [[Don Nickles]] (1980–92) * Former U.S. Senator [[Robert C. Dornan]] * Former U.S. Representative [[Duncan L. Hunter]] (1980) * Former U.S. Representative, now U.S. Senator [[Patrick Toomey]] (2004) * Former U.S. Representative and Florida Attorney General [[Bill McCollum]] (1980-2010)<ref name="berkowitz"/> * Former U.S. Representative [[Elton Gallegly]] (1986–90) * Former U.S. Representative [[Connie Mack IV]] (2004–12)<ref name="berkowitz"/> * Former U.S. Representative [[Mary Bono Mack]] (2008–12) * Former U.S. Representative [[Rick Lazio]], 2010 candidate for Governor of New York {{citation needed|date=August 2017}} * Former U.S. Representative [[Steve Pearce (politician)|Steve Pearce]]<ref name="monahan">{{cite web|url=http://joemonahansnewmexico.blogspot.com/2007/10/pearces.html|title=Pearce's First Strike Gets 'Em Talking|last=Monahan|first=Joe|date=October 22, 2007|work=New Mexico Politics with Joe Monahan|accessdate=May 1, 2009}}</ref> * Former UN Ambassador [[Jeane Kirkpatrick]] (1985–87) * Former Texas Lieutenant Governor [[David Dewhurst]] (1994-2006) * Former California State Senator [[Edward M. Davis|Ed Davis]] (1986) * [[Terry Dolan (US political figure)|Terry Dolan]]'s the [[National Conservative Political Action Committee]] (NCPAC) (1975–87) * [[Bill Binnie]], 2010 candidate for U.S. Senate from New Hampshire (2010)<ref>DiStaso, John, [http://www.unionleader.com/article.aspx?headline=John+DiStaso's+Granite+Status%3A+Senate+fund-raising+update&articleId=27a6ef22-7798-4fe2-8f2b-88e2d0d9e35c Bill Binnie campaign], ''Manchester Union Leader'', October 8, 2009.</ref>
Finkelstein's firm did non-political work for a number of organizations:<ref name="berkowitz"/> * ''[[Time magazine]]'' * [[Scott Paper]] * [[McDonald's]] * [[Quaker Oats]] * Ledger Publications * The [[Trump Organization]] * Opponents of the new stadium on the West Side of [[Manhattan]]
In 1988, Finkelstein was hired by the ''[[New York Post]]'' to do polling in the hotly contested Democratic presidential primary,<ref>Rosenthal, Andrew, Behind the Forecasts of a Close Race: Why Some Are Off the Mark, ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 21, 1988, pg. D-25.</ref> and in the surprisingly close presidential race in the state that fall.<ref name="Associated Press 1988"/>
== Personal life == In 1996, ''[[Boston Magazine]]'' [[outing|outed]] Finkelstein as a homosexual in a feature story. In April 2005, Finkelstein acknowledged that in December 2004, he had married his partner of forty years in a civil ceremony at his home in [[Massachusetts]].<ref name="nagourney">{{cite news | first=Adam | last=Nagourney | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/09/politics/09finkelstein.html | title=G.O.P. Consultant Weds His Male Partner | work=The New York Times | date=April 9, 2005 | accessdate=May 6, 2005| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110512094151/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/09/politics/09finkelstein.html| archivedate=May 12, 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Finkelstein was a self-identified [[libertarianism|libertarian]] conservative. (He once did polling work for the Free Libertarian Party.)<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/> In his final years he increasingly distanced himself personally from [[social conservatism|social conservative]] elements within the Republican Party (while nevertheless still working for many conservative candidates).<ref name="nagourney" /> In a 1979 interview, he denied he was "a hard-core right-winger," but noted there was hardly "a serious conservative over the last 10 years [i.e. 1969-79] whom I haven't been involved with."<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/>
Finkelstein died of lung cancer on August 18, 2017, aged 72, in [[Ipswich, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Arthur Finklestein, master campaign strategist, dies at 72|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/arthur-finklestein-master-campaign-strategist-dies-at-72/|accessdate=August 19, 2017|work=Times of Israel|date=August 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Schudel|first1=Matt|title=Arthur Finkelstein, quietly influential GOP campaign mastermind, dies at 72|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/arthur-finkelstein-shadowy-campaign-mastermind-and-gop-operative-dies-at-72/2017/08/19/0bd638c6-84e8-11e7-902a-2a9f2d808496_story.html|accessdate=August 19, 2017|work=Washington Post|date=August 19, 2017}}</ref> Survivors included his husband, Donald Curiale, of Ipswich and Fort Lauderdale; two daughters, Jennifer Delgado of Danvers, Mass., Molly Finkelstein of Alpharetta, Ga.; two brothers; and a granddaughter Maryn BairdKelly.<ref name="auto"/>
== Quotes == * "A crook always beats a fool." (frequent saying)<ref>Pollster John McLaughlin, quoting Finkelstein, May 9, 2016, on Sean Hannity (Fox), transcript via AP Alerts</ref> ** VARIANT of above: "When you allow people to choose between the corrupt and the stupid, they will go for the corrupt." (Said in reference to a 2003 Israeli campaign)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/122304/njgop.html|title=NJJN - GOP strategist keeps New Jersey job despite comments to Israeli daily|date=March 22, 2005|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=August 26, 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050322091944/http://www.njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/122304/njgop.html|archivedate=March 22, 2005|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="haaretz.com">[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/607655.html] {{dead link|date=August 2017}}</ref> * "The most overwhelming fact of politics is what people do not know." (frequent saying)<ref name="samroberts"/> * "Stupid people say stupid things." ([[Hebrew language]] paper [[Maariv]] in 1999) * "I have been criticized for 20 years for running ideologically arched campaigns. I plead guilty. I will continue to run ideologically arched campaigns as long as there are more conservatives than there are liberals, rather than more Democrats than there are Republicans." (Speech to Conservative Political Action Conference, 1991)<ref name="samroberts"/> * Finkelstein insisted he never lied -- "I do not slander somebody without proof."<ref name="samroberts"/> * "In politics, it's what you perceive to be true that's true, not truth. If I tell you one thing is true, you will believe the second thing is true. A good politician will tell you a few things that are true before he will tell you a few things that are untrue, because you will then believe all the things he has said, true and untrue." (2011 speech in Prague)<ref name="samroberts"/> * "The political center has disappeared, and the Republican Party has become the party of the Christian right more so than in any other period in modern history ... Bush's victory not only establishes the power of the American Christian Right in this candidacy, but in fact established its power to elect the next Republican president."<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/11/politics/campaign/gop-adviser-says-bushs-evangelical-strategy-split-country.html|title=G.O.P. Adviser Says Bush's Evangelical Strategy Split Country|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|date=November 11, 2004|accessdate=August 26, 2017|website=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref name="haaretz.com"/> * "From now on, anyone who belongs to the Republican Party will automatically find himself in the same group as the opponents of [[abortion]], and anyone who supports abortion will automatically be labeled a Democrat."<ref name="auto2"/> * "She will put off Democrats from the center. In terms of the Republicans, Hillary Clinton is a wonderful candidate for the presidency." ([[Maariv]], 11/04)<ref name="janofsky">{{cite news | first=Michael | last=Janofsky | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/11/politics/campaign/11repub.html?ex=1146369600&en=146eea676812e604&ei=5070 | title=G.O.P. Adviser Says Bush's Evangelical Strategy Split Country | date=November 11, 2004 | accessdate=April 28, 2006 | work=The New York Times}}</ref> * "I think I'm the playwright or the director, and not the actor. And the actors need to be onstage, not the director. And I think it's absurd that people who do what I do become as important, as celebrated, as the ones who are running."<ref name="auto"/> * Speaking to GOP congressional hopefuls in 1978: "If any of you do get elected, and chances are 19-to-1 you won't ... don't run your own campaign; don't let your spouse do it; and don't listen to the nice lady who praises the brilliance of your speech—she probably was the only one in the audience who thought so." He said [[Proposition 13]] (just passed in California) shouldn't be interpreted as "evidence people want services cut. They want taxes cut," and voters aren't sophisticated enough to understand that one leads to the other.<ref name="Baker, Donald P. 1978">Baker, Donald P., "GOP 'Pupils' Learn Humility; Workshop for Congressional Hopefuls" ''[[The Washington Post]]'', June 20, 1978, C1</ref> * He cited the 1965 New York mayoral campaign of [[John Lindsay]], elected because "he promised to cut the budget in half and double the services. Four years later, when it was apparent that he had doubled the budget and cut services; Lindsay said, 'Yes, I made a mistake,' but he was re-elected when he promised to help end the Vietnam War."<ref name="Baker, Donald P. 1978"/> * Said in 1979 that there are three kinds of candidates' wives—the wife "who hates politics and refuses to come out of the house," the wife who is reluctant but "will do what she is asked," and the wife "who wants to be the candidate and loves politics more than her husband does." He put [[Rosalynn Carter]] and Arlene (Mrs. Phil) Crane in the last category.<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/> * After being praised for his winning advice in a Nassau County election: "I'm a hero, but the first time a town clerk loses an election after my figures show him winning, I will be over the hill and a bum."<ref name="Lynn, Frank 1979"/> * Longtime associate George Birnbaum: "I would always say, 'Arthur, do you realize how much we're changing history?' He would say, 'I don't know how much we're changing history; we're touching history."<ref name="samroberts"/>

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Barbara Ehrenreich | image = Barbara Ehrenreich 2 by David Shankbone.jpg | caption =Ehrenreich in 2015 | pseudonym = | birth_name =Barbara Alexander | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|8|26|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Butte, Montana]] | occupation = Social critic, journalist, author, activist | genre = Nonfiction, investigative journalism | movement = | notableworks = | influences = | influenced = | children = 2 | spouse = | website = {{URL|http://barbaraehrenreich.com/}} }} {{American socialism|Activists}} '''Barbara Ehrenreich''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɛər|ən|r|aɪ|k}};<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.speech.cs.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/cmudict?in=barbara+ehrenreich|title=The CMU Pronouncing Dictionary|publisher=|accessdate=12 May 2016}}</ref> born August 26, 1941) is an American author and [[activism|political activist]] who describes herself as "a myth buster by trade"<ref name=booknotes>{{cite news|last=Lamb|first=Brian (Interviewer)|title=Fear of Falling: The Inner Life of the Middle Class: Barbara Ehrenreich Interview Transcript|url=http://www.booknotes.org/Watch/9435-1/Barbara-Ehrenreich.aspx|accessdate=8 May 2011|newspaper=Booknotes (CSPAN)|date=18 October 1989}}</ref> and has been called "a veteran [[muckraker]]" by ''[[The New Yorker]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Books Briefly Noted: Bait and Switch by Barbara Ehrenreich|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2005/09/26/050926crbn_brieflynoted3|accessdate=9 May 2011|newspaper=New Yorker|date=September 2005}}</ref> During the 1980s and early 1990s she was a prominent figure in the [[Democratic Socialists of America]]. She is a widely read and award-winning [[columnist]] and [[essayist]], and author of 21 books. Ehrenreich is perhaps best known for her 2001 book ''[[Nickel and Dimed|Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting By in America]]''. A memoir of Ehrenreich's three-month experiment surviving on [[minimum wage]] as a waitress, hotel maid, house cleaner, nursing-home aide, and [[Wal-Mart]] clerk, it was described by ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine as "jarring" and "full of riveting grit,"<ref>{{cite news|last=Meadows|first=Susannah|title=A Working Knowledge|newspaper=Newsweek|date=4 June 2001}}</ref> and by ''[[The New Yorker]]'' as an "exposé" putting "human flesh on the bones of such abstractions as 'living wage' and 'affordable housing'."<ref>{{cite news|title=Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting By in America|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2001/05/28/010528crbn_brieflynoted2|accessdate=9 May 2011|newspaper=New Yorker|date=28 May 2001}}</ref>
==Early life==
Ehrenreich was born '''Barbara Alexander''' to Isabelle Oxley and Ben Howes Alexander in [[Butte, Montana|Butte]], Montana, which she describes as then being "a bustling, brawling, blue collar mining town."<ref>{{cite news|last=Ehrenreich |first=Barbara |title=About Barbara |url=http://www.barbaraehrenreich.com/barbara_ehrenreich.htm |accessdate=8 May 2011 |newspaper=barbaraehrenreich.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623005647/http://barbaraehrenreich.com/barbara_ehrenreich.htm |archivedate=23 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> In an interview on [[C-SPAN]], she characterized her parents as "strong union people" with two family rules: "never [[Strikebreaker|cross a picket line]] and never vote Republican."<ref name=booknotes/> In a talk she gave in 1999, Ehrenreich called herself a "fourth-generation atheist."<ref>{{cite web|last=Ehrenreich|first=Barbara|title=My Family Values Atheism: Acceptance speech upon receiving the 1999 Freethought Heroine Award|url=http://www.ffrf.org/legacy/fttoday/2000/april2000/ehrenreich.html|publisher=Freedom From Religion Foundation|accessdate=9 May 2011}}</ref>
"As a little girl," she told ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 1993, "I would go to school and have to decide if my parents were the evil people they were talking about, part of the Red Menace we read about in the Weekly Reader, just because my mother was a liberal Democrat who would always talk about racial injustice."<ref name="Edwards">{{cite news|last=Edwards|first=Ivana|title=Barbara Ehrenreich's Writing Attracts an Attentive Audience|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/17/nyregion/barbara-ehrenreich-s-writing-attracts-an-attentive-audience.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=8 May 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=17 October 1993}}</ref> Her father was a [[copper mining|copper miner]] who went to the [[Montana Tech of the University of Montana|Montana School of Mines]] (now Montana Tech<ref>https://mtech.edu/</ref>), and then to [[Carnegie Mellon University]]. He eventually became a senior executive at the [[Gillette Corporation]]. Her parents later divorced.
Ehrenreich studied [[chemistry]] at [[Reed College]], graduating in 1963. Her senior thesis was entitled ''Electrochemical oscillations of the silicon anode''. In 1968, she received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]] in [[Immunology|cellular immunology]] from [[Rockefeller University]].<ref>{{cite av media|url=http://vimeo.com/channels/theschooloflife#10454695|title=The School of Life|publisher=|accessdate=12 May 2016}}</ref>
In 1970, Ehrenreich gave birth to her daughter [[Rosa Brooks]] in a public clinic in New York. "I was the only white patient at the clinic," she told ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' newspaper in 1987. "They induced my labor because it was late in the evening and the doctor wanted to go home. I was enraged. The experience made me a feminist."<ref name="Sherman">{{cite news|last=Sherman|first=Scott|title=Class Warrior: Barbara Ehrenreich's Singular Crusade|url=https://groups.yahoo.com/group/DemocraticLeft/message/11149|accessdate=9 May 2011|newspaper=Columbia Journalism Review|date=June 2003}}</ref>
==Career==
After completing her doctorate, Ehrenreich did not pursue a career in science. Instead, she worked first as an analyst with the [[Bureau of the Budget]] in New York City and with the [[Health Policy Advisory Center]], and later as an assistant professor at the [[State University of New York at Old Westbury]]. In 1972, Ehrenreich began co-teaching a course on women and health with feminist journalist and academic [[Deirdre English]]. Through the rest of the seventies, Ehrenreich worked mostly in health-related research, advocacy and activism, including co-writing, with English, several feminist books and pamphlets on the history and politics of women's health. During this period she began speaking frequently at conferences staged by women's health centers and women's groups, by universities, and by the United States government. She also spoke regularly about [[socialist feminism]] and about feminism in general.<ref name="oasis.lib.harvard.edu">{{cite web|title=Papers of Barbara Ehrenreich, 1922-2007 (inclusive), 1963-2007 (bulk): A Finding Aid|url=http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch01203|publisher=Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, Harvard University|accessdate=8 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111216220246/http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch01203|archive-date=2011-12-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Throughout her career, Ehrenreich has worked as a freelance writer, and she is arguably best known for her non-fiction reportage, book reviews and social commentary. Her reviews have appeared in ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'', ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', ''[[The Nation]]'', ''[[The New Republic]]'', the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' Book Review supplement, ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', [[Salon.com]], ''[[TV Guide]]'', ''[[Mirabella]]'' and ''American Film''. Her essays, op-eds and feature articles have appeared in ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'', ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'', ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'', ''[[The Nation (magazine)|The Nation]]'', ''The New Republic'', the ''[[New Statesman]]'', ''[[In These Times]]'', ''[[The Progressive]]'', ''Working Woman'', and ''[[Z magazine]]''.<ref name="oasis.lib.harvard.edu"/>
Ehrenreich has served as founder, advisor or board member to a number of organizations including the U.S. [[National Women's Health Network]], the [[National Abortion Rights Action League]], the National Mental Health Consumers' Self-Help Clearinghouse, the Nationwide Women's Program of the [[American Friends Service Committee]], the Brooklyn-based [[Association for Union Democracy]], political activist [[Robert Boehm]]'s Boehm Foundation, the anti-poverty group Women's Committee of 100, the [[National Writers Union]], ''The Progressive'' magazine's Progressive Media Project, the [[Fairness and Accuracy In Reporting]] (FAIR) advisory committee on women in the media, the [[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws]], the [[Center for Popular Economics]], and the [[Campaign for America's Future]].<ref name="oasis.lib.harvard.edu"/>
Between 1979 and 1981, she served as an adjunct associate professor at [[New York University]] and as a visiting professor at the [[University of Missouri]] at Columbia and at [[Sangamon State University]]. She lectured at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], was a writer-in-residence at the [[Ohio State University]], [[Wayne Morse]] chair at the [[University of Oregon]], and a teaching fellow at the graduate school of journalism at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. She has been a fellow at the [[New York Institute for the Humanities]], the [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation]], the [[Institute for Policy Studies]], and the New York-based Society of American Historians.<ref name="oasis.lib.harvard.edu"/>
In 2006, Ehrenreich founded United Professionals, an organization described as "a nonprofit, non-partisan membership organization for [[white-collar worker]]s, regardless of profession or employment status. We reach out to all unemployed, underemployed, and anxiously employed workers—people who bought the American dream that education and credentials could lead to a secure middle class life, but now find their lives disrupted by forces beyond their control."<ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.unitedprofessionals.org/about/ | publisher=United Professionals | title=About United Professionals | accessdate=2008-10-04 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010002507/http://www.unitedprofessionals.org/about/ | archivedate=10 October 2008 | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref>
{{As of | 2013}} Ehrenreich is an honorary co-chair of the [[Democratic Socialists of America]]. She also serves on the [[NORML]] Board of Directors, the [[Institute for Policy Studies]] Board of Trustees and the Editorial Board of ''The Nation''. She has served on the editorial boards of ''[[Social Policy (magazine)|Social Policy]]'', ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'', ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', ''[[Seven Days (newspaper)|Seven Days]]'', ''[[Lear's]]'', ''[[The New Press]]'', and Culturefront, and as a contributing editor to ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]]''.<ref name="oasis.lib.harvard.edu"/>
==Awards==
In 1980, Ehrenreich shared the [[National Magazine Award]] for excellence in reporting with colleagues at [[Mother Jones magazine]]<ref>{{cite web|title=National Magazine Awards Database of Past Winners and Finalists|url=http://www.magazine.org/asme/magazine_awards/searchable_database/index.aspx|publisher=American Society of Magazine Editors|accessdate=8 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110526232156/http://www.magazine.org/asme/magazine_awards/searchable_database/index.aspx| archivedate= 26 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> for the cover story ''The Corporate Crime of the Century'',<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news|title=Columnist Biography: Barbara Ehrenreich|url=https://www.nytimes.com/ref/opinion/ehrenreich-bio.html|accessdate=8 May 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=1 July 2004}}</ref> about "what happens after the U.S. government forces a dangerous drug, pesticide or other product off the domestic market, then the manufacturer sells that same product, frequently with the direct support of the State Department, throughout the rest of the world."<ref>{{cite news|last=Dowie|first=Mark|title=The Corporate Crime of the Century|url=http://motherjones.com/toc/1979/11/table-contents|accessdate=8 May 2011|newspaper=Mother Jones|year=1979|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006204928/https://www.motherjones.com/toc/1979/11/table-contents|archivedate=6 October 2012|df=}}</ref>
In 1998 the [[American Humanist Association]] named her "Humanist of the Year."<ref>{{cite web|title=Humanist of the Year|url=http://www.americanhumanist.org/who_we_are/about_the_AHA/Humanists_of_the_Year|publisher=American Humanist Association|accessdate=8 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110522103346/http://www.americanhumanist.org/who_we_are/about_the_AHA/Humanists_of_the_Year| archivedate= 22 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In 2000, she received the [[Sidney Hillman]] Award for journalism for the Harper's article "Nickel and Dimed," which was later published as a chapter in her book of the same title.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism |url=http://www.hillmanfoundation.org/hillman-prizes/hillman-prize-magazine-journalism |publisher=Sidney Hillman Foundation |accessdate=8 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110503214236/http://www.hillmanfoundation.org/hillman-prizes/hillman-prize-magazine-journalism |archivedate=3 May 2011 }}</ref>
In 2002, she won a National Magazine Award for her essay "Welcome to Cancerland: A mammogram leads to a cult of pink kitsch," which describes Ehrenreich's own experience of being diagnosed with breast cancer, and describes what she calls the "breast cancer cult," which "serves as an accomplice in global poisoning -- normalizing cancer, prettying it up, even presenting it, perversely, as a positive and enviable experience."<ref>{{cite web|title=Harper's Magazine Awards and Honors|url=http://www.harpers.org/advertising/pdfs-2008-10/Harpers_Magazine_AwardsAndHonors.pdf|publisher=Harper's Magazine|accessdate=8 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ehrenreich |first=Barbara |title=Welcome To Cancerland |url=http://www.barbaraehrenreich.com/cancerland.htm |accessdate=8 May 2011 |newspaper=Harper's Magazine |date=November 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609202708/http://www.barbaraehrenreich.com/cancerland.htm |archivedate=9 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 2004, she received the [[Puffin/Nation Prize for Creative Citizenship]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Barbara Ehrenreich At McGill, Thursday, Nov. 18, 6:30|url=http://neath.wordpress.com/2010/11/14/barbara-ehrenreich-at-mcgill-thursday-nov-18-630/|publisher=McGill University|accessdate=8 May 2011}}</ref> awarded jointly by the [[Puffin Foundation]] of New Jersey and [[The Nation Institute]] to an American who challenges the status quo "through distinctive, courageous, imaginative, socially responsible work of significance."<ref>{{cite web|title=Puffin Foundation: Puffin Nation Award For Creative Citizenship|url=http://www.puffinfoundation.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=23:puffin-nation-award-for-creative-citizenship&catid=5:projects&Itemid=37|publisher=Puffin Foundation|accessdate=8 May 2011}}</ref>
In 2007, she received the [[Four Freedoms Award|"Freedom from Want" Medal]], awarded by the [[Roosevelt Institute]] in celebration of "those whose life's work embodies FDR's Four Freedoms."<ref>{{cite web |title=Four Freedoms Award: Celebrating those whose life's work embodies FDR's Four Freedoms |url=http://www.rooseveltinstitute.org/four-freedoms-medals |publisher=Roosevelt Institute |accessdate=8 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725121827/http://www.rooseveltinstitute.org/four-freedoms-medals |archivedate=25 July 2011 |df= }} </ref>
Ehrenreich has received a [[Ford Foundation]] award for humanistic perspectives on contemporary society (1982), a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] (1987–88) and a grant for research and writing from the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation]] (1995). She has received honorary degrees from Reed College, the State University of New York at Old Westbury, the College of Wooster in Ohio, John Jay College, UMass Lowell and La Trobe University in Melbourne, Australia.<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
In November 2018, Ehrenreich received the prestigious [[Erasmus Prize]] by King [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands]] for her work in investigative journalism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.erasmusprijs.org/Nieuws?mode=detail&item=Press+release+2018+Erasmus+Prize+awarded+to+Barbara+Ehrenreich&lang=en|title=Press release: 2018 Erasmus Prize awarded to Barbara Ehrenreich|last=|first=|date=2018-03-01|website=www.erasmusprijs.org|publisher=Stichting Praemium Erasmianum|language=en|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
==Personal life and family==
Ehrenreich has one brother, Ben Alexander Jr., and one sister, Diane Alexander.
When Ehrenreich was 35, according to the book ''Always Too Soon: Voices of Support for Those Who Have Lost Both Parents'', her mother died "from a likely suicide."<ref name="Edited by Allison Gilbert and Christina Baker Kline 2006 269">{{cite book|last=Edited by Allison Gilbert and Christina Baker Kline|title=Always Too Soon: Voices of Support for Those Who Have Lost Both Parents|year=2006|publisher=Seal Press|pages=269|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ygkEWnnIrpkC&lpg=PA269&dq=%22always%20too%20soon%22%20barbara%20ehrenreich&pg=PA269#v=onepage&q=%22always%20too%20soon%22%20barbara%20ehrenreich&f=false}}</ref> Her father died years later from Alzheimer's disease.<ref name="Edited by Allison Gilbert and Christina Baker Kline 2006 269"/>
She has been married and divorced twice. She met her first husband, [[John Ehrenreich]], during an [[Peace movement|anti-war activism]] campaign in [[New York City]], and they married in 1966. He is a clinical psychologist,<ref>{{cite web|title=Bitters and Cream (personal site)|url=http://www.bittersandcream.com/index.php?p=1_4_About-Me|publisher=John Ehrenreich|accessdate=9 May 2011}}</ref> and they co-wrote several books about health policy and labor issues before divorcing in 1977. In 1983, she married Gary Stevenson, a [[trade union|union]] organizer for the [[International Brotherhood of Teamsters|Teamsters]].<ref name="Edwards"/> She divorced Stevenson in 1993.<ref name="oasis.lib.harvard.edu"/>
Ehrenreich has two children. Born in 1970, her daughter [[Rosa Brooks|Rosa]] was named after [[Rosa Parks]], [[Rosa Luxemburg]], and a great-grandmother.<ref name="Sherman"/> She is a Virginia-based law professor, national security and foreign policy expert and writer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/author/RosaBrooks|title=Foreign Policy - the Global Magazine of News and Ideas|publisher=|accessdate=12 May 2016}}</ref> Born in 1972, her son [[Ben Ehrenreich|Ben]] is a journalist and novelist in [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/ben-ehrenreich-david-grann-new-yorker-gq-atlantic-2011-5|title=Meet The Los Angeles Writer Who Beat The New Yorker, GQ, And The Atlantic|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-03-22|language=en}}</ref>
Filling in for a vacationing [[Thomas Friedman]] as a columnist with ''The New York Times'' in 2004, Ehrenreich wrote about how, in the fight for women's reproductive rights, "it's the women who shrink from acknowledging their own abortions who really irk me," and said that she herself "had two abortions during my all-too-fertile years."<ref>{{cite news|last=Ehrenreich|first=Barbara|title=Owning Up To Abortion|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/22/opinion/owning-up-to-abortion.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=9 May 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=22 July 2004}}</ref> In her 1990 book of essays ''The Worst Years of Our Lives'', she wrote that "the one regret I have about my own abortions is that they cost money that might otherwise have been spent on something more pleasurable, like taking the kids to movies and theme parks."<ref>{{cite book|last=Andrews|first=Robert|title=The Columbia Dictionary of Quotations|year=1993|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|pages=3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4cl5c4T9LWkC&lpg=PA3&dq=%22The%20one%20regret%20I%20have%20about%20my%20own%20abortions%20is%20that%20they%20cost%20money%20that%20might%20otherwise%20have%20been%20spent%20on%20something%20more%20pleasurable%2C%20like%20taking%20the%20kids%20to%20movies%20and%20theme%20parks.%22&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q=%22The%20one%20regret%20I%20have%20about%20my%20own%20abortions%20is%20that%20they%20cost%20money%20that%20might%20otherwise%20have%20been%20spent%20on%20something%20more%20pleasurable,%20like%20taking%20the%20kids%20to%20movies%20and%20theme%20parks.%22&f=false}}</ref>
Ehrenreich was diagnosed with [[breast cancer]] shortly after the release of her book ''[[Nickel and Dimed|Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting By in America]]''. This resulted in the award-winning article "Welcome to Cancerland," published in the November 2001 issue of ''[[Harper's Magazine]]''. The article inspired the 2011 documentary ''[[Pink Ribbons, Inc.]]''.<ref name=ctvcp>{{cite news|last=Szklarski|first=Cassandra|title=NFB doc examines the politics of marketing disease|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Entertainment/20120131/nfb-breast-cancer-documentary-120131/|accessdate=31 January 2012|newspaper=[[CTV News]]|date=31 January 2012|agency=[[Canadian Press]]}}</ref>
In 2000, Ehrenreich endorsed the [[Ralph Nader presidential campaign, 2000|Presidential campaign of Ralph Nader]]; in 2004, she urged voters to support [[John Kerry]] in the [[swing states]].<ref>[http://www.commondreams.org/news2004/0914-20.htm Nader's Top Endorsers From 2000 Urge "Swing States" Support for Kerry] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304111708/http://www.commondreams.org/news2004/0914-20.htm |date=2016-03-04 }}, [[Common Dreams]], Sept. 14, 2004</ref> In February 2008, Ehrenreich expressed support for Senator [[Barack Obama]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. presidential campaign]].<ref>[http://ehrenreich.blogs.com/barbaras_blog/2008/02/unstoppable-oba.html "Unstoppable Obama"] February 14, 2008</ref>
Ehrenreich lives in [[Alexandria, Virginia|Alexandria]], [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Ehrenreich|first=Barbara|title=Huffington Post Biography|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/barbara-ehrenreich|accessdate=8 May 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post}}</ref>
==Books== [[Image:Barbara Ehrenreich by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|250px|Ehrenreich at a ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' discussion]]
===Non-fiction=== * ''The Uptake, Storage, and Intracellular Hydrolysis of Carbohydrates by Macrophages'' (with [[Zanvil A. Cohn]]) (1969) * ''Long March, Short Spring: The Student Uprising at Home and Abroad'' (with John Ehrenreich) (1969) * ''The American Health Empire: Power, Profits, and Politics'' (with John Ehrenreich and Health PAC) (1971) * ''Witches, Midwives, and Nurses: A History of Women Healers'' (with [[Deirdre English]]) (1972) * ''Complaints and Disorders: The Sexual Politics of Sickness'' (with Deirdre English) (1973) * ''For Her Own Good: Two Centuries of the Experts' Advice to Women'' (with Deirdre English) (1978) * ''Women in the Global Factory'' (1983) * ''The Hearts of Men: American Dreams and the Flight from Commitment'' (1983) * ''Re-Making Love: The Feminization of Sex'' (with Elizabeth Hess and Gloria Jacobs) (1986) * ''The Mean Season'' (with [[Fred L. Block]], [[Richard A. Cloward]], and [[Frances Fox Piven]]) (1987) * ''Fear of Falling: The Inner Life of the Middle Class'' (1989) * ''The Worst Years of Our Lives: Irreverent Notes from a Decade of Greed'' (1990) * ''The Snarling Citizen: Essays'' (1995) * ''Blood Rites: Origins and History of the Passions of War'' (1997) * ''[[Nickel and Dimed]]: On (Not) Getting By In America'' (2001) * ''Global Woman: Nannies, Maids, and Sex Workers in the New Economy'' (ed., with Arlie Hochschild) (2003) * ''[[Bait and Switch: The (Futile) Pursuit of the American Dream]]'' (2005) * ''[[Dancing in the Streets: A History of Collective Joy]]'' (2007) * ''This Land Is Their Land: Reports From a Divided Nation'' (2008) * ''Bright-sided: How the Relentless Promotion of Positive Thinking Has Undermined America'' (2009). UK: ''Smile Or Die: How Positive Thinking Fooled America and the World'' * ''Living with a Wild God: A Nonbeliever's Search for the Truth about Everything'' (2014) * ''Natural Causes: An Epidemic of Wellness, the Certainty of Dying, and Killing Ourselves to Live Longer'' (2018)
===Fiction=== * ''Kipper's Game'' (1993)
==Essays== <!--Note: Please don't use *italics* for the titles of essays or articles, it's not correct. Instead, put quote marks round them. --> * [https://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/1979/11/ehrenreich.html "The Charge: Gynocide"], investigative journalism about the [[Dalkon Shield]] in the third world, ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', November/December issue, 1979 * "Making Sense of La Difference", ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' Magazine, 1992 * "Burt, Loni and Our Way of Life", ''TIME'' Magazine, September 20, 1993 * "In Defense of Talk Shows", ''TIME'' Magazine, December 4, 1995 * "[http://cogweb.ucla.edu/Debate/Ehrenreich.html The New Creationism: Biology Under Attack"] ''[[The Nation]]'', June 9, 1997 * "{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020217090106/http://www.geocities.com/i_sang_holy_holy/time_essay.html |date=February 17, 2002 |title=How 'Natural' Is Rape? Despite a Daffy New Theory, It's Not Just a Guy in Touch with His Inner Caveman" }}, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' Magazine, January 31, 2000 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131108181820/http://www.barbaraehrenreich.com/cancerland.htm "Welcome to Cancerland"], 2001 [[National Magazine Award]] finalist * "A New Counterterrorism Strategy: Feminism", AlterNet, 2005 * "Fight for Your Right to Party" ''TIME'' Magazine, December 18, 2006 * [http://www.commondreams.org/view/2009/02/22-4 "My Unwitting Role in Acts of Torture"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', February 22, 2009 * [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/09/opinion/09ehrenreich.html "Is It Now a Crime to Be Poor?"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 9, 2009 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091022105323/http://www.guernicamag.com/blog/1354/barbara_ehrenreich_are_women_g/ "Are Women Getting Sadder? Or Are We All Just Getting a Lot More Gullible?"], ''[[Guernica Magazine]]'', October 13, 2009 * [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jan/02/cancer-positive-thinking-barbara-ehrenreich "Smile! You've got cancer"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', January 2, 2010 *[http://rosalux.de/fileadmin/rls_uploads/pdfs/sonst_publikationen/ehrenreich_death_of_a_yuppie_dream90.pdf Death of a Yuppie Dream - The Rise and Fall of the Professional-Managerial Class]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{Official website|http://barbaraehrenreich.com/}} * [http://ehrenreich.blogs.com Barbara Ehrenreich's blog] * {{C-SPAN|Barbara Ehrenreich}} * {{worldcat id|id=lccn-n50-30509}} * [http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:RAD.SCHL:sch01203 Papers of Barbara Ehrenreich, 1922-2007 (inclusive), 1963-2007 (bulk).] [https://web.archive.org/web/20041016004838/http://www.sfbg.com/lit/march00/smile.html Schlesinger Library], Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University.
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
Lieutenant General '''Bazilio Olara-Okello''' (1929 – 9 January 1990) was a [[Uganda]]n [[Officer (armed forces)|military officer]] and one of the [[commander]]s of the [[Uganda National Liberation Army]] (UNLA) that together with the [[Tanzania People's Defence Force|Tanzanian army]] overthrew [[Idi Amin]] in 1979. In 1985, he was briefly the chairman of the ruling Military Council and ''de facto'' [[President of Uganda|head of state of Uganda]], and later, [[Lieutenant General]] and chief of the armed forces. During the [[Ugandan Bush War|civil war in Uganda]] between the UNLA (which was now the national army) and [[Yoweri Museveni]]'s [[National Resistance Army]], president [[Milton Obote]] alienated much of the [[Acholi]]-dominated officer corps, including Olara-Okello and General [[Tito Okello]], by appointing his fellow ethnic [[Langi people|Lango]], Brigadier Smith Opon Acak, as army Chief of Staff. On 27 July 1985, an army brigade of the UNLA commanded by Olara-Okello, and composed mostly of [[Acholi]] troops, staged a [[coup d'état]] against [[Milton Obote]]'s government and seized power. The [[National Assembly of Uganda|National Assembly]] was dissolved and a Military Council was established. Between 27 and 29 July 1985, Olara-Okello was Chairman of the Military Council, and ''de facto'' head of state. On 29 July, General [[Tito Okello]] replaced Olara-Okello as Chairman of the Military Council, and Olara-Okello was promoted from the rank of [[Brigadier]] to that of [[Lieutenant General]], and named chief of the armed forces. He commanded the army until [[Yoweri Museveni]]'s [[National Resistance Army]] seized power on 26 January 1986. Olara-Okello fled to exile in [[Sudan]], where he lived until he died in [[Omdurman]] Hospital in [[Khartoum]] on 9 January 1990. ==References== *[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/ugtoc.html "A Country Study: Uganda"], ''[[Library of Congress]] *[https://www.nytimes.com/1985/08/08/world/around-the-world-uganda-s-new-rulers-reportedly-detain-1000.html "Uganda's New Rulers Reportedly Detain 1,000"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 8, 1985 ==See also== *[[Uganda since 1979]], part of the [[History of Uganda]] series. *[[Nairobi Agreement, 1985]] *[[Politics of Uganda]] *[[Political parties of Uganda]] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=Chairman of the Military Council
''de facto'' head of state|before=[[Milton Obote]]
As [[President of Uganda]]|after=[[Tito Okello]]|years=27–29 July 1985}} {{s-end}} {{UgandaPresidents}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Okello, Bazilio Olara}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:Acholi people]] [[Category:Presidents of Uganda]] [[Category:Ugandan exiles]] [[Category:Ugandan military personnel]]
