font-size:90%" |+ '''[[Penang State Legislative Assembly]]''' !|Year !|Constituency !colspan=2| !|Votes !|Pct !colspan=2|Opponent(s) !|Votes !|Pct !|Ballots cast !|Majority !|Turnout |- | [[Malaysian general election, 1986|1986]] | '''Kampong Kolam''' | {{Party shading/Democratic Action Party}} | | {{nowrap|'''Lim Kit Siang'''}} ([[Democratic Action Party|'''DAP''']]) | align="right" | '''8,900''' | '''63.07%''' | {{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | | Tham Soon Seong ([[Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia|Gerakan]]) | align="right" | 5,211 | 36.93% | 14,391 | 3,689 | 73.49% |- | [[Malaysian general election, 1990|1990]] | '''Padang Kota''' | {{Party shading/Democratic Action Party}} | | {{nowrap|'''Lim Kit Siang'''}} ([[Democratic Action Party|'''DAP''']]) | align="right" | '''6,317''' | '''52.96%''' | {{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | | [[Lim Chong Eu]] ([[Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia|Gerakan]]) | align="right" | 5,611 | 47.04% | 12,221 | 706 | 72.14% |- | [[Malaysian general election, 1995|1995]] | '''Tanjong Bunga''' | {{Party shading/Democratic Action Party}} | | {{nowrap|Lim Kit Siang}} ([[Democratic Action Party|DAP]]) | align="right" | 5,384 | 29.15% | {{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | | '''[[Koh Tsu Koon]]''' ([[Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia|'''Gerakan''']]) | align="right" | 13,087 | 70.85% | 18,815 | 7,703 | 77.68% |- | [[Malaysian general election, 1999|1999]] | '''Kebun Bunga''' | {{Party shading/Democratic Action Party}} | | {{nowrap|Lim Kit Siang}} ([[Democratic Action Party|DAP]]) | align="right" | 5,142 | 37.11% | {{Party shading/Barisan Nasional}} | | '''Teng Hock Nan''' ([[Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia|'''Gerakan''']]) | align="right" | 8,551 | 61.72% | 14,195 | 3,409 | 68.67% |} == Timeline == {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * 1941: Born in [[Batu Pahat]], [[Johor]], [[British Malaya]] now [[Malaysia]]. * 1966: National Organising Secretary of the DAP (1966 to 1969). * 1969: Elected Member of Parliament for Kota Melaka (1969–1974); ** Promoted to Secretary-General of DAP; ** Detained under the Internal Security Act for 18 months. * 1974: Elected Member of Parliament for Kota Melaka, and State Assemblyman for Kubu, Melaka (1974–1978). * 1978: Elected Member of Parliament for Petaling Jaya (1978–1982); * 1979: Convicted of five charges under Official Secrets Act for exposing an arms deal between the government and a Swiss company. * 1982: Elected Member of Parliament for Kota Melaka (1982–1986). * 1986: Elected Member of Parliament for Tanjong, and State Assemblyman for Kampong Kolam, Penang (1986–1989). * 1987: Detained under the Internal Security Act in Operation Lallang for 17 months. * 1990: Elected State Assemblyman for Padang Kota, Penang (1990 -1995). * 1999: Lost the election; ** Elected Chairman of DAP. * 2004: Elected Member of Parliament for Ipoh Timur, led the opposition in parliament; ** Led the party's parliamentary caucus in the newly created position of Chairman of the Central Policy and Strategic Planning Commission. * 2008: Incumbent and re-elected as Member of Parliament for Ipoh Timur ** Post of Leader of Opposition succeeded by Datuk Seri Wan Azizah Wan Ismail * 2013: Contested in Gelang Patah Parliament Seat against [[List of Menteris Besar of Johor|Menteri Besar of Johor]] [[Abdul Ghani Othman]], and won. }} ==Books published== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| # Time Bombs in Malaysia (1978) # DAP and Labour Issues (1978) # Malaysia in the Dangerous 80s (1982) # Constitutional Crisis in Malaysia (1983) # This Day in the Last 18 Months (1983) # The BMF Scandal (1984) # [[Harris Salleh]] – Politics & [[Morality]] (1984) # [[Human rights]] In Malaysia (1985) # Malaysia – Crisis of Identity (1986) # BMF – The [[Scandal]] Of Scandals (1986) # The North-South Highway Scandal (1987) # Prelude To Operation Lalang (1990) # The Dirtiest [[Elections in Malaysia|General Elections]] In The History of Malaysia (1991) # Selected Speeches & Press Statements – Vol. I (1991) # [[Samy Vellu]] and MAIKA Scandal (1992) # Battle For Democracy (1992) # Vijandran [[Pornographic movie|Pornographic]] [[Videotape]] Scandal II (1992) # The Bank Negara RM30 Billion [[Foreign exchange market|Forex]] Losses Scandal (1994) # The Highland Tower Tragedy (1994) # Pendedahan Skandal Kewangan – Siapa Petualang FELCRA? (1994) # Land Acquisition Act – Abuses, Injustices, Reform (1994) # I.T. For All (1997) # [[Cyber law|Cyberlaws]] in Malaysia (1997) # Economic & [[Currency crisis|Financial Crisis]] (1998) # Political & [[Economic system|Economic]] Crisis in Malaysia(1998) # The Budget That Was Never Passed (1999) # Constitutional Case of the Millennium (2000) # BA & [[Islam]]ic State (2001) # No To 929 (2002) # DAP (2004) }} ==Notes and references== ===Other references=== * Pillai, M.G.G. (1 November 2005). [https://web.archive.org/web/20071013161748/http://www.malaysia-today.net/columns/pillai/2005/11/did-lee-kuan-yew-want-singapore.htm "Did Lee Kuan Yew want Singapore ejected from Malaysia?"]. ''Malaysia Today''. ==External links== * [http://www.limkitsiang.com Official website] * [http://dapmalaysia.org Official Website for DAP Malaysia] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Asri Muda|Mohamed Asri Muda]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Malaysian Leaders of the Opposition|Leader of the Opposition of Malaysia]]|years=1973–1974}} {{s-aft|after=[[James Wong (politician)|James Wong]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Edmund Langgu Saga]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Malaysian Leaders of the Opposition|Leader of the Opposition of Malaysia]]|years=1975–1999}} {{s-aft|after=[[Fadzil Noor]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Abdul Hadi Awang]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Malaysian Leaders of the Opposition|Leader of the Opposition of Malaysia]]|years=2004–2008}} {{s-aft|after=[[Wan Azizah Wan Ismail]]}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Chen Man Hin]]}} {{s-ttl|title=National Chairman of the [[Democratic Action Party]]|years=1999–2004}} {{s-aft|after=[[Karpal Singh]]}} |- {{s-bef|before= [[Goh Hock Guan]]
[[Fan Yew Teng|Fan Yew Teng (acting)]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Secretary-General of the [[Democratic Action Party]]|years=1969–1999}} {{s-aft|after=[[Kerk Kim Hock]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=''Post created''}} {{s-ttl|title=Organising Secretary of the [[Democratic Action Party]]|years=1966–1969}} {{s-aft|after=[[Fan Yew Teng]]}} {{s-end}} {{Leaders of the Opposition (Malaysia)}} {{Johor-FedRep}} {{Authority control}} {{portal|Malaysia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lim, Kit Siang}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Batu Pahat]] [[Category:People from Johor]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Hokkien descent]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Malaysian lawyers]] [[Category:Malaysian politicians]] [[Category:Malaysian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Malaysia]] [[Category:Recipients of Malaysian royal pardons]] [[Category:Democratic socialists]] [[Category:Democratic Action Party (Malaysia) politicians]] [[Category:Malaysian Leaders of the Opposition]] [[Category:Members of the Dewan Rakyat]] [[Category:Members of the Malacca State Legislative Assembly]] [[Category:Members of the Penang State Legislative Assembly]] [[Category:Members of Lincoln's Inn]] [[Category:21st-century Malaysian politicians]] [[Category:21st-century Malaysian people]]

page.title: List of People of the Year Award winners

revision.text:
The '''Rehab [[People of the Year Awards]]''' is an annual awards ceremony in Ireland organised by [[The Rehab Group]], televised by [[RTÉ]] television.
The Awards are given to people who bring joy and light to the lives of others or have supported others in their darkest hours. These are individuals who have demonstrated their courage and energy in Ireland and throughout the world.<ref name="Award Categories">{{cite web|title=Award Categories |date=June 2013 |accessdate=14 September 2014 |url=http://www.peopleoftheyear.com/About-the-Awards/Categories.aspx |work=PeopleOfTheYear.com}}</ref> The nominees are chosen by members of the public. The winners are then chosen by a panel of adjudicators, composed of leading members of the media, voluntary sector and business community.
The Awards had for many years been held in December of each year.<ref name ="Twenty16"/> The 2018 edition, awarded for nominations made in 2017, was held in April, having been postponed from February due to [[beast from the east weather event|''Beast from the East'' weather event]].<ref name="Twenty18"/>
==Award categories==
* The International Person of the Year - awarded to an Irish person who has made an outstanding contribution on an international level, or to a person from outside Ireland who has made a positive impact to life on the island. * The Young Person of the Year - for exceptional achievements by a young person (aged 25 or under). * Sports Person of the Year * Community Group of the Year * People of the Year Awards <ref name="Award Categories"/>
===Complete list of winners===
==2010s== ===2018=== (for year 2017)<ref name="Twenty18IT">{{cite news |accessdate=16 April 2018 |date=15 April 2018 |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/tv-radio-web/people-of-the-year-awards-honour-ireland-s-2018-ledgebags-1.3462741 |title=People of the Year awards honour Irish ‘ledgebags’ of the year |first=Patrick |last=Freyne |work=[[The Irish Times]]}}</ref><ref name="Twenty18">{{cite news |date=15 April 2018 |archivedate=16 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180416060701/https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0415/954699-people-of-the-year/ |accessdate=16 April 2018 |website=[[RTÉ.ie]] |title=Coast Guard and Catherine Corless honoured at People Of The Year awards |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0415/954699-people-of-the-year/}}</ref> * Local historian [[Catherine Corless]], for her work in exposing the [[Bon Secours Mother and Baby Home#2012–14 reports|treatment of Women and the bodies of children at the Bon Secours Moher and Baby Home]], in [[Tuam]], County Galway * The community of [[Ballaghadereen]] for its welcoming response to the [[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian refugee crisis]] * Colette Byrne, Everyday Hero, for founding [http://widow.ie widow.ie], a website which helps people who have lost a spouse * [[Ifrah Ahmed]], International Person of the Year, founder of the [[Ifrah Foundation]], for her work in campaigning to end [[female genital mutilation]] * Harry and Molly Flynn, Young people of the Year, for saving the life of their little sister Isabelle during several apnea episodes * Fr. [[Peter McVerry]] S.J. (second time awardee), for a lifetime dedication to helping the homeless * Vera Twomey, for her campaign, including a 260 km walk to Dublin, to legalise [[medicinal cannabis]] on behalf of her daughter Ava who has [[Dravet syndrome]] * The [[Irish Coast Guard]], for the heroic work of the men and women who risk, and sometimes lose, their lives to assist maritime and coastal communities * The community of [[Erris]] for its support in the search and rescue operation following the [[2017 Irish Coast Guard Rescue 116 crash]] * [[Joy Neville]], Sports Person of The Year, Rugby referee and [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|grand slam]] winning rugby international * [[Galway Hurling Team]], Sports People of the Year, for winning the [[2018 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]]
===2016=== <ref name="Twenty16">{{cite web |deadurl=no |url=http://www.peopleoftheyear.com/Press/News/2016/Winners-of-2016-People-of-the-Year-Awards-announce.aspx |publisher=[[The Rehab Group]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161205091457/http://www.peopleoftheyear.com/Press/News/2016/Winners-of-2016-People-of-the-Year-Awards-announce.aspx |title=Winners of the 2016 People of the Year Awards Announced |date=4 December 2016 |accessdate=5 December 2016 |archivedate=5 December 2016}}</ref> * [[Robbie Keane]], International Person of the Year for "service leadership and passion" as [[captain]] of the [[Republic of Ireland national football team]] and charity ambassador * Davitt Walsh for rescuing an infant in the [[Buncrana#20th century|Buncrana tragedy]] * [[Paul O'Donovan|Paul]] and [[Gary O'Donovan]], and [[Annalise Murphy]], Sports Person of the Year (Joint), for their performances at the [[Ireland at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Rio Olympics]] * Alan Herdman, Young Person of the Year, for [[Rusheen Bay#2015 Incident|rescuing 8 children]] from drowning in [[Rusheen Bay]] * AMEN for its work in supporting male victims of [[domestic abuse]]. * Brother Kevin Crowley for running the Capuchin Day Centre for the homeless * [[John Muldoon (rugby player born 1982)|John Muldoon]] and [[Pat Lam]] for leading [[Connacht Rugby]] to its first [[Pro14|Pro12]] victory * Róisín and Mark Molloy, for highlighting [[Childbirth#Management|maternity service]] inequalities across the [[Health Service Executive|Irish health service]] * [[Ireland at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Ireland's Paralympic medallists]] for their performances at [[Ireland at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Rio 2016]]
===2015=== <ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151206105856/http://www.dublinnews.net/index.php/sid/239187223|url=http://www.dublinnews.net/index.php/sid/239187223 |title=Glittering ceremony as Irish People of Year receive awards |date=6 December 2015 |accessdate=6 December 2015 |archivedate=6 December 2015 |work= Dublin News}}</ref> * John Evoy of the [[men's shed#Health and wellbeing|Irish Men's Sheds Association]] for contributing to male mental health and wellbeing * Padraic Mangan and Aoibhean Godwin, Young People of the Year for founding [http://www.farmsafety4kids.net/ FarmSafety4Kids] * Philip Grant, Irish [[Consul (representative)|Consul]], California, and Fr. Brendan McBride, International People of the Year, for their efforts following the [[Berkeley balcony collapse]] * Fadhili Haji, of Sports Against Rascism Ireland and [[Football Against Racism in Europe]] for her work in encouraging Muslim girls to play football * Ade Stack and Marty Curley, for assisting parents and families of sick children, through the founding of Hugh's House, which provides accommodation near the [[Rotunda Hospital|Rotunda]] and [[Children's University Hospital, Temple Street|Temple Street Children's]] Hospitals * [[Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland#Political parties|Yes Equality]] ([[Gay and Lesbian Equality Network]], [[Irish Council for Civil Liberties]], Marriage Equality Ireland) for their campaign to [[Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|amend the Constitution]] * [[Paul O'Connell]], former [[Munster Rugby|Munster]] and [[Ireland national rugby union team|Irish]] [[Rugby union|rugby]] captain, Sports person of the Year * Ken Maleady, for saving a life by delivering [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] during the [[Dublin City Marathon]] * [[Irish Defence Forces|Óglaigh na hÉireann]] for the work of the [[Naval Service (Ireland)|Irish Naval Service]] in protecting life in the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] during the [[European migrant crisis]].
===2014=== <ref name ="Twenty14">{{cite web|title=Winners of the 2014 People of the Year Awards Announced |work=PeopleOfTheYear.com |date=December 2014 |accessdate=29 December 2014 |url=http://www.peopleoftheyear.com/Press/News/2014/Winners-of-the-2014-People-of-the-Year-Awards-Anno.aspx}}</ref> * [[Rory O'Neill]]/[[Panti]], People of the Year Award winner. For [[Panti#Comments about homophobia on RTÉ|his public contributions]] in fighting for equality and freedom of expression. * Paul Kelly, People of the Year Award winner. For his work with Console - a Suicide Prevention, Intervention and Postvention Service. * [[Maurice McCabe]] and [[John Wilson (Garda)|John Wilson]], People of the Year Award winners. For [[Garda whistleblower scandal|exposing irregularities]] in the work of the justice system. * [[Society of Saint Vincent de Paul#Ireland|The Society of Saint Vincent de Paul]], Community Group of the Year. For its work as a leader in the homeless and hunger charity sector. * Owen Condon, ''Every Day Hero'' Award, in association with the [[Nicky Byrne|Nicky Byrne Show with Jenny Greene]], [[RTÉ 2FM]]. For saving the life of a friend. * Adam Horgan, Joint Young Person of the Year Award. For rescuing two people from drowning near [[Youghal]], [[Co. Cork]]. * Shane Kennedy, Joint Young Person of the Year Award. For the care he gives to his younger brother who has [[Cri du chat]] syndrome. * Mary and Tony Heffernan, People of the Year Award winners. For their work with the Saoirse Foundation which helps children affected by [[Batten disease]], and the BUMBLEance, children's ambulance service. * [[Tomi Reichental]], International Person of the Year award 2014. For raising awareness of the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]], since his family moved to Ireland in the 1950s. * Louise O’Keeffe, People of the Year Award winner. For her struggle to expose the abuse she and others suffered during her school days in 1973.
===2013=== <ref>{{cite web |title=2013 People of the Year |url=http://www.peopleoftheyear.com/Inspirational-People/2013-People-of-the-Year.aspx |work=PeopleOfTheYear.com |date=September 2013 |accessdate=14 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911150302/http://www.peopleoftheyear.com/Inspirational-People/2013-People-of-the-Year.aspx |archivedate=11 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> * Fiona Doyle, People of the Year Award winner. For her courage, determination and bravery in fighting for her own rights and the rights of survivors of abuse. * Loretta Brennan Glucksman, International Person of the Year winner. In recognition of her tireless work, dedication and commitment, her extraordinary philanthropic efforts with [[the American Ireland Fund]] and her generosity of spirit. * [[Death of Adrian Donohoe|Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe]], Person of the Year Award winner. For his dedication in protecting the ordinary citizens of Ireland, and for his bravery and courage in the line of duty, Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe was posthumously awarded a People of the Year Award.. * Donal Walsh, Joint Young Person of the Year (posthumous). For his courage, strength, determination and desire to show young people the true value and meaning of life, and for being an inspiration to so many people, Donal Walsh was posthumously awarded a Young Person of the Year Award. * Fabian Lugandu, People of the Year Award. For his bravery and fearlessness when he came to the rescue of Liz O’Brien and her son Derek, and for his quick thinking and courage, which ensured that Liz and her son returned home safely that day, Fabian Lugandu was awarded a People of the Year Award. * Joe Prendergast, Joint Young Person of the Year. For his motivation, determination and successful achievements, Joe Prendergast was awarded the Young Person of the Year Award. * [[Ireland women's national rugby union team|Irish Women's Rugby Team]], Sports Person of the Year. For their skill, passion and dedication in achieving their success, for capturing the hearts of the nation and breaking down barriers for women's sport in Ireland, the Ireland women's rugby team received a People of the Year Award. * Orla O'Sullivan, People of the Year Award. For her determination, her incredible talent and for acting as an inspiration for others with a disability to follow their dreams, Orla O’Sullivan was awarded a People of the Year Award. * [[Tom Arnold (economist)|Tom Arnold]]. People of the Year Award. For his commitment and energy as a leading and tireless advocate in the fight against hunger and malnutrition across the world Tom Arnold was presented with a People of the Year Award. * Ciarán Finn, Dad of the Year (in association with 2fm's Breakfast with Hector). For being a dedicated dad who goes above and beyond for his children, for teaching skills in a novel and fun way and for being an inspiration to those around him, Ciarán Finn received the Dad of the Year Award in association with [[RTÉ 2fm|2fm's]] [[Breakfast with Hector]]. * [[Brendan O'Carroll]], People of the Year Award. For his services to the Irish entertainment industry and his ability to bring a smile to the faces of so many people, Brendan O’Carroll was awarded a People of the Year Award.
===2012=== * Gill Waters, People of the Year Award winner, for her innovation in pioneering [[Today FM]]'s [[Shave or Dye]] Campaign for the [[Irish Cancer Society]] and for creating vital public dialogue around cancer. * Adventurer [[Mark Pollock]], People of the Year Award winner, for his determination in overcoming significant physical adversity and constantly pushing out new boundaries as an explorer and adventure racer. * Maeve Flaherty, from Ballinteer in Dublin, winner of the 2012 special award category Neighbour of the Year, for her fantastic neighbourly spirit and selflessness in supporting people in difficulty. The award was presented in association with RTÉ 2fm's [[Tubridy (radio show)|Tubridy]]. * [[Katie Taylor]], Sports Person of the Year, for her outstanding sporting achievements, most recently as an Olympic Gold medallist, and for being a proud ambassador for Ireland [[Amateur Boxing|Boxer]]. * [[Tony Scott (physicist)|Dr. Tony Scott]], of [[University College Dublin]], People of the Year Award winner, for his immense contribution to the field of science in Ireland and co-founding of what is today known as the [[Young Scientist]] Exhibition. * The people of [[Union Hall, County Cork]], winner of Community Group of the Year, for its outstanding community spirit and unshakeable resolve in efforts to find five fishermen lost at sea on the [[List of shipwrecks in 2012#16 January|Tit Bonhomme]] near [[Glandore|Glandore Harbour]]. * [[Joanne O'Riordan]], Young Person of the Year, for her determination in highlighting the challenges faced by people with disabilities today. * The late [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] Ciarán Jones, posthumous winner of a People of the Year Award, for the enormous bravery, heroism and selflessness shown by him in losing his life in trying to protect others in the floods of winter 2011 in [[Manor Kilbride]] County Wicklow. * Cork Penny Dinners, People of the Year Award winner, for providing food and warmth to those in need in [[Cork (city)|Cork]] for over 100 years. * Broadcaster [[Colm Murray]] People of the Year Award winner, for his courageous response to a diagnosis of [[Motor Neuron Disease]], and his inspirational efforts in speaking out about the condition and the need for a cure. * The [[Ireland at the 2012 Summer Paralympics|2012 Irish Paralympic Team]] People of the Year Award winner, for its inspiring sporting achievements at the London 2012 Paralympic Games and a record haul of 16 medals.
===2011=== * [[Rory McIlroy]], named Sports Person of the Year, for winning the [[2011 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open Golf Championship in June 2011]] becoming its youngest winner since 1923, and tying or breaking 12 Open records. * The [[Ireland cricket team]] for [[2011 Cricket World Cup Group B#England vs Ireland|winning a match]] against [[England cricket team|England]] at the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]] * Police Constable [[Ronan Kerr]] (age 25), (posthumously) for his service in the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland|PSNI]], having been killed by a bomb in [[Omagh]] in April 2011 * Sharon Malloy, from Co. Laois, named Best Friend of the Year in a special award for 2011, for her support to a friend battling drug addiction * The community of [[Skerries, Dublin|Skerries]] in North Co. Dublin, named Community of the Year for its extraordinary solidarity in the search for two men who went missing at sea in April 2011 * Edith Wilkins, named International Person of the Year for her compassion and unfaltering commitment to improving the lives of the people of India, and for providing a safe haven to the most vulnerable in society * [[Joan Freeman (politician)|Joan Freeman]] for her work in establishing Pieta House, the only service of its kind in Ireland to provide counselling and support for those who are actively suicidal, are contemplating suicide, or who self-harm * Jackie Kelly (18 years), from Co. Tipperary, named Young Person of the Year for being a positive role model in supporting her mum who had been diagnosed with cancer and for her determination to pass her Leaving Cert * AJ McCullough (21 years) for his heroic efforts in his brave and courageous rescue of the Attah family when their car plunged into the Boyne Canal in Drogheda in December 2010 * The [[Tall Ships' Races|Tall Ships Festival]] Waterford 2011 for the enormous voluntary and community effort which led to a hugely successful festival, with more than 500 volunteers providing support
===2010=== *Owen O'Keefe *[[Catherine McGuinness]] *Dr. Louise Ivers and Gena Heraty *The families of victims of [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday]] *Emma Fogarty *Rio Hogarty *[[Graeme McDowell]] *[[Limerick]]'s [[Garda Síochána]]'s Community Policing Unit *[[Gerry Ryan]]
==2000s==
===2009=== * Bernadette Lanigan * Sarah Kavanagh * Debbie Deegan * The [[Irish Rugby]] Team<ref name="Collins09"/> * Brian O’Driscoll<ref name="Collins09"/> * Steve Collins<!-- Not the boxer [[Steve Collins]] -->, father of gang-victim [[List of major crimes in Ireland|Roy Collins]], for working to end gang violence in Limerick<ref name="Collins09">{{cite web |title=We Have Campaigned Enough, We Can Take a Step Back and Get Back to Normal; PEOPLE OF THE YEAR AWARD FOR GANG VICTIM'S DAD |url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-207761279/we-have-campaigned-enough-we-can-take-a-step-back |publisher=[[Irish Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=25 October 2014| date= 14 September 2009 }} {{Subscription required |via=[[Questia]]}}</ref> * [[Christine Buckley]] * Michael O’Brien * David Kelly<ref name="Collins09"/> * Eleanor Thomson * [[Sylvia Meehan]] * Irish Hospice Foundation

page.title: List of Queensland Australian of the Year award recipients

revision.text:
The '''Queensland Australian of the Year Award''' is given annually on [[Australia Day]]. The announcement of the award has become a major public event in Australia, and is televised nationwide. The award "offers an insight into Australian identity, reflecting the nation's evolving relationship with world, the role of sport in Australian culture, the impact of multiculturalism, and the special status of Australia's Indigenous people".http://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/the-awards/awards-history/ The national level awards, four in total, are chosen exclusively from the state and territory award recipients. The following is a list of the recipients of the Queensland [[Australian of the Year]] award.[https://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/honour-roll/?view=landing&year=2019 Queensland Australian of the Year - Honour Roll] {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year of
award ! Name ! Post
nominals ! Born ! Died ! Comments |- | 2004 | {{sortname|Steve|Irwin}} | | 1962 | 2006 | Naturalist, zoologist, conservationist. |- | 2005 | {{sortname|Bill|Bristow}} | | | | Humanitarian. |- | 2006 | Professor {{sortname|Ian|Frazer}} | | 1953 | | Clinical Immunologist and Inventor of the Cervical Cancer Vaccine |- | 2007 | {{sortname|David|Conry}} | | | | YoungCare founder |- | 2008 | {{sortname|Lee|Kernaghan}} | {{post-nominals|country=AUS|sep=,|OAM}} | 1964 | | Country Music Legend |- | 2009 | {{sortname|Bronwyn|Sheehan}} | | | | Literacy advocate |- | 2010 | Dr {{sortname|Chris|Sarra}} | | | | Indigenous educator |- | 2011 | Professor {{sortname|Noel|Hayman}} | | | | Doctor |- | 2012 | {{sortname|Bruce|Morcombe}}
{{sortname|Denise|Morcombe}} | | | | Child protection advocates |- | 2013 | Professor {{sortname|Adele|Green}} | {{post-nominals|country=AUS|sep=,|AC}} | 1952 | | Cancer researcher |- | 2014 | {{sortname|Li|Cunxin}} | | 1961 | | Ballet Director |- | 2015 | {{sortname|Hetty|Johnston}} | {{post-nominals|country=AUS|sep=,|AM}} | 1958 | | Child protection activist |- | 2016 | Group Captain {{sortname|Catherine|McGregor}} | {{post-nominals|country=AUS|sep=,|AM}} | 1956 | | Distinguished RAAF officer |- | 2017 | {{sortname|Alan|Mackay-Sim}} | | 1951 | | Biomedical scientist treating spinal cord injuries |- | 2018 | {{sortname|Johnathan|Thurston}} | | 1983 | | NRL player and indigenous mentor |- | 2019 | Detective Inspector {{sortname|Jon|Rouse}} | | | | Distinguished Child protection Police Officer |} ==See also== * [[List of Senior Australian of the Year Award recipients]] * [[List of Young Australian of the Year Award recipients]] * [[List of Australian Local Hero Award recipients]] * [[List of South Australian of the Year Award recipients]] * [[List of New South Wales Australian of the Year award recipients]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Lists of award winners|Queenslanders]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Portuguese name|Silva|Vaz de Lima}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Marina Silva |image = Marina Silva crop.jpg |office = Spokesperson of the [[Sustainability Network]] |alongside = [[Zé Gustavo]] |term_start = 22 September 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = ''Position established'' |successor = |office1 = [[Federal Senate|Senator]] for [[Acre (state)|Acre]] |term_start1 = 13 May 2008 |term_end1 = 1 February 2011 |term_start2 = 1 February 1995 |term_end2 = 1 January 2003 |office3 = [[Ministry of the Environment (Brazil)|Minister of the Environment]] |president3 = [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] |term_start3 = 1 January 2003 |term_end3 = 13 May 2008 |predecessor3 = José Carlos Carvalho |successor3 = [[Carlos Minc]] |office4 = [[Legislative Assemblies of Brazilian states|State Deputy of Acre]] |term_start4 = 1 February 1991 |term_end4 = 1 February 1995 |office5 = Councillor of [[Rio Branco, Acre|Rio Branco]] |term_start5 = 1 January 1989 |term_end5 = 1 February 1991 |birth_name = Maria Osmarina da Silva |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|2|8|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Rio Branco, Acre|Rio Branco]], [[Acre (state)|Acre]], [[Brazil]] |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = {{marriage|Fábio Vaz de Lima|1986}} |children = 4 |party = [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|PT]] {{small|(1986–2009)}}
[[Green Party (Brazil)|PV]] {{small|(2009–2011)}}
[[Independent politician|Independent]] {{small|(2011–2013)}}
[[Brazilian Socialist Party|PSB]] {{small|(2013–2015)}}
[[Sustainability Network|REDE]] {{small|(2015–present)}} |alma_mater = [[Federal University of Acre]] }} '''Maria Osmarina Marina Silva Vaz de Lima'''{{cite web|url=http://www.senado.gov.br/senadores/dinamico/paginst/senador59a.asp|title=Home - Senado Federal|website=www.senado.gov.br|accessdate=3 September 2018}} (born 8 February 1958) is a Brazilian politician and environmentalist. She is currently the spokeswoman for the [[Sustainability Network|Sustainability Party]] (REDE). During her political career, Silva served as a Senator of the state of [[Acre (state)|Acre]] between 1995 and 2011 and Minister of the Environment from 2003 to 2008. She ran for president in 2010, 2014 and 2018. Born in a rubber plantation in [[Acre (state)|Acre]], Marina moved to the state capital [[Rio Branco, Acre|Rio Branco]] as a teenager, where she became literate. After graduating high school, she completed her undergraduate degree in History from the [[Federal University of Acre]] at 26. She developed an interest in politics and joined the Communist Revolutionary Party, a Marxist organization that was housed in the [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|Workers Party (PT)]], later helping to found the Central Workers' Union of Acre. She helped [[Chico Mendes]] to lead the trade union movement, being elected as councillor of Rio Branco in 1988 for her first mandate in a public office. Silva was a member of the [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|PT]] until 2009, and served as a Senator before becoming Minister of the Environment in 2003. She ran for president in the [[Brazilian presidential election, 2010|2010 Brazilian elections]] as the candidate for the [[Green Party (Brazil)|Green Party (PV)]], coming in 3rd with 19% of the first-round vote.{{cite web|url=http://placar.eleicoes.uol.com.br/2010/1turno/|title=Eleições 2010 – Apuração|publisher=uol.com.br|language=Portuguese|year=2010|accessdate=2013-06-03}} In April 2014, [[Eduardo Campos]] announced his candidacy for the fall [[Brazilian general election, 2014|2014 presidential election]], naming Marina Silva as his vice presidential candidate.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-27029256|title=Campos-Silva in Brazil 2014 election|date=14 April 2014|publisher=|accessdate=3 September 2018|via=www.bbc.com}} After Campos's death in a plane crash on August, she was selected to run as the [[Brazilian Socialist Party|Socialist Party]]'s candidate for the Presidency.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/14/marina-silva-obvious-successor-after-campos-death|title=Marina Silva emerges as obvious successor after Campos death|work=[[The Guardian]]|author=Jonathan Watts|date=14 August 2014|accessdate=16 August 2014}} In the first round of the October 2014 election, she won 21% of the vote (less than many of the opinion polls had predicted), coming in 3rd and failing to advance to the run-off.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-29501500|title=Brazil election: Dilma Rousseff to face Aecio Neves in run-off|editor=BBC|date=6 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014}} In the second round, she supported [[PSDB]] candidate [[Aécio Neves]] over [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|PT]] incumbent [[Dilma Rousseff]]. She is running for president again in the [[Brazilian general election, 2018|2018 election]], this time under the Sustainability Network. Silva has won a number of awards from US and international organizations in recognition of her environmental activism. In 1996, Silva won the [[Goldman Environmental Prize]] for South & Central America.{{Cite news|url=http://www.goldmanprize.org/recipient/marina-silva/|title=Marina Silva - Goldman Environmental Foundation|work=Goldman Environmental Foundation|access-date=2017-09-19|language=en-US}} In 2007, the United Nations Environment Program named her one of the [[Champions of the Earth]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.unep.org/championsofearth/laureates/2007/he-marina-silva|title=H.E Marina Silva {{!}} Champions of the Earth|website=www.unep.org|access-date=2017-09-19}} and the 2009 [[Sophie Prize]].{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-environment-prize/brazilian-forest-conservationist-silva-wins-norway-prize-idUKTRE5305MJ20090401|title=Brazilian forest conservationist Silva wins Norway prize|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.K.|access-date=2017-09-19|language=en-GB}} In December 2014, Marina Silva was elected by the British ''[[Financial Times]]'' newspaper as one of its ''Women of the Year''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/57610270-7f9c-11e4-adff-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3LnyrLN1v|title=Women of 2014: Marina Silva, presidential candidate|date=12 December 2014}} Silva is also a member of [[Washington, D.C.]]-based think tank, the [[Inter-American Dialogue]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedialogue.org/experts/marina-silva/|title=Inter-American Dialogue {{!}} Marina Silva|website=www.thedialogue.org|access-date=2017-04-19}} In 2010, she, along with [[Cécile Duflot]], [[Monica Frassoni]], [[Elizabeth May]] and [[Renate Künast]], were named by ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' magazine to its list of top global thinkers,[https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2010/11/29/the_fp_top_100_global_thinkers?page=0,30 Top 100] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018134430/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2010/11/29/the_fp_top_100_global_thinkers?page=0,30|date=18 October 2014}} for taking [[Green politics|Green]] mainstream. In 2012 she was one of eight people chosen to carry the flag for the opening ceremonies of the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London Olympic Games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/media/press/2012/liberty-director-carries-the-olympic-flag-in-opening-cer.php|title=Liberty Director carries the Olympic Flag in opening ceremony|date=27 July 2012}} == Early life == [[File:Marina Silva em Xapuri 02.jpg|thumb|left|Marina Silva in [[Xapuri]], Acre]] [[File:Marina Silva em Xapuri 01.jpg|thumb|left|Silva in [[Amazon rainforest]], Acre]] Marina Silva was born '''Maria Osmarina da Silva''' in the small village of Breu Velho, 70 km outside [[Rio Branco, Acre]]. Silva is a descendant of [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] and [[Black people|black African]] ancestors in both her maternal and paternal lines.[http://revistaepoca.globo.com/Revista/Epoca/0,,EMI88634-15223,00.html Marina Silva deixa o PT] {{pt icon}} She was one of eleven children in a community of [[Rubber tapping|rubber tappers]] on the ''Bagaço'' rubber tree plantation ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''Seringal Bagaço''), in the western state of [[Acre (state)|Acre]]. Growing up, she survived five bouts of malaria in addition to cases of hepatitis and metal poisoning.{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3149004/the-green-activist-who-might-become-brazils-next-president/ |title=The Green Activist Who Might Become Brazil's Next President |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=20 August 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-24}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ea83371c-26b4-11e4-bc19-00144feabdc0|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|accessdate=3 September 2018}} Orphaned at age 16, young Marina moved to the state capital, Rio Branco, to study and receive treatment for hepatitis. She was taken in by nuns in a convent and received a Catholic education. There, she became the first person in her family to learn to read and write. After leaving the convent, she went to work as a housemaid in exchange for lodging.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-28865958|title=Tragedy puts Marina Silva at heart of Brazil campaign|first=Julia|last=Carneiro|date=21 August 2014|publisher=|accessdate=3 September 2018|via=www.bbc.com}} She completed her undergraduate degree in History from the [[Federal University of Acre]] at 26 and became increasingly politically active. In 1984 Silva helped create Acre's first workers' union.{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Tom |url=http://www.chinadialogue.net/article/summary/2115--I-d-lost-the-strength-to-carry-on- |title=I'd lost the strength to carry on |publisher=[[chinadialogue]] |date=20 June 2008 |accessdate=2008-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005181454/http://www.chinadialogue.net/article/summary/2115--I-d-lost-the-strength-to-carry-on- |archivedate=5 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} She led demonstrations called ''empates'' with [[Chico Mendes]] to warn against [[deforestation]] and the outplacement of forest communities from their traditional locations.{{cite news|url=http://www.goldmanprize.org/node/162 |title=Marina Silva |publisher=The Goldman Environmental Prize |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821103758/http://goldmanprize.org/node/162 |archivedate=21 August 2008 |df= }} == Silva as a Senator == In 1994, Ms. Silva was the first rubber tapper ever elected to the [[Senate of Brazil|Federal Senate]]. As a native Amazonian and a senator, she built support for environmental protection of the reserves as well as for social justice and [[sustainable development]] in the [[Amazon region]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goldmanprize.org/node/162 |title=Marina Silva |accessdate=2008-08-08 |publisher=The Goldman Environmental Prize |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821103758/http://goldmanprize.org/node/162 |archivedate=21 August 2008 |df= }} Deforestation decreased by 59% from 2004 to 2007, during which she implemented an integrated government policy. It simultaneously fostered sustainable development, favored territorial zoning, and attached greater value to standing forests. It also incorporated elements from international conventions and documents.{{cite web |url=http://www.brazil.org.uk/environment/deforestation.html |title=Fall in Amazon deforestation rates (2004–2007) |accessdate=2008-08-08 |publisher=Embassy of Brazil in London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006034747/http://www.brazil.org.uk/environment/deforestation.html |archivedate=6 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} "All of this demonstrates that, when there is integrated planning and effort, it is truly possible to change the picture," Silva said in a statement to the Embassy of Brazil in London. == Lula's minister == A member of the [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|Workers' Party]], Marina Silva was appointed Environment Minister by [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Lula]] in his first term (2003). She remained in office until 2008 and received several criticisms from entrepreneurs (mainly related to [[agribusiness]]) on account of delays in granting permits for projects with large environmental impact. In early 2005, however, she stated that she would not give up upon facing challenges even if imposed by the government to which she belonged, like the controversy over the [[São Francisco River|São Francisco River Diversion Project]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/8575010.stm|title=Brazil's huge river diversion project divides opinion|author=Henry Mance|publisher=BBC News|date=12 April 2010|accessdate=2010-07-02}} and the building of the BR-163 highway through the [[rainforest]]: "I don't admit defeat, just challenges that must be overcome".{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsterraviva.net/tv/wsf2005/viewstory.asp?idnews=146|title=ENVIRONMENT – THE FRAGILE BALANCE OF A MINISTRY|last=Wodianer Marcondes|first=Adalberto|publisher=[[Inter Press Service]]|date=29 January 2005|accessdate=2010-07-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713170317/http://www.ipsterraviva.net/TV/WSF2005/viewstory.asp?idnews=146|archivedate=13 July 2010|df=dmy-all}} Also in 2005, Silva established her main lines of action for the next two years: social participation, [[sustainable development]], creation of a National Environmental System, and an Integrated Environmental Policy. As she said, "Our ministry is new. It's only 13 years old, and it needs to be rebuilt". In the same year, Silva was confronted by Paulo Adário, coordinator of [[Greenpeace]] Brazil, over her environmental actions during her tenure in the ministry. Ever since her tenure began, Ms. Silva, together with the [[Federal Police (Brazil)|Federal Police]], the [[Brazilian Army]] and the [[Federal Highway Police]], performed 32 operations against illegal [[deforestation of the Amazon rainforest|deforestation in the Amazon]]. But Adário claims that his organization monitors the Amazon region and that only one such operation was conducted in October 2004, in the town of [[Itaituba]], Pará. According to him, even if the 32 operations had actually been carried out, it would represent only half of what was anticipated in the National Plan to Combat Deforestation. == Resignation == Silva resigned from the Lula government in May 2008. She was replaced by [[Carlos Minc]].{{cite news |last=Barrionuevo |first=Alexei |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/16/world/americas/16brazil.html?ref=world |title='Stagnation' Made Brazil's Environment Chief Resign |work=New York Times |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08}} Silva cited "the growing resistance found by our team in important sectors of the government and society" as the reason for her resignation. Tension between her and the rest of the Lula administration increased when President [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Lula da Silva]] chose Minister of Strategic Affairs [[Roberto Mangabeira Unger]] to coordinate a sustainable development plan for the Amazon, instead of her. She had become increasingly isolated in [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Lula da Silva]]'s government due to her views against hydroelectric dams, [[biofuels]], and genetically modified crops. == Party switch and 2010 presidential bid == [[File:Lovejoy, Silva, and Schneider.jpg|thumb|alt=Waist high portrait of three middle aged people in the library of what could be a boat or other confined space.|Silva (center) with [[Thomas Lovejoy]] and [[Stephen Schneider]]]] On 19 August 2009, Silva announced her switch from the [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|Workers' Party]] to the [[Green Party (Brazil)|Green Party]], primarily in protest against the environmental policies endorsed by the [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|PT]]. Confirming the expectations,{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8211549.stm|title=Amazon activist eyes election bid|date=20 August 2009|publisher=|accessdate=3 September 2018|via=news.bbc.co.uk}} Marina Silva launched her candidacy{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/10/03/brazilian-presidential-profile-marina-silva/|title=Brazilian presidential profile: Marina Silva|date=3 October 2010|publisher=|accessdate=3 September 2018}} to the [[Brazilian presidential election, 2010|2010 election]] under the Green Party ticket on 16 May 2010 in the city of Nova Iguaçu, [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|state of Rio de Janeiro]]. Silva said she wanted to be "the first black woman of poor origin" to become president of Brazil.[http://www.abril.com.br/noticias/brasil/marina-silva-diz-querer-ser-primeira-mulher-negra-ser-presidente-568637.shtml Marina Silva diz querer ser primeira mulher negra a ser presidente] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716023826/http://www.abril.com.br/noticias/brasil/marina-silva-diz-querer-ser-primeira-mulher-negra-ser-presidente-568637.shtml |date=16 July 2011 }} {{pt icon}} She has also become a Pentecostal Christian{{cite web |last1=Castro |first1=Nazaret |title=The rising political power of Evangelicals in Latin America |url=https://www.equaltimes.org/the-rising-political-power-of#.W5GWKvZFxPY |website=Equal Times |accessdate=6 September 2018 |language=en}}{{cite web |last1=Blair |first1=Leonardo |title=Devout Evangelical Christian Marina Silva Started Life Illiterate in the Amazon; Now She's Primed to Become Brazil's First Black President |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/devout-evangelical-christian-marina-silva-started-life-illiterate-in-the-amazon-now-shes-primed-to-become-brazils-first-black-president-125539/ |website=The Christian Post |publisher=The Christian Post, INC |accessdate=6 September 2018 |language=en-US |date=August 28, 2014}} in the [[Assemblies of God]], the second largest Christian denomination in Brazil after the declining but still mainstream [[Roman Catholic Church]].{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/evangelical-population-explodes-in-brazil-as-catholic-church-shows-signs-of-decline-77470/|title=Evangelical Population Explodes in Brazil as Catholic Church Shows Signs of Decline|editor=CP World|author=Andrea Madambashi|date=1 July 2012|accessdate=2012-09-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pulsamerica.co.uk/2012/07/02/brazil-catholic-church-on-the-decline/|title=Brazil: Catholic Church on the decline|editor=Pulsamerica|author=Benjamin Ahnert|date=2 July 2012|accessdate=2012-09-05}} Nevertheless, during her election campaign, she was criticized by one of the main leaders of the Brazilian [[Assemblies of God]], Pastor [[Silas Malafaia]], after having proposed a [[referendum]] on abortion and [[Legality of cannabis|decriminalization of marijuana]]. According to Malafaia, Marina Silva should be "more courageous and consistent" in defense of her religious convictions.{{cite web|url=http://www.sidneyrezende.com/noticia/102263|title=Pastor Silas Malafaia critica Marina Silva e vira destaque no Twitter|language=Portuguese|date=28 September 2010|accessdate=2012-08-01}} [[File:SBT Brasil, Carlos Nascimento, Marina Silva, Karyn Bravo.jpg|thumb|left|Silva on [[Sistema Brasileiro de Televisão|SBT]]]] In her campaign, Silva defended the "exercise of citizen-based political principles and values", "education for the knowledge society", "economy applied to a sustainable society", "social protection, health, welfare and 3rd generation of social programs", "[[quality of life]] and safety for all Brazilians", and "strengthening of culture and diversity".{{cite web|url=http://www.minhamarina.org.br/home/home_campanha.php|title=Marina Silva – Official Site|language=Portuguese|accessdate=2012-08-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728202331/http://www.minhamarina.org.br/home/home_campanha.php|archivedate=28 July 2012|df=dmy-all}} With her speech against the endemic corruption in Brazil (see ''[[A Privataria Tucana]]'' and ''[[Mensalão scandal]]''), and in favor of sustainable development (with a due consideration to environmental issues), Silva managed to attract the middle class sectors disillusioned with the government of the [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]]'s [[Partido da Social Democracia Brasileira|PSDB]] and dissatisfied with the compensatory social policies of Lula da Silva's administration. As a result, she came to be seen as an alternative.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifch.unicamp.br/formulario_cemarx/selecao/2012/trabalhos/7355_Maciel_David.pdf|title=De Lula à Dilma Roussef: crise econômica, hegemonia neoliberal e regressão política|author=David Maciel|format=PDF|language=Portuguese|accessdate=2012-08-01}} Marina Silva received strong support among young and highly educated voters. Running on a small party ticket, she had about 1/20th of the TV time compared to the other two biggest party coalitions. Opinion polls notwithstanding, she received 19.4% of the votes cast.[http://colunistas.ig.com.br/guilhermebarros/2010/09/28/marina-silva-surpreende-na-reta-final-e-pode-gerar-segundo-turno-diz-instituto-analise/ ''Marina surpreende e pode chegar ao segundo turno''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101003225834/http://colunistas.ig.com.br/guilhermebarros/2010/09/28/marina-silva-surpreende-na-reta-final-e-pode-gerar-segundo-turno-diz-instituto-analise/ |date=3 October 2010 }} {{pt icon}} This number far exceeded earlier estimates (more than double), but not enough to join the runoff against [[Dilma Rousseff]] or [[José Serra]].[http://www.diariodepernambuco.com.br/politica/nota.asp?materia=20101004094807&assunto=27&onde=Curinga ''Dilma e Serra Disputarão Segundo Turno no Dia 31 de Outubro''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706152506/http://www.diariodepernambuco.com.br/politica/nota.asp?materia=20101004094807&assunto=27&onde=Curinga |date=6 July 2011 }} {{pt icon}} == Silva in London 2012 Olympics == The participation of Marina Silva as one of the eight invited [[flag-bearer]]s to carry the [[Olympic flag]] at the opening of the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London Summer Games 2012]], took by surprise the [[Brazilian government]] representatives present at the ceremony.{{cite web|url=http://jconline.ne10.uol.com.br/canal/londres-2012/noticia/2012/07/28/marina-silva-causa-mal-estar-entre-ministros-em-londres-50735.php|title=Marina Silva causa mal estar entre ministros em Londres|language=Portuguese|editor=jconline.com.br|date=28 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111223000/http://jconline.ne10.uol.com.br/canal/londres-2012/noticia/2012/07/28/marina-silva-causa-mal-estar-entre-ministros-em-londres-50735.php|archive-date=11 November 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/9437285/London-2012-Olympics-Brazilians-caught-up-in-right-royal-kerfuffle-over-Danny-Boyles-opening-ceremony.html|title=London 2012 Olympics: Brazilians caught up in right royal kerfuffle over Danny Boyle's opening ceremony|editor=telegraph.co.uk|author=Jacquelin Magnay|date=29 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-2180781/London-2012-Olympics-Brazilian-government-angered-flagbearer.html|title=Brazilian government angered as Amazon campaigner carries flag at opening ceremony|editor=dailymail.co.uk|date=29 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18}} In the Brazilian press headlines like "Marina steals [[Dilma Rousseff|Dilma]]'s attention" appeared.{{cite web|url=http://oglobo.globo.com/pais/noblat/posts/2012/07/28/jornal-das-olimpiadas-marina-silva-rouba-cena-de-dilma-457538.asp|title=Jornal das Olimpíadas – Marina Silva rouba a cena de Dilma|editor=[[O Globo]]|language=Portuguese|date=28 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18}}{{cite web|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/blog/politica/olimpiada-2012/marina-silva-sera-homenageada-na-abertura-da-olimpiada/|title=Marina Silva será homenageada na abertura da Olimpíada|editor=[[Veja (magazine)|Veja]]|language=Portuguese|date=27 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801230101/http://veja.abril.com.br/blog/politica/olimpiada-2012/marina-silva-sera-homenageada-na-abertura-da-olimpiada/|archivedate=1 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} Commenting on the event, [[Aldo Rebelo]], Brazilian Sports Minister from the PT, which realised it would likely lose votes to Marina in a presidential contest, said that Silva "always had good relations with the [[European aristocracy]]" and that it was the responsibility of the [[House of Windsor|Royal House]] to choose who would participate in the event. The [[International Olympic Committee|Olympic Committee]] said it was aware of Silva's work as an activist in defense of the [[rainforest]], but denied any political motivations regarding the choice.{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/olympic-organizers-defend-choice-flagbearer-185513168--oly.html|title=Olympic organizers defend choice of flagbearer|editor=sports.yahoo.com|date=29 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18}} About her participation in the ceremony, Silva compared it to the feeling she got when passing, aged 16, her [[Literacy|literacy course]]: "it was the same kind of happiness."{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/portuguese/videos_e_fotos/2012/07/120728_olympics_marina_pai.shtml|title=Marina Silva compara Olimpíada à emoção de ter sido alfabetizada|editor=bbc.co.uk|author=Paula Adamo Idoeta|language=Portuguese|date=28 July 2012|accessdate=2012-08-18}} == Sustainability Network == On 16 February 2013 a new party, ''Rede Sustentabilidade'' ("Sustainability Network"), was officially launched in Brasilia.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21487993|title=Brazil's Marina Silva launches 'sustainability party'|editor=[[BBC News]]|date=16 February 2013|accessdate=2013-02-20}} According to its founders, the name to be used at the polls would be simply REDE ("NETWORK").{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/politica/noticia/2013/02/novo-partido-de-marina-silva-vai-se-chamar-rede-sustentabilidade.html|title=Novo partido de Marina Silva vai se chamar Rede Sustentabilidade|author=Iara Lemos|editor=[[O Globo]]|language=Portuguese|date=16 February 2013|accessdate=2013-02-20}} On 4 October 2013, the [[Supreme Electoral Court]] blocked the party's creation, there being insufficient signatures to register it.{{cite web|author1=Bragon, Ranier |author2=Falcão, Márcio |title=Electoral Court Blocks Marina Silva's Party|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/internacional/en/brazil/2013/10/1351715-electoral-court-blocks-marina-silvas-presidential-bid.shtml|accessdate= 6 October 2013}} The following day, Marina announced her affiliation to the [[Brazilian Socialist Party]].{{cite web|title=Brazil's Marina Silva and Socialists eye 2014 elections.|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-24416480|accessdate=6 October 2013}} == 2014 presidential bid == [[File:Marina Silva e Eduardo Campos 2013.JPG|thumb|180px|With [[Eduardo Campos]].]] In April 2014, [[Eduardo Campos]] announced his name for the [[Brazilian general election, 2014|October 2014 presidential election]], naming Marina Silva as his candidate for vice president. On Wednesday, 13 August 2014, Campos' private jet, with six others on board, crashed in bad weather as it was preparing to land in the coastal city of [[Santos, Brazil|Santos]], just south of [[São Paulo]]. After his death, Silva{{cite web|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/brazil-party-chooses-marina-silva-as-presidential-candidate-1408235460|title=Brazil Party Chooses Marina Silva as Presidential Candidate|editor=WSJ|date=16 August 2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}} became the Brazilian Socialist Party's candidate for President of Brazil.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-28822676|title=Brazil: Marina Silva 'to replace' late candidate Campos|publisher=BBC|date=16 August 2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/08/16/uk-brazil-election-silva-idUKKBN0GG09X20140816|title=Brazil party plans to launch Marina Silva presidential bid|editor=Reuters|date=16 August 2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}} Soon after taking the place of Campos in the bid, Marina polled 20% of the votes, 10% more than Campos was polling. She enjoys strong support among young voters and evangelicals, but because of her pro-environmental stance she is largely distrusted by Brazil's powerful agribusiness sector.{{cite web|url=http://news.msn.com/world/brazil-presidential-candidate-campos-killed-in-plane-crash|title=Breaking News Stories from US and Around the World - MSN News|website=news.msn.com|accessdate=3 September 2018}} As an [[Evangelical Christian]], she opposes [[abortion]].[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-08-15/deadly-plane-crash-turns-green-evangelical-into-brazil-kingmaker.html Bloomberg: "Deadly Plane Crash Turns Evangelical Into Brazil’s Kingmaker" By Raymond Colitt and David Biller] 15 August 2014 On 30 August 2014, Silva generated considerable controversy when she renounced the party's support for [[same-sex marriage]], which was supported by Campos and had been included in the party's manifesto, published a day earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/brazilian-presidential-candidate-drops-short-lived-gay-marriage-pledge010914-0|title=Brazilian presidential candidate drops short-lived gay marriage pledge: Marina Silva revises pro-gay government plan just one day after publication|editor=Gay Star News|date=1 September 2014|accessdate=14 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140909135205/http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/brazilian-presidential-candidate-drops-short-lived-gay-marriage-pledge010914-0|archivedate=9 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} On Sunday, 5 October 2014, Silva received 21% of the vote in the first round of the election, to Rousseff's 41% and Neves's 34%. Although many observers had expected Silva to advance to a second round against Rousseff, Silva ultimately received a much lower share of the vote than most opinion polls had indicated in the lead-up to the election, and did not advance to the 26 October run-off. Some days after the election she endorsed Aecio Neves in the run-off against Dilma Rousseff.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/brazil-election-blows-rousseff-silva-backs-rival|title=Brazil election blow for Rousseff after Silva backs rival for presidency|first=Jonathan|last=Watts|date=12 October 2014|website=the Guardian|accessdate=3 September 2018}} ==2018 Presidential bid== On 4 August 2018, Marina Silva was officially nominated as the Sustainability Network's presidential candidate in the [[Brazilian general election, 2018|2018 elections]]. Silva's running mate is [[Eduardo Jorge]] of the [[Green Party (Brazil)|Green Party]].https://g1.globo.com/politica/noticia/2018/08/04/rede-confirma-candidatura-de-marina-silva-a-presidencia-da-republica.ghtml Until August 2018, Silva came in third in [[Opinion polling for the Brazilian general election, 2018|opinion polls]] for the presidency, behind [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] (whose candidacy was later barred) and [[Jair Bolsonaro]]. However, she has later been overtaken by [[Ciro Gomes]], [[Fernando Haddad]], and [[Geraldo Alckmin]], and was later polling fifth on average.{{cite web |title=Brazil election Coverage |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-brazil-election/ |website=Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=27 September 2018}} In the last few days before the election, her poll numbers dropped significantly, and in the end she polled around a single percentage point. She came out eight with 1.0% and 1,066,893 votes. ==Political views== Marina Silva is generally considered to be a [[Centrism|centrist]] and an [[environmentalist]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/marina-silva-counts-on-brazil-anti-graft-wave-in-threadbare-campaign-idUSKBN1JW2PE |title=Marina Silva counts on Brazil anti-graft wave in threadbare campaign |last=Paraguassu |first=Lisandra |date=July 6, 2018 |work=Reuters U.S. |access-date=2018-09-06 |publisher=Reuters |last2=Brito |first2=Ricardo |location=Brazilia |language=en-US}} She is running on an anti-corruption platform. She opposes Brazil's nuclear energy program, and wants to redistribute the nuclear energy funds in order to allocate more money towards solar and wind power. Furthermore, she wants to initiate a national plebiscite on investments in nuclear energy.{{Cite web |url=https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/brazil-considers-nuclear-option |title=Brazil Considers the Nuclear Option |date=August 23, 2018 |website=Stratfor |language=en |access-date=2018-09-06}} She is in favor of imposing presidential [[term limits]].{{Cite web |url=https://wtop.com/latin-america/2018/06/brazil-presidential-contender-criticizes-rivals-candidacy/ |title=Marina Silva says Brazil needs change, but light on details |date=2018-06-08 |website=WTOP |publisher=Associated Press |location=Rio de Janeiro |language=en-US |access-date=2018-09-06}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Wikiquote|Marina Silva}} {{commonscat|Marina Silva|'''Marina Silva'''}} * {{Official Website|http://marinasilva.org.br/|name=Marina Silva}} {{pt icon}} {{Navboxes |title = Offices and distinctions |list1 = {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=José Carlos Carvalho}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of the Environment (Brazil)|Minister of the Environment]]|years=2003–2008}} {{s-aft|after=[[Carlos Minc]]}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=Alfredo Sirkis}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Green Party (Brazil)|Green Party]] nominee for [[President of Brazil]]|years=[[Brazilian general election, 2010|2010]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[Eduardo Jorge]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Anthony Garotinho]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Brazilian Socialist Party]] nominee for [[President of Brazil]]|years=[[Brazilian general election, 2014|2014]]}} {{s-inc|recent}} {{s-new|party}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Sustainability Network]] nominee for [[President of Brazil]]|years=[[Brazilian general election, 2018|2018]]}} {{s-inc|recent}} {{s-new|party}} {{s-ttl|title=Spokesperson of the [[Sustainability Network]]|years=2015–present|alongside=Zé Gustavo}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Silva de Lima, Marina}} revision.text:
{{otherpeople}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Mark Bright | image = | caption = | fullname = Mark Abraham Bright<ref name="kent"/> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|6|6|df=y}}<ref name="kent"/> | birth_place = [[Stoke-on-Trent]], England<ref name="kent"/> | height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Mark Bright|url=http://www.adrianbullock.com/swfc/stats/play0072.htm|website=www.adrianbullock.com|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] | years1 = 1980–1981 |clubs1 = [[Leek Town F.C.|Leek Town]] |caps1 = |goals1 = | years2 = 1981–1984 |clubs2 = [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] |caps2 = 29 |goals2 = 10 | years3 = 1984–1986 |clubs3 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] |caps3 = 42 |goals3 = 6 | years4 = 1986–1992 |clubs4 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] |caps4 = 227 |goals4 = 91 | years5 = 1992–1997 |clubs5 = [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] |caps5 = 133 |goals5 = 48 | years6 = 1996 |clubs6 = → [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] (loan) |caps6 = 3 |goals6 = 1 | years7 = 1997 |clubs7 = [[FC Sion|Sion]] |caps7 = 0 |goals7 = 0 | years8 = 1997–1999 |clubs8 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] |caps8 = 27 |goals8 = 10 | totalcaps = 461 |totalgoals = 166 }}
'''Mark Abraham Bright''' (born 6 June 1962) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]] who is now a sports [[pundit]] on [[BBC Television|BBC]], [[Eurosport|British Eurosport]] and [[Al Jazeera]], as well as a coach at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].
He made the move from non-league [[Leek Town F.C.|Leek Town]] to [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in 1981, where he remained for three years before he signed with [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. In 1986, he transferred to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], where he would score 92 league goals over the next six years. Joining [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in 1992, he stayed with the club for five years before moving to Swiss side [[FC Sion]] in 1997, following a short loan stay at [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]. He returned to England later in 1997 to play for [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], before he announced his retirement in 1999. A [[Forward (association football)|forward]], he scored 166 goals in 461 league games throughout an 18-year career in [[the Football League]]. He played in one [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] and two [[FA Cup]] finals, all of which ended in defeat. He helped Crystal Palace and Charlton Athletic to win promotion to the top-flight via the play-offs.
==Football career== After a spell working in a factory and playing part-time at [[Cheshire County League]] outfit [[Leek Town F.C.|Leek Town]], Bright moved to [[John McGrath (footballer, born 1938)|John McGrath]]'s [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in October 1981, a club that had previously released him from their youth team at the age of 16.<ref>{{cite news|title=Football: Top players must lead way on ref respect, says Vale hero Bright|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Football-players-lead-way-ref-respect-says-Vale/story-15199172-detail/story.html|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]]|date=11 February 2012}}</ref> He made his full debut on the last day of the [[1981–82 Port Vale F.C. season|1981–82]] season, in a 2–0 win over [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] at [[Vale Park]], two weeks after coming on as a [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a goalless home draw with [[York City F.C.|York City]] on 1 May 1982.<ref name="kent">{{cite book|last=Kent|first=Jeff|title=Port Vale Personalities|publisher=Witan Books|page=41|year=1996|isbn=0-9529152-0-0|url=https://www.amazon.ca/Port-Vale-Personalities-Jeff-Kent/dp/0952915200}}</ref> He played just once in the [[1982–83 Port Vale F.C. season|1982–83]] [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] promotion campaign, scoring Vale's second goal in a 2–0 home win over [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] on 9 October.<ref name="kent"/> Bright came to prominence for the "Valiants" under the stewardship of new boss [[John Rudge]] towards the end of the [[1983–84 Port Vale F.C. season|1983–84]] season, scoring ten goals in 31 games, though this was not enough to save the club from relegation out of the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]].<ref name="kent"/> [[Graham Barnett]] advised him to reject John Rudge's offer of a two-year contract, and in June 1984 Bright was sold to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for £33,333.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kent|first=Jeff|title=Port Vale Tales: A Collection Of Stories, Anecdotes And Memories|publisher=Witan Books|date=December 1991|pages=30|isbn=0-9508981-6-3}}</ref> This fee was later doubled due to a top-up clause.<ref name="kent"/>
[[Gordon Milne]]'s "Foxes" struggled in the lower half of the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] table in the [[1984–85 Football League|1984–85]] and [[1985–86 Leicester City F.C. season|1985–86]] seasons. Bright scored six goals in 42 league games in his two seasons on [[Filbert Street]]. He was sold on by new manager [[Bryan Hamilton]] early in the [[1986–87 Leicester City F.C. season|1986–87]] season.
Bright was signed to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] by manager [[Steve Coppell]] for a £75,000 fee in November 1986. The "Eagles" were pressing for promotion out of the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]], but finished two points outside the play-offs in [[1986–87 Football League|1986–87]]. He earned the Golden Boot for the highest scorer in the division in [[1987–88 Football League|1987–88]] with 24 goals, though again the club finished one place and two points outside of the play-offs.<ref name="BBCPO">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/biographies/biogs/sport/markbright.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202201514/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/biographies/biogs/sport/markbright.shtml |archivedate=2 February 2007 |title=Mark Bright |publisher= ''BBC Press Office''|date=April 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> A third-place finish in [[1988–89 Football League|1988–89]] secured them a play-off place. In the [[1989 Football League play-offs|play-offs]], he scored in the semi-final victory over [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], which helped Palace to reach the [[1989 Football League Second Division play-off Final|play-off final]]; Palace then beat [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] 4–3 on aggregate, to win promotion to the top-flight.
His 12 goals in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] in [[1989–90 Football League|1989–90]] were an important part of Palace's creditable showing, and it was Bright's crashing drive at the start of the second-half that began Palace's recovery against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the [[FA Cup]] semi-final and ultimately helped them to get to the [[1990 FA Cup Final|final]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]]. Their victory over Liverpool was particularly remarkable as they had [[Liverpool 9–0 Crystal Palace (1989)|lost 9–0]] at [[Anfield]] at the start of the season. After a 3–3 draw in the original tie, Palace lost 1–0 to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the replay of the final.
As Palace impressed in the First Division throughout [[1990–91 Crystal Palace F.C. season|1990–91]], Bright proved his predatory skills at the highest level with a sequence of seven top-flight goals in just ten midwinter games as the "Eagles" secured their highest ever league finish of third. The potency of Bright and [[Ian Wright]]'s partnership was demonstrated on 25 September 1990, when both players scored hat-tricks in an 8–0 win over [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] at [[Selhurst Park]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]]. Even after Wright had left the club Bright continued his great form for Palace, and his 17 First Division goals in [[1991–92 Crystal Palace F.C. season|1991–92]] was, at the time, a record return for a Palace striker in the top-flight; he was also the division's seventh highest scorer.
Bright left Palace for [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in September 1992 in a cash plus player exchange deal involving fellow striker [[Paul Williams (footballer, born 1965)|Paul Williams]]. He finished as the [[List of Sheffield Wednesday F.C. seasons|club's top-scorer]] for three consecutive seasons, taking pressure off club stalwart [[David Hirst (footballer)|David Hirst]]. He eventually became the "Owls" highest goalscorer in the [[Premier League]] to date, scoring 48 goals between 1992 and 1996.<ref name="BBCPO" /> After scoring six goals in the [[1992–93 Football League Cup|League Cup]], Bright played in the [[1993 Football League Cup Final|League Cup Final]], which ended in a 2–1 defeat to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. One of Bright's notable goals came in the [[Steel City derby|All-Sheffield]] FA Cup [[1992–93 FA Cup|semi-final in 1993]], Bright's extra-time header sealing a place in the [[1993 FA Cup Final|final]]. He fared far less well in the final itself, controversially elbowing Arsenal defender [[Andy Linighan]] in the face, causing a broken nose. Later, with the scores level in the last minute of extra time, a heavily bandaged Linighan out-jumped Bright from a corner to score the winning goal.<ref name="ldd">{{cite news|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/7109931.New_season_will_begin_again_minus_a_Linighan/|title=New season will begin again minus a Linighan|date=11 May 2001 |work=The Northern Echo|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>
With 19 goals, he was Wednesday's highest scorer and the Premier League's seventh highest scorer in [[1993–94 Sheffield Wednesday F.C. season|1993–94]]. He then hit 13 goals in the [[1994–95 Sheffield Wednesday F.C. season|1994–95]] season, in manager [[Trevor Francis]]'s last season in charge. Bright played in the [[1995 UEFA Intertoto Cup]], scoring goals against [[Poland|Polish]] club [[Górnik Zabrze]], German side [[Karlsruher SC]], and [[Denmark|Danish]] side [[Aarhus Gymnastikforening|AGF]]. The [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]] outfit then finished 15th in the league in [[1995–96 Sheffield Wednesday F.C. season|1995–96]] under the stewardship of [[David Pleat]]. Bright then fell out of the first team picture in [[1996–97 Sheffield Wednesday F.C. season|1996–97]], and was loaned to Second Division side [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], before joining Swiss club [[FC Sion]] in January 1997. He left soon after due to unpaid wages and issues with his transfer fee with Sheffield Wednesday.<ref name="Sion">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/29210/9242320/brits-abroad-former-crystal-palace-hero-mark-bright-discusses-his-brief-stay-in-switzerland-with-fc-sion|title=Brits abroad: Former Crystal Palace hero Mark Bright discusses his brief stay in Switzerland with FC Sion|date=4 April 2014|work=Sky Sports|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref>
Bright joined [[Alan Curbishley]]'s [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] towards the end of the [[1996–97 Charlton Athletic F.C. season|1996–97]] season. He helped the "Addicks" to finish fourth in the second tier in [[1997–98 Football League|1997–98]], and played in their dramatic win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the [[1998 Football League First Division play-off Final|1998 play off final]],<ref name="BBCPO" /> which was won 7–6 on [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]] after a 4–4 draw. He left [[The Valley (London)|The Valley]] and retired from professional football at the end of the [[1998–99 Charlton Athletic F.C. season|1998–99]] season.
==Media career== After retiring, Bright became a football correspondent on ''[[The Big Breakfast]]''. He currently works on the [[BBC]] show ''[[Football Focus]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/football_focus/3569255.stm|title=Mark Bright|date=25 March 2004|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 May 2009}}</ref> He also commentates on some international matches, often alongside [[Jonathan Pearce]] and [[Steve Wilson (football commentator)|Steve Wilson]] on ''[[Match of the Day]]''.<ref name="BBCPO" /> He is also the sports correspondent for [[BBC London News]].<ref name="BBCPO" /> He has also written for ''[[Match (magazine)|Match]]'' magazine, appeared on ''[[606 (radio show)|606]]'' phone-in show, ''[[Fighting Talk]]'' radio show, ''[[5 live Sport]]'' radio show, and on television programme ''[[Final Score]]''.
In 2013, Bright agreed to join the British Eurosport team to commentate on the live [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations|African Cup of Nations]] matches.
Bright featured as himself in a television advert for [[Cancer Research UK|Prostate Cancer UK]] in January 2013 alongside impressionist [[Jon Culshaw]], who featured as [[Tiziano Crudeli]].
For the 2013/14 season, Bright joined [[Al Jazeera]] as a [[pundit]] on their [[Premier League]] coverage.
==Coaching career== In summer 2009 he joined the Crystal Palace academy set-up, along with his former teammate [[John Salako]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10323~1790306,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224075535/http://www.cpfc.co.uk/page/News/0%2C%2C10323~1790306%2C00.html |archivedate=24 February 2012 |title=Palace Legends Join Academy Set Up |publisher=Crystal Palace FC |date=11 September 2009 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Personal life== Bright's father was [[The Gambia|Gambian]] and his mother was English, he was raised in his mother's hometown of [[Stoke-on-Trent]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Pupils-Bright-idea-African-aid-mission/story-12481558-detail/story.html|title=Former Port Vale star returns to school to help African children|date=11 June 2009|work=The Sentinel|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>
He met British singer and actress [[Michelle Gayle]] in 1995, the couple later married in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and in 2000 had a son they named Isaiah. They separated in 2007, though remain on good terms.
In his spare time he enjoys playing [[golf]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/jul/04/newsstory.sport3|title=Mark Bright|date=4 July 2003|work=The Guardian|accessdate=12 October 2013 | location=London | first=Dan | last=Rookwood}}</ref> and riding [[Motorcycle|motorbike]]s.<ref name="BBCPO" />
Bright has completed six [[half marathon]]s since his retirement in 1999, all of them in the [[Great North Run]].<ref name="BBCPO" /> He is also a regular competitor in the [[London Marathon]], raising funds for [[cancer research]] in 2000, the [[Willow Foundation]] in 2005 and The Rhys Daniels Trust in 2006.<ref name="BBCPO" /> In 2006, he starred in [[Cirque de Celebrité]], only to be the first person to be voted off. In March 2007, he scored the first goal at the new [[Wembley Stadium]] for a "Geoff Thomas Foundation Charity XI", in aid of his captain at Palace, [[Geoff Thomas (footballer, born 1964)|Geoff Thomas]]; his team won 2–0 ([[Simon Jordan]] scoring the second goal).<ref name="BBCPO" />
==Statistics== Source:<ref>{{ENFA}}</ref>
